The body appears transparent, apart from black pigment at the end of its abdomen." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="424" data-file-width="546" height="171" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Drosophila_melanogaster_-_side_%28aka%29.jpg/220px-Drosophila_melanogaster_-_side_%28aka%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Drosophila_melanogaster_-_side_%28aka%29.jpg/330px-Drosophila_melanogaster_-_side_%28aka%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Drosophila_melanogaster_-_side_%28aka%29.jpg/440px-Drosophila_melanogaster_-_side_%28aka%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
     </a>
     <div class="thumbcaption">
      <div class="magnify">
       <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Drosophila_melanogaster_-_side_(aka).jpg" title="Enlarge">
       </a>
      </div>
      Fruit flies (
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Drosophila" title="Drosophila">
        Drosophila
       </a>
      </i>
      ) have been extensively studied to gain insight into the role of genes in brain development.
     </div>
    </div>
   </div>
   <p>
    This category includes
    <a href="/wiki/Tardigrade" title="Tardigrade">
     tardigrades
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Arthropod" title="Arthropod">
     arthropods
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Mollusca" title="Mollusca">
     molluscs
    </a>
    , and numerous types of worms. The diversity of invertebrate body plans is matched by an equal diversity in brain structures.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17">
     <a href="#cite_note-17">
      [17]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Two groups of invertebrates have notably complex brains: arthropods (insects,
    <a href="/wiki/Crustacean" title="Crustacean">
     crustaceans
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Arachnid" title="Arachnid">
     arachnids
    </a>
    , and others), and
    <a href="/wiki/Cephalopod" title="Cephalopod">
     cephalopods
    </a>
    (octopuses,
    <a href="/wiki/Squid" title="Squid">
     squids
    </a>
    , and similar molluscs).
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Butler_18-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Butler-18">
      [18]
     </a>
    </sup>
    The brains of arthropods and cephalopods arise from twin parallel nerve cords that extend through the body of the animal. Arthropods have a central brain, the
    <a href="/wiki/Supraesophageal_ganglion" title="Supraesophageal ganglion">
     supraesophageal ganglion
    </a>
    , with three divisions and large
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Optic_lobe_(arthropod)" title="Optic lobe (arthropod)">
     optical lobes
    </a>
    behind each eye for visual processing.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Butler_18-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-Butler-18">
      [18]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Cephalopods such as the octopus and squid have the largest brains of any invertebrates.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bulloch1995_19-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Bulloch1995-19">
      [19]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    There are several invertebrate species whose brains have been studied intensively because they have properties that make them convenient for experimental work:
   </p>
   <ul>
    <li>
     Fruit flies (
     <i>
      Drosophila
     </i>
     ), because of the large array of techniques available for studying their
     <a href="/wiki/Genetics" title="Genetics">
      genetics
     </a>
     , have been a natural subject for studying the role of genes in brain development.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
      <a href="#cite_note-20">
       [20]
      </a>
     </sup>
     In spite of the large evolutionary distance between insects and mammals, many aspects of
     <i>
      Drosophila
     </i>
     <a href="/wiki/Neurogenetics" title="Neurogenetics">
      neurogenetics
     </a>
     have been shown to be relevant to humans. The first biological
     <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Clock_gene" title="Clock gene">
      clock genes
     </a>
     , for example, were identified by examining
     <i>
      Drosophila
     </i>
     mutants that showed disrupted daily activity cycles.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21">
      <a href="#cite_note-21">
       [21]
      </a>
     </sup>
     A search in the genomes of vertebrates revealed a set of analogous genes, which were found to play similar roles in the mouse biological clock—and therefore almost certainly in the human biological clock as well.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22">
      <a href="#cite_note-22">
       [22]
      </a>
     </sup>
     Studies done on Drosophila, also show that most
     <a href="/wiki/Neuropil" title="Neuropil">
      neuropil
     </a>
     regions of the brain are continuously reorganized throughout life in response to specific living conditions.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23">
      <a href="#cite_note-23">
       [23]
      </a>
     </sup>
    </li>
    <li>
     The nematode worm
     <i>
      <a href="/wiki/Caenorhabditis_elegans" title="Caenorhabditis elegans">
       Caenorhabditis elegans
      </a>
     </i>
     , like
     <i>
      Drosophila
     </i>
     , has been studied largely because of its importance in genetics.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
      <a href="#cite_note-24">
       [24]
      </a>
     </sup>
     In the early 1970s,
     <a href="/wiki/Sydney_Brenner" title="Sydney Brenner">
      Sydney Brenner
     </a>
     chose it as a
     <a href="/wiki/Model_organism" title="Model organism">
      model organism
     </a>
     for studying the way that genes control development. One of the advantages of working with this worm is that the body plan is very stereotyped: the nervous system of the
     <a href="/wiki/Hermaphrodite" title="Hermaphrodite">
      hermaphrodite
     </a>
     contains exactly 302 neurons, always in the same places, making identical synaptic connections in every worm.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25">
      <a href="#cite_note-25">
       [25]
      </a>
     </sup>
     Brenner's team sliced worms into thousands of ultrathin sections and photographed each one under an electron microscope, then visually matched fibers from section to section, to map out every neuron and synapse in the entire body.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26">
      <a href="#cite_note-26">
       [26]
      </a>
     </sup>
     The complete neuronal
     <i>
      wiring diagram
     </i>
     of
     <i>
      C.elegans
     </i>
     – its
     <a href="/wiki/Connectome" title="Connectome">
      connectome
     </a>
     was achieved.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27">
      <a href="#cite_note-27">
       [27]
      </a>
     </sup>
     Nothing approaching this level of detail is available for any other organism, and the information gained has enabled a multitude of studies that would otherwise have not been possible.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28">
      <a href="#cite_note-28">
       [28]
      </a>
     </sup>
    </li>
    <li>
     The sea slug
     <i>
      <a href="/wiki/Aplysia" title="Aplysia">
       Aplysia
      </a>
      californica
     </i>
     was chosen by Nobel Prize-winning neurophysiologist
     <a href="/wiki/Eric_Kandel" title="Eric Kandel">
      Eric Kandel
     </a>
     as a model for studying the cellular basis of
     <a href="/wiki/Learning" title="Learning">
      learning
     </a>
     and
     <a href="/wiki/Memory" title="Memory">
      memory
     </a>
     , because of the simplicity and accessibility of its nervous system, and it has been examined in hundreds of experiments.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29">
      <a href="#cite_note-29">
       [29]
      </a>
     </sup>
    </li>
   </ul>
   <h4>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Vertebrates">
     Vertebrates
    </span>
   </h4>
   <div class="thumb tright">
    <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
     <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Shark_brain.png">
      <img alt="A T-shaped object is made up of the cord at the bottom which feeds into a lower central mass. This is topped by a larger central mass with an arm extending from either side." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="362" data-file-width="348" height="177" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Shark_brain.png/170px-Shark_brain.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Shark_brain.png/255px-Shark_brain.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Shark_brain.png/340px-Shark_brain.png 2x" width="170"/>
     </a>
     <div class="thumbcaption">
      <div class="magnify">
       <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Shark_brain.png" title="Enlarge">
       </a>
      </div>
      The brain of a
      <a href="/wiki/Shark" title="Shark">
       shark
      </a>
     </div>
    </div>
   </div>
   <p>
    The first
    <a href="/wiki/Vertebrate" title="Vertebrate">
     vertebrates
    </a>
    appeared over 500 million years ago (
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mya_(unit)" title="Mya (unit)">
     Mya
    </a>
    ), during the
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cambrian_period" title="Cambrian period">
     Cambrian period
    </a>
    , and may have resembled the modern
    <a href="/wiki/Hagfish" title="Hagfish">
     hagfish
    </a>
    in form.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30">
     <a href="#cite_note-30">
      [30]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Sharks appeared about 450 Mya, amphibians about 400 Mya, reptiles about 350 Mya, and mammals about 200 Mya. Each species has an equally long
    <a href="/wiki/Evolution" title="Evolution">
     evolutionary history
    </a>
    , but the brains of modern hagfishes,
    <a href="/wiki/Lamprey" title="Lamprey">
     lampreys
    </a>
    , sharks, amphibians, reptiles, and mammals show a gradient of size and complexity that roughly follows the evolutionary sequence. All of these brains contain the same set of basic anatomical components, but many are rudimentary in the hagfish, whereas in mammals the foremost part (the
    <a href="/wiki/Cerebrum" title="Cerebrum">
     telencephalon
    </a>
    ) is greatly elaborated and expanded.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31">
     <a href="#cite_note-31">
      [31]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Brains are most simply compared in terms of their size. The relationship between
    <a href="/wiki/Brain_size" title="Brain size">
     brain size
    </a>
    , body size and other variables has been studied across a wide range of vertebrate species. As a rule, brain size increases with body size, but not in a simple linear proportion. In general, smaller animals tend to have larger brains, measured as a fraction of body size. For mammals, the relationship between brain volume and body mass essentially follows a
    <a href="/wiki/Power_law" title="Power law">
     power law
    </a>
    with an
    <a href="/wiki/Exponentiation" title="Exponentiation">
     exponent
    </a>
    of about 0.75.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32">
     <a href="#cite_note-32">
      [32]
     </a>
    </sup>
    This formula describes the central tendency, but every family of mammals departs from it to some degree, in a way that reflects in part the complexity of their behavior. For example, primates have brains 5 to 10 times larger than the formula predicts. Predators tend to have larger brains than their prey, relative to body size.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33">
     <a href="#cite_note-33">
      [33]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <div class="thumb tleft">
    <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
     <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:EmbryonicBrain.svg">
      <img alt="The nervous system is shown as a rod with protrusions along its length. The spinal cord at the bottom connects to the hindbrain which widens out before narrowing again. This is connected to the midbrain, which again bulges, and which finally connects to the forebrain which has two large protrusions." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="720" data-file-width="960" height="188" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/EmbryonicBrain.svg/250px-EmbryonicBrain.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/EmbryonicBrain.svg/375px-EmbryonicBrain.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/EmbryonicBrain.svg/500px-EmbryonicBrain.svg.png 2x" width="250"/>
     </a>
     <div class="thumbcaption">
      <div class="magnify">
       <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:EmbryonicBrain.svg" title="Enlarge">
       </a>
      </div>
      The main subdivisions of the
      <a href="/wiki/Embryogenesis" title="Embryogenesis">
       embryonic
      </a>
      vertebrate brain, which later differentiate into the forebrain, midbrain and hindbrain
     </div>
    </div>
   </div>
   <p>
    All vertebrate brains share a common underlying form, which appears most clearly during early stages of embryonic development. In its earliest form, the brain appears as three swellings at the front end of the
    <a href="/wiki/Neural_tube" title="Neural tube">
     neural tube
    </a>
    ; these swellings eventually become the forebrain, midbrain, and hindbrain (the
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prosencephalon" title="Prosencephalon">
     prosencephalon
    </a>
    ,
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mesencephalon" title="Mesencephalon">
     mesencephalon
    </a>
    , and
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rhombencephalon" title="Rhombencephalon">
     rhombencephalon
    </a>
    , respectively). At the earliest stages of brain development, the three areas are roughly equal in size. In many classes of vertebrates, such as fish and amphibians, the three parts remain similar in size in the adult, but in mammals the forebrain becomes much larger than the other parts, and the midbrain becomes very small.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kandel_2000_7-5">
     <a href="#cite_note-Kandel_2000-7">
      [7]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    The brains of vertebrates are made of very soft tissue.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kandel_2000_7-6">
     <a href="#cite_note-Kandel_2000-7">
      [7]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Living brain tissue is pinkish on the outside and mostly white on the inside, with subtle variations in color. Vertebrate brains are surrounded by a system of
    <a href="/wiki/Connective_tissue" title="Connective tissue">
     connective tissue
    </a>
    <a href="/wiki/Biological_membrane" title="Biological membrane">
     membranes
    </a>
    called
    <a href="/wiki/Meninges" title="Meninges">
     meninges
    </a>
    that separate the skull from the brain.
    <a href="/wiki/Blood_vessel" title="Blood vessel">
     Blood vessels
    </a>
    enter the central nervous system through holes in the meningeal layers. The cells in the blood vessel walls are joined tightly to one another, forming the
    <a href="/wiki/Blood%E2%80%93brain_barrier" title="Blood–brain barrier">
     blood–brain barrier
    </a>
    , which blocks the passage of many
    <a href="/wiki/Toxin" title="Toxin">
     toxins
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Pathogen" title="Pathogen">
     pathogens
    </a>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CarpenterCh1_34-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-CarpenterCh1-34">
      [34]
     </a>
    </sup>
    (though at the same time blocking
    <a href="/wiki/Antibody" title="Antibody">
     antibodies
    </a>
    and some drugs, thereby presenting special challenges in treatment of diseases of the brain).
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35">
     <a href="#cite_note-35">
      [35]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    <a href="/wiki/Neuroanatomy" title="Neuroanatomy">
     Neuroanatomists
    </a>
    usually divide the vertebrate brain into six main regions: the
    <a href="/wiki/Cerebrum" title="Cerebrum">
     telencephalon
    </a>
    (cerebral hemispheres),
    <a href="/wiki/Diencephalon" title="Diencephalon">
     diencephalon
    </a>
    (thalamus and hypothalamus),
    <a href="/wiki/Midbrain" title="Midbrain">
     mesencephalon
    </a>
    (midbrain),
    <a href="/wiki/Cerebellum" title="Cerebellum">
     cerebellum
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Pons" title="Pons">
     pons
    </a>
    , and
    <a href="/wiki/Medulla_oblongata" title="Medulla oblongata">
     medulla oblongata
    </a>
    . Each of these areas has a complex internal structure. Some parts, such as the cerebral cortex and the cerebellar cortex, consist of layers that are folded or convoluted to fit within the available space. Other parts, such as the thalamus and hypothalamus, consist of clusters of many small nuclei. Thousands of distinguishable areas can be identified within the vertebrate brain based on fine distinctions of neural structure, chemistry, and connectivity.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kandel_2000_7-7">
     <a href="#cite_note-Kandel_2000-7">
      [7]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Although the same basic components are present in all vertebrate brains, some branches of vertebrate evolution have led to substantial distortions of brain geometry, especially in the forebrain area. The brain of a shark shows the basic components in a straightforward way, but in
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Teleostei" title="Teleostei">
     teleost
    </a>
    fishes (the great majority of existing fish species), the forebrain has become "everted", like a sock turned inside out. In birds, there are also major changes in forebrain structure.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36">
     <a href="#cite_note-36">
      [36]
     </a>
    </sup>
    These distortions can make it difficult to match brain components from one species with those of another species.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37">
     <a href="#cite_note-37">
      [37]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <div class="thumb tright">
    <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
     <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vertebrate-brain-regions_small.png">
      <img alt="Corresponding regions of human and shark brain are shown. The shark brain is splayed out, while the human brain is more compact. The shark brain starts with the medulla, which is surrounded by various structures, and ends with the telencephalon. The cross-section of the human brain shows the medulla at the bottom surrounded by the same structures, with the telencephalon thickly coating the top of the brain." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="432" data-file-width="300" height="317" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Vertebrate-brain-regions_small.png/220px-Vertebrate-brain-regions_small.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/be/Vertebrate-brain-regions_small.png 1.5x" width="220"/>
     </a>
     <div class="thumbcaption">
      <div class="magnify">
       <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vertebrate-brain-regions_small.png" title="Enlarge">
       </a>
      </div>
      The main anatomical regions of the vertebrate brain, shown for shark and human. The same parts are present, but they differ greatly in size and shape.
     </div>
    </div>
   </div>
   <p>
    Here is a list of some of the most important vertebrate brain components, along with a brief description of their functions as currently understood:
   </p>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    See also:
    <a href="/wiki/List_of_regions_in_the_human_brain" title="List of regions in the human brain">
     List of regions in the human brain
    </a>
   </div>
   <ul>
    <li>
     The
     <b>
      <a href="/wiki/Medulla_oblongata" title="Medulla oblongata">
       medulla
      </a>
     </b>
     , along with the spinal cord, contains many small nuclei involved in a wide variety of sensory and involuntary motor functions such as vomiting, heart rate and digestive processes.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kandel_2000_7-8">
      <a href="#cite_note-Kandel_2000-7">
       [7]
      </a>
     </sup>
    </li>
    <li>
     The
     <b>
      <a href="/wiki/Pons" title="Pons">
       pons
      </a>
     </b>
     lies in the brainstem directly above the medulla. Among other things, it contains nuclei that control often voluntary but simple acts such as sleep, respiration, swallowing, bladder function, equilibrium, eye movement, facial expressions, and posture.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38">
      <a href="#cite_note-38">
       [38]
      </a>
     </sup>
    </li>
    <li>
     The
     <b>
      <a href="/wiki/Hypothalamus" title="Hypothalamus">
       hypothalamus
      </a>
     </b>
     is a small region at the base of the forebrain, whose complexity and importance belies its size. It is composed of numerous small nuclei, each with distinct connections and neurochemistry. The hypothalamus is engaged in additional involuntary or partially voluntary acts such as sleep and wake cycles, eating and drinking, and the release of some hormones.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39">
      <a href="#cite_note-39">
       [39]
      </a>
     </sup>
    </li>
    <li>
     The
     <b>
      <a href="/wiki/Thalamus" title="Thalamus">
       thalamus
      </a>
     </b>
     is a collection of nuclei with diverse functions: some are involved in relaying information to and from the cerebral hemispheres, while others are involved in motivation. The subthalamic area (
     <a href="/wiki/Zona_incerta" title="Zona incerta">
      zona incerta
     </a>
     ) seems to contain action-generating systems for several types of "consummatory" behaviors such as eating, drinking, defecation, and copulation.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40">
      <a href="#cite_note-40">
       [40]
      </a>
     </sup>
    </li>
    <li>
     The
     <b>
      <a href="/wiki/Cerebellum" title="Cerebellum">
       cerebellum
      </a>
     </b>
     modulates the outputs of other brain systems, whether motor related or thought related, to make them certain and precise. Removal of the cerebellum does not prevent an animal from doing anything in particular, but it makes actions hesitant and clumsy. This precision is not built-in, but learned by trial and error. The muscle coordination learned while riding a bicycle is an example of a type of
     <a href="/wiki/Neuroplasticity" title="Neuroplasticity">
      neural plasticity
     </a>
     that may take place largely within the cerebellum.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kandel_2000_7-9">
      <a href="#cite_note-Kandel_2000-7">
       [7]
      </a>
     </sup>
     10% of the brain's total volume consists of the cerebellum and 50% of all neurons are held within its structure.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41">
      <a href="#cite_note-41">
       [41]
      </a>
     </sup>
    </li>
    <li>
     The
     <b>
      <a href="/wiki/Superior_colliculus" title="Superior colliculus">
       optic tectum
      </a>
     </b>
     allows actions to be directed toward points in space, most commonly in response to visual input. In mammals it is usually referred to as the
     <a href="/wiki/Superior_colliculus" title="Superior colliculus">
      superior colliculus
     </a>
     , and its best-studied function is to direct eye movements. It also directs reaching movements and other object-directed actions. It receives strong visual inputs, but also inputs from other senses that are useful in directing actions, such as auditory input in owls and input from the thermosensitive
     <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pit_organ" title="Pit organ">
      pit organs
     </a>
     in snakes. In some primitive fishes, such as
     <a href="/wiki/Lamprey" title="Lamprey">
      lampreys
     </a>
     , this region is the largest part of the brain.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42">
      <a href="#cite_note-42">
       [42]
      </a>
     </sup>
     The superior colliculus is part of the midbrain.
    </li>
    <li>
     The
     <b>
      <a href="/wiki/Pallium_(neuroanatomy)" title="Pallium (neuroanatomy)">
       pallium
      </a>
     </b>
     is a layer of gray matter that lies on the surface of the forebrain and is the most complex and most recent evolutionary development of the brain as an organ.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LullFerris1922_43-0">
      <a href="#cite_note-LullFerris1922-43">
       [43]
      </a>
     </sup>
     In reptiles and mammals, it is called the
     <i>
      cerebral cortex
     </i>
     . Multiple functions involve the pallium, including
     <a href="/wiki/Olfaction" title="Olfaction">
      smell
     </a>
     and
     <a href="/wiki/Spatial_memory" title="Spatial memory">
      spatial memory
     </a>
     . In mammals, where it becomes so large as to dominate the brain, it takes over functions from many other brain areas. In many mammals, the cerebral cortex consists of folded bulges called
     <a href="/wiki/Gyrus" title="Gyrus">
      gyri
     </a>
     that create deep furrows or fissures called
     <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sulcus_(anatomy)" title="Sulcus (anatomy)">
      sulci
     </a>
     . The folds increase the surface area of the cortex and therefore increase the amount of gray matter and the amount of information that can be stored and processed.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44">
      <a href="#cite_note-44">
       [44]
      </a>
     </sup>
    </li>
    <li>
     The
     <b>
      <a href="/wiki/Hippocampus" title="Hippocampus">
       hippocampus
      </a>
     </b>
     , strictly speaking, is found only in mammals. However, the area it derives from, the medial pallium, has counterparts in all vertebrates. There is evidence that this part of the brain is involved in complex events such as spatial memory and navigation in fishes, birds, reptiles, and mammals.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45">
      <a href="#cite_note-45">
       [45]
      </a>
     </sup>
    </li>
    <li>
     The
     <b>
      <a href="/wiki/Basal_ganglia" title="Basal ganglia">
       basal ganglia
      </a>
     </b>
     are a group of interconnected structures in the forebrain. The primary function of the basal ganglia appears to be
     <a href="/wiki/Action_selection" title="Action selection">
      action selection
     </a>
     : they send inhibitory signals to all parts of the brain that can generate motor behaviors, and in the right circumstances can release the inhibition, so that the action-generating systems are able to execute their actions. Reward and punishment exert their most important neural effects by altering connections within the basal ganglia.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Grillner2005_46-0">
      <a href="#cite_note-Grillner2005-46">
       [46]
      </a>
     </sup>
    </li>
    <li>
     The
     <b>
      <a href="/wiki/Olfactory_bulb" title="Olfactory bulb">
       olfactory bulb
      </a>
     </b>
     is a special structure that processes olfactory sensory signals and sends its output to the olfactory part of the pallium. It is a major brain component in many vertebrates, but is greatly reduced in humans and other primates (whose senses are dominated by information acquired by sight rather than smell).
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47">
      <a href="#cite_note-47">
       [47]
      </a>
     </sup>
    </li>
   </ul>
   <h4>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Mammals">
     Mammals
    </span>
   </h4>
   <p>
    The most obvious difference between the brains of mammals and other vertebrates is in terms of size. On average, a mammal has a brain roughly twice as large as that of a bird of the same body size, and ten times as large as that of a reptile of the same body size.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Northcutt2002_48-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Northcutt2002-48">
      [48]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Size, however, is not the only difference: there are also substantial differences in shape. The hindbrain and midbrain of mammals are generally similar to those of other vertebrates, but dramatic differences appear in the forebrain, which is greatly enlarged and also altered in structure.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Barton_49-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Barton-49">
      [49]
     </a>
    </sup>
    The cerebral cortex is the part of the brain that most strongly distinguishes mammals. In non-mammalian vertebrates, the surface of the
    <a href="/wiki/Cerebrum" title="Cerebrum">
     cerebrum
    </a>
    is lined with a comparatively simple three-layered structure called the
    <a href="/wiki/Pallium_(neuroanatomy)" title="Pallium (neuroanatomy)">
     pallium
    </a>
    . In mammals, the pallium evolves into a complex six-layered structure called
    <a href="/wiki/Neocortex" title="Neocortex">
     neocortex
    </a>
    or
    <i>
     isocortex
    </i>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Aboitiz_50-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Aboitiz-50">
      [50]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Several areas at the edge of the neocortex, including the hippocampus and
    <a href="/wiki/Amygdala" title="Amygdala">
     amygdala
    </a>
    , are also much more extensively developed in mammals than in other vertebrates.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Barton_49-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-Barton-49">
      [49]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    The elaboration of the cerebral cortex carries with it changes to other brain areas. The
    <a href="/wiki/Superior_colliculus" title="Superior colliculus">
     superior colliculus
    </a>
    , which plays a major role in visual control of behavior in most vertebrates, shrinks to a small size in mammals, and many of its functions are taken over by visual areas of the cerebral cortex.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Northcutt2002_48-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-Northcutt2002-48">
      [48]
     </a>
    </sup>
    The cerebellum of mammals contains a large portion (the
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neocerebellum" title="Neocerebellum">
     neocerebellum
    </a>
    ) dedicated to supporting the cerebral cortex, which has no counterpart in other vertebrates.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51">
     <a href="#cite_note-51">
      [51]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h5>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Primates">
     Primates
    </span>
   </h5>
   <table align="right" class="wikitable" style="margin-left: 10px;">
    <caption>
     Encephalization Quotient
    </caption>
    <tr>
     <th>
      Species
     </th>
     <th>
      EQ
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Roth2005_52-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Roth2005-52">
        [52]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </th>
    </tr>
    <tr>
     <td>
      Human
     </td>
     <td>
      7.4–7.8
     </td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
     <td>
      <a href="/wiki/Chimpanzee" title="Chimpanzee">
       Chimpanzee
      </a>
     </td>
     <td>
      2.2–2.5
     </td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
     <td>
      <a href="/wiki/Rhesus_macaque" title="Rhesus macaque">
       Rhesus monkey
      </a>
     </td>
     <td>
      2.1
     </td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
     <td>
      <a href="/wiki/Bottlenose_dolphin" title="Bottlenose dolphin">
       Bottlenose dolphin
      </a>
     </td>
     <td>
      4.14
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Marino_53-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Marino-53">
        [53]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
     <td>
      Elephant
     </td>
     <td>
      1.13–2.36
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54">
       <a href="#cite_note-54">
        [54]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
     <td>
      Dog
     </td>
     <td>
      1.2
     </td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
     <td>
      Horse
     </td>
     <td>
      0.9
     </td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
     <td>
      <a href="/wiki/Rat" title="Rat">
       Rat
      </a>
     </td>
     <td>
      0.4
     </td>
    </tr>
   </table>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    See also:
    <a href="/wiki/Human_brain" title="Human brain">
     Human brain
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    The brains of humans and other
    <a href="/wiki/Primate" title="Primate">
     primates
    </a>
    contain the same structures as the brains of other mammals, but are generally larger in proportion to body size.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Finlay_55-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Finlay-55">
      [55]
     </a>
    </sup>
    The
    <a href="/wiki/Encephalization_quotient" title="Encephalization quotient">
     encephalization quotient
    </a>
    (EQ) is used to compare brain sizes across species. It takes into account the nonlinearity of the brain-to-body relationship.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Roth2005_52-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-Roth2005-52">
      [52]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Humans have an average EQ in the 7-to-8 range, while most other primates have an EQ in the 2-to-3 range. Dolphins have values higher than those of primates other than humans,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Marino_53-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-Marino-53">
      [53]
     </a>
    </sup>
    but nearly all other mammals have EQ values that are substantially lower.
   </p>
   <p>
    Most of the enlargement of the primate brain comes from a massive expansion of the cerebral cortex, especially the
    <a href="/wiki/Prefrontal_cortex" title="Prefrontal cortex">
     prefrontal cortex
    </a>
    and the parts of the cortex involved in
    <a href="/wiki/Visual_perception" title="Visual perception">
     vision
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56">
     <a href="#cite_note-56">
      [56]
     </a>
    </sup>
    The visual processing network of primates includes at least 30 distinguishable brain areas, with a complex web of interconnections. It has been estimated that visual processing areas occupy more than half of the total surface of the primate neocortex.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sereno1995_57-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Sereno1995-57">
      [57]
     </a>
    </sup>
    The
    <a href="/wiki/Prefrontal_cortex" title="Prefrontal cortex">
     prefrontal cortex
    </a>
    carries out functions that include
    <a href="/wiki/Foresight_(psychology)" title="Foresight (psychology)">
     planning
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Working_memory" title="Working memory">
     working memory
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Motivation" title="Motivation">
     motivation
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Attention" title="Attention">
     attention
    </a>
    , and
    <a href="/wiki/Executive_functions" title="Executive functions">
     executive control
    </a>
    . It takes up a much larger proportion of the brain for primates than for other species, and an especially large fraction of the human brain.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58">
     <a href="#cite_note-58">
      [58]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h2>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Development">
     Development
    </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neural_development" title="Neural development">
     Neural development
    </a>
   </div>
   <div class="thumb tright">
    <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
     <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:6_week_embryo_brain.jpg">
      <img alt="Very simple drawing of the front end of a human embryo, showing each vesicle of the developing brain in a different color." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="401" data-file-width="544" height="221" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/6_week_embryo_brain.jpg/300px-6_week_embryo_brain.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/6_week_embryo_brain.jpg/450px-6_week_embryo_brain.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c8/6_week_embryo_brain.jpg 2x" width="300"/>
     </a>
     <div class="thumbcaption">
      <div class="magnify">
       <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:6_week_embryo_brain.jpg" title="Enlarge">
       </a>
      </div>
      Brain of a human embryo in the sixth week of development
     </div>
    </div>
   </div>
   <p>
    The brain develops in an intricately orchestrated sequence of stages.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Purves_1985_59-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Purves_1985-59">
      [59]
     </a>
    </sup>
    It changes in shape from a simple swelling at the front of the nerve cord in the earliest embryonic stages, to a complex array of areas and connections. Neurons are created in special zones that contain
    <a href="/wiki/Stem_cell" title="Stem cell">
     stem cells
    </a>
    , and then migrate through the tissue to reach their ultimate locations. Once neurons have positioned themselves, their axons sprout and navigate through the brain, branching and extending as they go, until the tips reach their targets and form synaptic connections. In a number of parts of the nervous system, neurons and synapses are produced in excessive numbers during the early stages, and then the unneeded ones are pruned away.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Purves_1985_59-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-Purves_1985-59">
      [59]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    For vertebrates, the early stages of neural development are similar across all species.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Purves_1985_59-2">
     <a href="#cite_note-Purves_1985-59">
      [59]
     </a>
    </sup>
    As the embryo transforms from a round blob of cells into a wormlike structure, a narrow strip of
    <a href="/wiki/Ectoderm" title="Ectoderm">
     ectoderm
    </a>
    running along the midline of the back is
    <a href="/wiki/Cellular_differentiation" title="Cellular differentiation">
     induced
    </a>
    to become the
    <a href="/wiki/Neural_plate" title="Neural plate">
     neural plate
    </a>
    , the precursor of the nervous system. The neural plate folds inward to form the
    <a href="/wiki/Neural_groove" title="Neural groove">
     neural groove
    </a>
    , and then the lips that line the groove merge to enclose the
    <a href="/wiki/Neural_tube" title="Neural tube">
     neural tube
    </a>
    , a hollow cord of cells with a fluid-filled ventricle at the center. At the front end, the ventricles and cord swell to form three vesicles that are the precursors of the
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prosencephalon" title="Prosencephalon">
     forebrain
    </a>
    ,
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mesencephalon" title="Mesencephalon">
     midbrain
    </a>
    , and
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rhombencephalon" title="Rhombencephalon">
     hindbrain
    </a>
    . At the next stage, the forebrain splits into two vesicles called the
    <a href="/wiki/Cerebrum" title="Cerebrum">
     telencephalon
    </a>
    (which will contain the cerebral cortex, basal ganglia, and related structures) and the
    <a href="/wiki/Diencephalon" title="Diencephalon">
     diencephalon
    </a>
    (which will contain the thalamus and hypothalamus). At about the same time, the hindbrain splits into the
    <a href="/wiki/Metencephalon" title="Metencephalon">
     metencephalon
    </a>
    (which will contain the cerebellum and pons) and the
    <a href="/wiki/Myelencephalon" title="Myelencephalon">
     myelencephalon
    </a>
    (which will contain the
    <a href="/wiki/Medulla_oblongata" title="Medulla oblongata">
     medulla oblongata
    </a>
    ). Each of these areas contains proliferative zones where neurons and glial cells are generated; the resulting cells then migrate, sometimes for long distances, to their final positions.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Purves_1985_59-3">
     <a href="#cite_note-Purves_1985-59">
      [59]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Once a neuron is in place, it extends dendrites and an axon into the area around it. Axons, because they commonly extend a great distance from the cell body and need to reach specific targets, grow in a particularly complex way. The tip of a growing axon consists of a blob of protoplasm called a
    <a href="/wiki/Growth_cone" title="Growth cone">
     growth cone
    </a>
    , studded with chemical receptors. These receptors sense the local environment, causing the growth cone to be attracted or repelled by various cellular elements, and thus to be pulled in a particular direction at each point along its path. The result of this pathfinding process is that the growth cone navigates through the brain until it reaches its destination area, where other chemical cues cause it to begin generating synapses. Considering the entire brain, thousands of
    <a href="/wiki/Gene" title="Gene">
     genes
    </a>
    create products that influence axonal pathfinding.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Purves_1985_59-4">
     <a href="#cite_note-Purves_1985-59">
      [59]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    The synaptic network that finally emerges is only partly determined by genes, though. In many parts of the brain, axons initially "overgrow", and then are "pruned" by mechanisms that depend on neural activity.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Purves_1985_59-5">
     <a href="#cite_note-Purves_1985-59">
      [59]
     </a>
    </sup>
    In the projection from the eye to the midbrain, for example, the structure in the adult contains a very precise mapping, connecting each point on the surface of the
    <a href="/wiki/Retina" title="Retina">
     retina
    </a>
    to a corresponding point in a midbrain layer. In the first stages of development, each axon from the retina is guided to the right general vicinity in the midbrain by chemical cues, but then branches very profusely and makes initial contact with a wide swath of midbrain neurons. The retina, before birth, contains special mechanisms that cause it to generate waves of activity that originate spontaneously at a random point and then propagate slowly across the retinal layer. These waves are useful because they cause neighboring neurons to be active at the same time; that is, they produce a neural activity pattern that contains information about the spatial arrangement of the neurons. This information is exploited in the midbrain by a mechanism that causes synapses to weaken, and eventually vanish, if activity in an axon is not followed by activity of the target cell. The result of this sophisticated process is a gradual tuning and tightening of the map, leaving it finally in its precise adult form.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wong_60-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Wong-60">
      [60]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Similar things happen in other brain areas: an initial synaptic matrix is generated as a result of genetically determined chemical guidance, but then gradually refined by activity-dependent mechanisms, partly driven by internal dynamics, partly by external sensory inputs. In some cases, as with the retina-midbrain system, activity patterns depend on mechanisms that operate only in the developing brain, and apparently exist solely to guide development.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wong_60-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-Wong-60">
      [60]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    In humans and many other mammals, new neurons are created mainly before birth, and the infant brain contains substantially more neurons than the adult brain.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Purves_1985_59-6">
     <a href="#cite_note-Purves_1985-59">
      [59]
     </a>
    </sup>
    There are, however, a few areas where new neurons continue to be generated throughout life. The two areas for which adult
    <a href="/wiki/Neurogenesis" title="Neurogenesis">
     neurogenesis
    </a>
    is well established are the olfactory bulb, which is involved in the sense of smell, and the
    <a href="/wiki/Dentate_gyrus" title="Dentate gyrus">
     dentate gyrus
    </a>
    of the hippocampus, where there is evidence that the new neurons play a role in storing newly acquired memories. With these exceptions, however, the set of neurons that is present in early childhood is the set that is present for life. Glial cells are different: as with most types of cells in the body, they are generated throughout the lifespan.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61">
     <a href="#cite_note-61">
      [61]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    There has long been debate about whether the qualities of
    <a href="/wiki/Mind" title="Mind">
     mind
    </a>
    , personality, and intelligence can be attributed to heredity or to upbringing—this is the
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nature_and_nurture" title="Nature and nurture">
     nature and nurture
    </a>
    controversy.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
     <a href="#cite_note-62">
      [62]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Although many details remain to be settled, neuroscience research has clearly shown that both factors are important. Genes determine the general form of the brain, and genes determine how the brain reacts to experience. Experience, however, is required to refine the matrix of synaptic connections, which in its developed form contains far more information than the genome does. In some respects, all that matters is the presence or absence of experience during critical periods of development.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63">
     <a href="#cite_note-63">
      [63]
     </a>
    </sup>
    In other respects, the quantity and quality of experience are important; for example, there is substantial evidence that animals raised in
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Environmental_enrichment_(neural)" title="Environmental enrichment (neural)">
     enriched environments
    </a>
    have thicker cerebral cortices, indicating a higher density of synaptic connections, than animals whose levels of stimulation are restricted.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64">
     <a href="#cite_note-64">
      [64]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h2>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Physiology">
     Physiology
    </span>
   </h2>
   <p>
    The functions of the brain depend on the ability of neurons to transmit electrochemical signals to other cells, and their ability to respond appropriately to electrochemical signals received from other cells. The
    <a href="/wiki/Membrane_potential" title="Membrane potential">
     electrical properties
    </a>
    of neurons are controlled by a wide variety of biochemical and metabolic processes, most notably the interactions between neurotransmitters and receptors that take place at synapses.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kandel_2000_7-10">
     <a href="#cite_note-Kandel_2000-7">
      [7]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Neurotransmitters_and_receptors">
     Neurotransmitters and receptors
    </span>
   </h3>
   <p>
    <a href="/wiki/Neurotransmitter" title="Neurotransmitter">
     Neurotransmitters
    </a>
    are chemicals that are released at synapses when an action potential activates them—neurotransmitters attach themselves to receptor molecules on the membrane of the synapse's target cell, and thereby alter the electrical or chemical properties of the receptor molecules. With few exceptions, each neuron in the brain releases the same chemical neurotransmitter, or combination of neurotransmitters, at all the synaptic connections it makes with other neurons; this rule is known as
    <a href="/wiki/Dale%27s_principle" title="Dale's principle">
     Dale's principle
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kandel_2000_7-11">
     <a href="#cite_note-Kandel_2000-7">
      [7]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Thus, a neuron can be characterized by the neurotransmitters that it releases. The great majority of
    <a href="/wiki/Psychoactive_drug" title="Psychoactive drug">
     psychoactive drugs
    </a>
    exert their effects by altering specific neurotransmitter systems. This applies to drugs such as
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cannabinoids" title="Cannabinoids">
     cannabinoids
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Nicotine" title="Nicotine">
     nicotine
    </a>
    , heroin,
    <a href="/wiki/Cocaine" title="Cocaine">
     cocaine
    </a>
    , alcohol,
    <a href="/wiki/Fluoxetine" title="Fluoxetine">
     fluoxetine
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Chlorpromazine" title="Chlorpromazine">
     chlorpromazine
    </a>
    , and many others.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65">
     <a href="#cite_note-65">
      [65]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    The two neurotransmitters that are used most widely in the vertebrate brain are
    <a href="/wiki/Glutamic_acid" title="Glutamic acid">
     glutamate
    </a>
    , which almost always exerts excitatory effects on target neurons, and
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gamma-aminobutyric_acid" title="Gamma-aminobutyric acid">
     gamma-aminobutyric acid
    </a>
    (GABA), which is almost always inhibitory. Neurons using these transmitters can be found in nearly every part of the brain.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66">
     <a href="#cite_note-66">
      [66]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Because of their ubiquity, drugs that act on glutamate or GABA tend to have broad and powerful effects. Some general anesthetics act by reducing the effects of glutamate; most tranquilizers exert their sedative effects by enhancing the effects of GABA.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67">
     <a href="#cite_note-67">
      [67]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    There are dozens of other chemical neurotransmitters that are used in more limited areas of the brain, often areas dedicated to a particular function.
    <a href="/wiki/Serotonin" title="Serotonin">
     Serotonin
    </a>
    , for example—the primary target of antidepressant drugs and many dietary aids—comes exclusively from a small brainstem area called the
    <a href="/wiki/Raphe_nuclei" title="Raphe nuclei">
     raphe nuclei
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68">
     <a href="#cite_note-68">
      [68]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <a href="/wiki/Norepinephrine" title="Norepinephrine">
     Norepinephrine
    </a>
    , which is involved in arousal, comes exclusively from a nearby small area called the
    <a href="/wiki/Locus_coeruleus" title="Locus coeruleus">
     locus coeruleus
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mehler_69-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Mehler-69">
      [69]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Other neurotransmitters such as
    <a href="/wiki/Acetylcholine" title="Acetylcholine">
     acetylcholine
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Dopamine" title="Dopamine">
     dopamine
    </a>
    have multiple sources in the brain, but are not as ubiquitously distributed as glutamate and GABA.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70">
     <a href="#cite_note-70">
      [70]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Electrical_activity">
     Electrical activity
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="thumb tright">
    <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
     <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Spike-waves.png">
      <img alt="Graph showing 16 voltage traces going across the page from left to right, each showing a different signal. At the middle of the page all of the traces abruptly begin to show sharp jerky spikes, which continue to the end of the plot." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="478" height="230" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Spike-waves.png/220px-Spike-waves.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Spike-waves.png/330px-Spike-waves.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Spike-waves.png/440px-Spike-waves.png 2x" width="220"/>
     </a>
     <div class="thumbcaption">
      <div class="magnify">
       <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Spike-waves.png" title="Enlarge">
       </a>
      </div>
      Brain electrical activity recorded from a human patient during an
      <a href="/wiki/Epilepsy" title="Epilepsy">
       epileptic seizure
      </a>
     </div>
    </div>
   </div>
   <p>
    As a side effect of the electrochemical processes used by neurons for signaling, brain tissue generates electric fields when it is active. When large numbers of neurons show synchronized activity, the electric fields that they generate can be large enough to detect outside the skull, using
    <a href="/wiki/Electroencephalography" title="Electroencephalography">
     electroencephalography
    </a>
    (EEG)
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Niedermeyer_71-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Niedermeyer-71">
      [71]
     </a>
    </sup>
    or
    <a href="/wiki/Magnetoencephalography" title="Magnetoencephalography">
     magnetoencephalography
    </a>
    (MEG). EEG recordings, along with recordings made from electrodes implanted inside the brains of animals such as rats, show that the brain of a living animal is constantly active, even during sleep.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Buzsaki_72-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Buzsaki-72">
      [72]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Each part of the brain shows a mixture of rhythmic and nonrhythmic activity, which may vary according to behavioral state. In mammals, the cerebral cortex tends to show large slow
    <a href="/wiki/Delta_wave" title="Delta wave">
     delta waves
    </a>
    during sleep, faster
    <a href="/wiki/Alpha_wave" title="Alpha wave">
     alpha waves
    </a>
    when the animal is awake but inattentive, and chaotic-looking irregular activity when the animal is actively engaged in a task. During an
    <a href="/wiki/Epilepsy" title="Epilepsy">
     epileptic seizure
    </a>
    , the brain's inhibitory control mechanisms fail to function and electrical activity rises to pathological levels, producing EEG traces that show large wave and spike patterns not seen in a healthy brain. Relating these population-level patterns to the computational functions of individual neurons is a major focus of current research in
    <a href="/wiki/Neurophysiology" title="Neurophysiology">
     neurophysiology
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Buzsaki_72-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-Buzsaki-72">
      [72]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Metabolism">
     Metabolism
    </span>
   </h3>
   <p>
    All vertebrates have a blood–brain barrier that allows metabolism inside the brain to operate differently from metabolism in other parts of the body.
    <a href="/wiki/Neuroglia" title="Neuroglia">
     Glial cells
    </a>
    play a major role in brain metabolism by controlling the chemical composition of the fluid that surrounds neurons, including levels of ions and nutrients.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nieuwenhuys_73-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Nieuwenhuys-73">
      [73]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Brain tissue consumes a large amount of energy in proportion to its volume, so large brains place severe metabolic demands on animals. The need to limit body weight in order, for example, to fly, has apparently led to selection for a reduction of brain size in some species, such as bats.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
     <a href="#cite_note-74">
      [74]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Most of the brain's energy consumption goes into sustaining the electric charge (
    <a href="/wiki/Membrane_potential" title="Membrane potential">
     membrane potential
    </a>
    ) of neurons.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nieuwenhuys_73-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-Nieuwenhuys-73">
      [73]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Most vertebrate species devote between 2% and 8% of basal metabolism to the brain. In primates, however, the percentage is much higher—in humans it rises to 20–25%.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75">
     <a href="#cite_note-75">
      [75]
     </a>
    </sup>
    The energy consumption of the brain does not vary greatly over time, but active regions of the cerebral cortex consume somewhat more energy than inactive regions; this forms the basis for the functional brain imaging methods
    <a href="/wiki/Positron_emission_tomography" title="Positron emission tomography">
     PET
    </a>
    ,
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FMRI" title="FMRI">
     fMRI
    </a>
    ,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76">
     <a href="#cite_note-76">
      [76]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Near_infrared_spectroscopy" title="Near infrared spectroscopy">
     NIRS
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77">
     <a href="#cite_note-77">
      [77]
     </a>
    </sup>
    The brain typically gets most of its energy from oxygen-dependent metabolism of
    <a href="/wiki/Glucose" title="Glucose">
     glucose
    </a>
    (i.e., blood sugar),
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nieuwenhuys_73-2">
     <a href="#cite_note-Nieuwenhuys-73">
      [73]
     </a>
    </sup>
    but
    <a href="/wiki/Ketone_bodies" title="Ketone bodies">
     ketones
    </a>
    provide a major alternative source, together with contributions from medium chain
    <a href="/wiki/Fatty_acid" title="Fatty acid">
     fatty acids
    </a>
    (
    <a href="/wiki/Caprylic_acid" title="Caprylic acid">
     caprylic
    </a>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ebert_2003_78-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Ebert_2003-78">
      [78]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Heptanoic_acid" title="Heptanoic acid">
     heptanoic
    </a>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Marin_Valencia_2013_79-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Marin_Valencia_2013-79">
      [79]
     </a>
    </sup>
    acids),
    <a href="/wiki/Lactic_acid" title="Lactic acid">
     lactate
    </a>
    ,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boumezbeur_2010_80-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Boumezbeur_2010-80">
      [80]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <a href="/wiki/Acetate" title="Acetate">
     acetate
    </a>
    ,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Deelchand_2009_81-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Deelchand_2009-81">
      [81]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and possibly
    <a href="/wiki/Amino_acid" title="Amino acid">
     amino acids
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82">
     <a href="#cite_note-82">
      [82]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h2>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Functions">
     Functions
    </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="thumb tright">
    <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
     <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Model_of_Cerebellar_Perceptron.jpg">
      <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="379" data-file-width="464" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Model_of_Cerebellar_Perceptron.jpg/220px-Model_of_Cerebellar_Perceptron.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Model_of_Cerebellar_Perceptron.jpg/330px-Model_of_Cerebellar_Perceptron.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Model_of_Cerebellar_Perceptron.jpg/440px-Model_of_Cerebellar_Perceptron.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
     </a>
     <div class="thumbcaption">
      <div class="magnify">
       <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Model_of_Cerebellar_Perceptron.jpg" title="Enlarge">
       </a>
      </div>
      Model of a neural circuit in the cerebellum, as proposed by
      <a href="/wiki/James_S._Albus" title="James S. Albus">
       James S. Albus
      </a>
     </div>
    </div>
   </div>
   <p>
    Information from the sense organs is collected in the brain. There it is used to determine what actions the organism is to take. The brain
    <a href="/wiki/Multisensory_integration" title="Multisensory integration">
     processes
    </a>
    the raw data to extract information about the structure of the environment. Next it combines the processed information with information about the current needs of the animal and with memory of past circumstances. Finally, on the basis of the results, it generates motor response patterns. These signal-processing tasks require intricate interplay between a variety of functional subsystems.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CarewCh1_83-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-CarewCh1-83">
      [83]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    The function of the brain is to provide coherent control over the actions of an animal. A centralized brain allows groups of muscles to be co-activated in complex patterns; it also allows stimuli impinging on one part of the body to evoke responses in other parts, and it can prevent different parts of the body from acting at cross-purposes to each other.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CarewCh1_83-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-CarewCh1-83">
      [83]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Perception">
     Perception
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="thumb tright">
    <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
     <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hearing_mechanics_cropped.jpg">
      <img alt="Drawing showing the ear, inner ear, and brain areas involved in hearing. A series of light blue arrows shows the flow of signals through the system." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="489" data-file-width="574" height="187" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Hearing_mechanics_cropped.jpg/220px-Hearing_mechanics_cropped.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Hearing_mechanics_cropped.jpg/330px-Hearing_mechanics_cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Hearing_mechanics_cropped.jpg/440px-Hearing_mechanics_cropped.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
     </a>
     <div class="thumbcaption">
      <div class="magnify">
       <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hearing_mechanics_cropped.jpg" title="Enlarge">
       </a>
      </div>
      Diagram of signal processing in the
      <a href="/wiki/Auditory_system" title="Auditory system">
       auditory system
      </a>
     </div>
    </div>
   </div>
   <p>
    The human brain is provided with information about light, sound, the chemical composition of the atmosphere, temperature, head orientation, limb position, the chemical composition of the bloodstream, and more. In other animals additional senses are present, such as the infrared heat-sense of snakes, the
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Magnetoception" title="Magnetoception">
     magnetic field sense
    </a>
    of some birds, or the electric field sense of some types of fish.
   </p>
   <p>
    Each sensory system begins with specialized receptor cells,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kandel_2000_7-12">
     <a href="#cite_note-Kandel_2000-7">
      [7]
     </a>
    </sup>
    such as light-receptive neurons in the
    <a href="/wiki/Retina" title="Retina">
     retina
    </a>
    of the eye, or vibration-sensitive neurons in the
    <a href="/wiki/Cochlea" title="Cochlea">
     cochlea
    </a>
    of the ear. The axons of sensory receptor cells travel into the spinal cord or brain, where they transmit their signals to a
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sensory_system" title="Sensory system">
     first-order sensory nucleus
    </a>
    dedicated to one specific
    <a href="/wiki/Stimulus_modality" title="Stimulus modality">
     sensory modality
    </a>
    . This primary sensory nucleus sends information to higher-order sensory areas that are dedicated to the same modality. Eventually, via a way-station in the
    <a href="/wiki/Thalamus" title="Thalamus">
     thalamus
    </a>
    , the signals are sent to the cerebral cortex, where they are processed to extract the relevant features, and
    <a href="/wiki/Multisensory_integration" title="Multisensory integration">
     integrated
    </a>
    with signals coming from other sensory systems.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kandel_2000_7-13">
     <a href="#cite_note-Kandel_2000-7">
      [7]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Motor_control">
     Motor control
    </span>
   </h3>
   <p>
    <a href="/wiki/Motor_system" title="Motor system">
     Motor systems
    </a>
    are areas of the brain that are involved in
    <a href="/wiki/Motor_control" title="Motor control">
     initiating body movements
    </a>
    , that is, in activating muscles. Except for the muscles that control the eye, which are driven by nuclei in the midbrain, all the voluntary muscles in the body are directly innervated by
    <a href="/wiki/Motor_neuron" title="Motor neuron">
     motor neurons
    </a>
    in the spinal cord and hindbrain.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kandel_2000_7-14">
     <a href="#cite_note-Kandel_2000-7">
      [7]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Spinal motor neurons are controlled both by neural circuits intrinsic to the spinal cord, and by inputs that descend from the brain. The intrinsic spinal circuits implement many
    <a href="/wiki/Reflex" title="Reflex">
     reflex
    </a>
    responses, and contain
    <a href="/wiki/Central_pattern_generator" title="Central pattern generator">
     pattern generators
    </a>
    for rhythmic movements such as walking or swimming. The descending connections from the brain allow for more sophisticated control.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kandel_2000_7-15">
     <a href="#cite_note-Kandel_2000-7">
      [7]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    The brain contains several motor areas that project directly to the spinal cord. At the lowest level are motor areas in the medulla and pons, which control stereotyped movements such as walking, breathing, or swallowing. At a higher level are areas in the midbrain, such as the
    <a href="/wiki/Red_nucleus" title="Red nucleus">
     red nucleus
    </a>
    , which is responsible for coordinating movements of the arms and legs. At a higher level yet is the
    <a href="/wiki/Primary_motor_cortex" title="Primary motor cortex">
     primary motor cortex
    </a>
    , a strip of tissue located at the posterior edge of the frontal lobe. The primary motor cortex sends projections to the subcortical motor areas, but also sends a massive projection directly to the spinal cord, through the
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pyramidal_tract" title="Pyramidal tract">
     pyramidal tract
    </a>
    . This direct corticospinal projection allows for precise voluntary control of the fine details of movements. Other motor-related brain areas exert secondary effects by projecting to the primary motor areas. Among the most important secondary areas are the premotor cortex, basal ganglia, and cerebellum.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kandel_2000_7-16">
     <a href="#cite_note-Kandel_2000-7">
      [7]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <table class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto;">
    <caption>
     Major areas involved in controlling movement
    </caption>
    <tr>
     <th>
      Area
     </th>
     <th width="100">
      Location
     </th>
     <th>
      Function
     </th>
    </tr>
    <tr>
     <th scope="row" style="text-align:left">
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anterior_horn_of_spinal_cord" title="Anterior horn of spinal cord">
       Ventral horn
      </a>
     </th>
     <td style="background: tan">
      Spinal cord
     </td>
     <td style="background:#ffdead">
      Contains motor neurons that directly activate muscles
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84">
       <a href="#cite_note-84">
        [84]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
     <th scope="row" style="text-align:left">
      <a href="/wiki/Oculomotor_nucleus" title="Oculomotor nucleus">
       Oculomotor nuclei
      </a>
     </th>
     <td style="background: tan">
      Midbrain
     </td>
     <td style="background:#ffdead">
      Contains motor neurons that directly activate the eye muscles
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85">
       <a href="#cite_note-85">
        [85]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
     <th scope="row" style="text-align:left">
      <a href="/wiki/Cerebellum" title="Cerebellum">
       Cerebellum
      </a>
     </th>
     <td style="background: tan">
      Hindbrain
     </td>
     <td style="background:#ffdead">
      Calibrates precision and timing of movements
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kandel_2000_7-17">
       <a href="#cite_note-Kandel_2000-7">
        [7]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
     <th scope="row" style="text-align:left">
      <a href="/wiki/Basal_ganglia" title="Basal ganglia">
       Basal ganglia
      </a>
     </th>
     <td style="background: tan">
      Forebrain
     </td>
     <td style="background:#ffdead">
      Action selection on the basis of motivation
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86">
       <a href="#cite_note-86">
        [86]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
     <th scope="row" style="text-align:left">
      <a href="/wiki/Motor_cortex" title="Motor cortex">
       Motor cortex
      </a>
     </th>
     <td style="background: tan">
      Frontal lobe
     </td>
     <td style="background:#ffdead">
      Direct cortical activation of spinal motor circuits
     </td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
     <th scope="row" style="text-align:left">
      <a href="/wiki/Premotor_cortex" title="Premotor cortex">
       Premotor cortex
      </a>
     </th>
     <td style="background: tan">
      Frontal lobe
     </td>
     <td style="background:#ffdead">
      Groups elementary movements into coordinated patterns
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kandel_2000_7-18">
       <a href="#cite_note-Kandel_2000-7">
        [7]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
     <th scope="row" style="text-align:left">
      <a href="/wiki/Supplementary_motor_area" title="Supplementary motor area">
       Supplementary motor area
      </a>
     </th>
     <td style="background: tan">
      Frontal lobe
     </td>
     <td style="background:#ffdead">
      Sequences movements into temporal patterns
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87">
       <a href="#cite_note-87">
        [87]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
     <th scope="row" style="text-align:left">
      <a href="/wiki/Prefrontal_cortex" title="Prefrontal cortex">
       Prefrontal cortex
      </a>
     </th>
     <td style="background: tan">
      Frontal lobe
     </td>
     <td style="background:#ffdead">
      Planning and other
      <a href="/wiki/Executive_functions" title="Executive functions">
       executive functions
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88">
       <a href="#cite_note-88">
        [88]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </td>
    </tr>
   </table>
   <p>
    In addition to all of the above, the brain and spinal cord contain extensive circuitry to control the
    <a href="/wiki/Autonomic_nervous_system" title="Autonomic nervous system">
     autonomic nervous system
    </a>
    , which works by secreting hormones and by modulating the "smooth" muscles of the gut.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kandel_2000_7-19">
     <a href="#cite_note-Kandel_2000-7">
      [7]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Arousal">
     Arousal
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    See also:
    <a href="/wiki/Sleep" title="Sleep">
     Sleep
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    Many animals alternate between sleeping and waking in a daily cycle. Arousal and alertness are also modulated on a finer time scale by a network of brain areas.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kandel_2000_7-20">
     <a href="#cite_note-Kandel_2000-7">
      [7]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    A key component of the arousal system is the
    <a href="/wiki/Suprachiasmatic_nucleus" title="Suprachiasmatic nucleus">
     suprachiasmatic nucleus
    </a>
    (SCN), a tiny part of the hypothalamus located directly above the point at which the
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Optic_nerves" title="Optic nerves">
     optic nerves
    </a>
    from the two eyes cross. The SCN contains the body's central biological clock. Neurons there show activity levels that rise and fall with a period of about 24 hours,
    <a href="/wiki/Circadian_rhythm" title="Circadian rhythm">
     circadian rhythms
    </a>
    : these activity fluctuations are driven by rhythmic changes in expression of a set of "clock genes". The SCN continues to keep time even if it is excised from the brain and placed in a dish of warm nutrient solution, but it ordinarily receives input from the optic nerves, through the
    <a href="/wiki/Retinohypothalamic_tract" title="Retinohypothalamic tract">
     retinohypothalamic tract
    </a>
    (RHT), that allows daily light-dark cycles to calibrate the clock.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89">
     <a href="#cite_note-89">
      [89]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    The SCN projects to a set of areas in the hypothalamus, brainstem, and midbrain that are involved in implementing sleep-wake cycles. An important component of the system is the
    <a href="/wiki/Reticular_formation" title="Reticular formation">
     reticular formation
    </a>
    , a group of neuron-clusters scattered diffusely through the core of the lower brain. Reticular neurons send signals to the thalamus, which in turn sends activity-level-controlling signals to every part of the cortex. Damage to the reticular formation can produce a permanent state of coma.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kandel_2000_7-21">
     <a href="#cite_note-Kandel_2000-7">
      [7]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Sleep involves great changes in brain activity.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kandel_2000_7-22">
     <a href="#cite_note-Kandel_2000-7">
      [7]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Until the 1950s it was generally believed that the brain essentially shuts off during sleep,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90">
     <a href="#cite_note-90">
      [90]
     </a>
    </sup>
    but this is now known to be far from true; activity continues, but patterns become very different. There are two types of sleep:
    <i>
     <a href="/wiki/Rapid_eye_movement_sleep" title="Rapid eye movement sleep">
      REM sleep
     </a>
    </i>
    (with dreaming) and
    <i>
     <a href="/wiki/Non-rapid_eye_movement_sleep" title="Non-rapid eye movement sleep">
      NREM
     </a>
    </i>
    (non-REM, usually without dreaming) sleep, which repeat in slightly varying patterns throughout a sleep episode. Three broad types of distinct brain activity patterns can be measured: REM, light NREM and deep NREM. During deep NREM sleep, also called
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slow_wave_sleep" title="Slow wave sleep">
     slow wave sleep
    </a>
    , activity in the cortex takes the form of large synchronized waves, whereas in the waking state it is noisy and desynchronized. Levels of the neurotransmitters
    <a href="/wiki/Norepinephrine" title="Norepinephrine">
     norepinephrine
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Serotonin" title="Serotonin">
     serotonin
    </a>
    drop during slow wave sleep, and fall almost to zero during REM sleep; levels of acetylcholine show the reverse pattern.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kandel_2000_7-23">
     <a href="#cite_note-Kandel_2000-7">
      [7]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Homeostasis">
     Homeostasis
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="thumb tright">
    <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
     <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:LocationOfHypothalamus.jpg">
      <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="250" data-file-width="350" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/LocationOfHypothalamus.jpg/220px-LocationOfHypothalamus.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/LocationOfHypothalamus.jpg/330px-LocationOfHypothalamus.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/9f/LocationOfHypothalamus.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
     </a>
     <div class="thumbcaption">
      <div class="magnify">
       <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:LocationOfHypothalamus.jpg" title="Enlarge">
       </a>
      </div>
      Cross-section of a human head, showing location of the
      <a href="/wiki/Hypothalamus" title="Hypothalamus">
       hypothalamus
      </a>
     </div>
    </div>
   </div>
   <p>
    For any animal, survival requires maintaining a variety of parameters of bodily state within a limited range of variation: these include temperature, water content, salt concentration in the bloodstream, blood glucose levels, blood oxygen level, and others.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dougherty_91-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Dougherty-91">
      [91]
     </a>
    </sup>
    The ability of an animal to regulate the internal environment of its body—the
    <a href="/wiki/Milieu_int%C3%A9rieur" title="Milieu intérieur">
     milieu intérieur
    </a>
    , as pioneering physiologist
    <a href="/wiki/Claude_Bernard" title="Claude Bernard">
     Claude Bernard
    </a>
    called it—is known as
    <a href="/wiki/Homeostasis" title="Homeostasis">
     homeostasis
    </a>
    (
    <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek" title="Ancient Greek">
     Greek
    </a>
    for "standing still").
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92">
     <a href="#cite_note-92">
      [92]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Maintaining homeostasis is a crucial function of the brain. The basic principle that underlies homeostasis is
    <a href="/wiki/Negative_feedback" title="Negative feedback">
     negative feedback
    </a>
    : any time a parameter diverges from its set-point, sensors generate an error signal that evokes a response that causes the parameter to shift back toward its optimum value.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dougherty_91-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-Dougherty-91">
      [91]
     </a>
    </sup>
    (This principle is widely used in engineering, for example in the control of temperature using a
    <a href="/wiki/Thermostat" title="Thermostat">
     thermostat
    </a>
    .)
   </p>
   <p>
    In vertebrates, the part of the brain that plays the greatest role is the
    <a href="/wiki/Hypothalamus" title="Hypothalamus">
     hypothalamus
    </a>
    , a small region at the base of the forebrain whose size does not reflect its complexity or the importance of its function.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dougherty_91-2">
     <a href="#cite_note-Dougherty-91">
      [91]
     </a>
    </sup>
    The hypothalamus is a collection of small nuclei, most of which are involved in basic biological functions. Some of these functions relate to arousal or to social interactions such as sexuality, aggression, or maternal behaviors; but many of them relate to homeostasis. Several hypothalamic nuclei receive input from sensors located in the lining of blood vessels, conveying information about temperature, sodium level, glucose level, blood oxygen level, and other parameters. These hypothalamic nuclei send output signals to motor areas that can generate actions to rectify deficiencies. Some of the outputs also go to the
    <a href="/wiki/Pituitary_gland" title="Pituitary gland">
     pituitary gland
    </a>
