    ": the amount of memory or computer time required becomes astronomical for problems of a certain size. The search for more efficient problem-solving algorithms is a high priority.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Intractability_50-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Intractability-50">
      [50]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Human beings ordinarily use fast, intuitive judgments rather than step-by-step deduction that early AI research was able to model.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Psychological_evidence_of_sub-symbolic_reasoning_51-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Psychological_evidence_of_sub-symbolic_reasoning-51">
      [51]
     </a>
    </sup>
    AI has progressed using "sub-symbolic" problem solving:
    <a href="/wiki/Embodied_agent" title="Embodied agent">
     embodied agent
    </a>
    approaches emphasize the importance of
    <a href="/wiki/Sensory-motor_coupling" title="Sensory-motor coupling">
     sensorimotor
    </a>
    skills to higher reasoning;
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neural_net" title="Neural net">
     neural net
    </a>
    research attempts to simulate the structures inside the brain that give rise to this skill;
    <a href="#Statistical">
     statistical approaches to AI
    </a>
    mimic the human ability to guess.
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Knowledge_representation">
     Knowledge representation
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Knowledge representation">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="thumb tright">
    <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
     <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GFO_taxonomy_tree.png">
      <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="443" data-file-width="469" height="208" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/GFO_taxonomy_tree.png/220px-GFO_taxonomy_tree.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/GFO_taxonomy_tree.png/330px-GFO_taxonomy_tree.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/GFO_taxonomy_tree.png/440px-GFO_taxonomy_tree.png 2x" width="220"/>
     </a>
     <div class="thumbcaption">
      <div class="magnify">
       <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GFO_taxonomy_tree.png" title="Enlarge">
       </a>
      </div>
      An ontology represents knowledge as a set of concepts within a domain and the relationships between those concepts.
     </div>
    </div>
   </div>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main articles:
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Knowledge_representation" title="Knowledge representation">
     Knowledge representation
    </a>
    and
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Commonsense_knowledge" title="Commonsense knowledge">
     Commonsense knowledge
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Knowledge_representation" title="Knowledge representation">
     Knowledge representation
    </a>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Knowledge_representation_52-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Knowledge_representation-52">
      [52]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Knowledge_engineering" title="Knowledge engineering">
     knowledge engineering
    </a>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Knowledge_engineering_53-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Knowledge_engineering-53">
      [53]
     </a>
    </sup>
    are central to AI research. Many of the problems machines are expected to solve will require extensive knowledge about the world. Among the things that AI needs to represent are: objects, properties, categories and relations between objects;
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Representing_categories_and_relations_54-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Representing_categories_and_relations-54">
      [54]
     </a>
    </sup>
    situations, events, states and time;
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Representing_time_55-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Representing_time-55">
      [55]
     </a>
    </sup>
    causes and effects;
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Representing_causation_56-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Representing_causation-56">
      [56]
     </a>
    </sup>
    knowledge about knowledge (what we know about what other people know);
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Representing_knowledge_about_knowledge_57-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Representing_knowledge_about_knowledge-57">
      [57]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and many other, less well researched domains. A representation of "what exists" is an
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ontology_(computer_science)" title="Ontology (computer science)">
     ontology
    </a>
    : the set of objects, relations, concepts, and properties formally described so that software agents can interpret them. The
    <a href="/wiki/Semantics" title="Semantics">
     semantics
    </a>
    of these are captured as
    <a href="/wiki/Description_logic" title="Description logic">
     description logic
    </a>
    concepts, roles, and individuals, and typically implemented as classes, properties, and individuals in the
    <a href="/wiki/Web_Ontology_Language" title="Web Ontology Language">
     Web Ontology Language
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58">
     <a href="#cite_note-58">
      [58]
     </a>
    </sup>
    The most general ontologies are called
    <a href="/wiki/Upper_ontology" title="Upper ontology">
     upper ontologies
    </a>
    , which attempt to provide a foundation for all other knowledge
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ontology_59-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Ontology-59">
      [59]
     </a>
    </sup>
    by acting as mediators between
    <a href="/wiki/Ontology_(information_science)#Domain_ontology" title="Ontology (information science)">
     domain ontologies
    </a>
    that cover specific knowledge about a particular knowledge domain (field of interest or area of concern). Such formal knowledge representations are suitable for content-based indexing and retrieval, scene interpretation, clinical decision support, knowledge discovery via automated reasoning (inferring new statements based on explicitly stated knowledge), etc. Video events are often represented as
    <a href="/wiki/Semantic_Web_Rule_Language" title="Semantic Web Rule Language">
     SWRL
    </a>
    rules, which can be used, among others, to automatically generate subtitles for constrained videos.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60">
     <a href="#cite_note-60">
      [60]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Among the most difficult problems in knowledge representation are:
   </p>
   <dl>
    <dt>
     <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Default_reasoning" title="Default reasoning">
      Default reasoning
     </a>
     and the
     <a href="/wiki/Qualification_problem" title="Qualification problem">
      qualification problem
     </a>
    </dt>
    <dd>
     Many of the things people know take the form of "working assumptions". For example, if a bird comes up in conversation, people typically picture an animal that is fist sized, sings, and flies. None of these things are true about all birds.
     <a href="/wiki/John_McCarthy_(computer_scientist)" title="John McCarthy (computer scientist)">
      John McCarthy
     </a>
     identified this problem in 1969
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Qualification_problem_61-0">
      <a href="#cite_note-Qualification_problem-61">
       [61]
      </a>
     </sup>
     as the qualification problem: for any commonsense rule that AI researchers care to represent, there tend to be a huge number of exceptions. Almost nothing is simply true or false in the way that abstract logic requires. AI research has explored a number of solutions to this problem.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Default_reasoning_and_non-monotonic_logic_62-0">
      <a href="#cite_note-Default_reasoning_and_non-monotonic_logic-62">
       [62]
      </a>
     </sup>
    </dd>
    <dt>
     The breadth of commonsense knowledge
    </dt>
    <dd>
     The number of atomic facts that the average person knows is very large. Research projects that attempt to build a complete knowledge base of
     <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Commonsense_knowledge" title="Commonsense knowledge">
      commonsense knowledge
     </a>
     (e.g.,
     <a href="/wiki/Cyc" title="Cyc">
      Cyc
     </a>
     ) require enormous amounts of laborious
     <a href="/wiki/Ontology_engineering" title="Ontology engineering">
      ontological engineering
     </a>
     —they must be built, by hand, one complicated concept at a time.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Breadth_of_commonsense_knowledge_63-0">
      <a href="#cite_note-Breadth_of_commonsense_knowledge-63">
       [63]
      </a>
     </sup>
     A major goal is to have the computer understand enough concepts to be able to learn by reading from sources like the Internet, and thus be able to add to its own ontology.
     <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
      [
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
        <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2010)">
         citation needed
        </span>
       </a>
      </i>
      ]
     </sup>
    </dd>
    <dt>
     The subsymbolic form of some commonsense knowledge
    </dt>
    <dd>
     Much of what people know is not represented as "facts" or "statements" that they could express verbally. For example, a chess master will avoid a particular chess position because it "feels too exposed"
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDreyfusDreyfus1986_64-0">
      <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDreyfusDreyfus1986-64">
       [64]
      </a>
     </sup>
     or an art critic can take one look at a statue and realize that it is a fake.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGladwell2005_65-0">
      <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGladwell2005-65">
       [65]
      </a>
     </sup>
     These are non-conscious and sub-symbolic intuitions or tendencies in the human brain.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Intuition_66-0">
      <a href="#cite_note-Intuition-66">
       [66]
      </a>
     </sup>
     Knowledge like this informs, supports and provides a context for symbolic, conscious knowledge. As with the related problem of sub-symbolic reasoning, it is hoped that
     <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Situated_artificial_intelligence" title="Situated artificial intelligence">
      situated AI
     </a>
     ,
     <a href="/wiki/Computational_intelligence" title="Computational intelligence">
      computational intelligence
     </a>
     , or
     <a href="#Statistical">
      statistical AI
     </a>
     will provide ways to represent this kind of knowledge.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Intuition_66-1">
      <a href="#cite_note-Intuition-66">
       [66]
      </a>
     </sup>
    </dd>
   </dl>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Planning">
     Planning
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Planning">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="thumb tright">
    <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
     <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hierarchical-control-system.svg">
      <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="539" data-file-width="596" height="199" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/76/Hierarchical-control-system.svg/220px-Hierarchical-control-system.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/76/Hierarchical-control-system.svg/330px-Hierarchical-control-system.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/76/Hierarchical-control-system.svg/440px-Hierarchical-control-system.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
     </a>
     <div class="thumbcaption">
      <div class="magnify">
       <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hierarchical-control-system.svg" title="Enlarge">
       </a>
      </div>
      A
      <a href="/wiki/Hierarchical_control_system" title="Hierarchical control system">
       hierarchical control system
      </a>
      is a form of
      <a href="/wiki/Control_system" title="Control system">
       control system
      </a>
      in which a set of devices and governing software is arranged in a hierarchy.
     </div>
    </div>
   </div>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a href="/wiki/Automated_planning_and_scheduling" title="Automated planning and scheduling">
     Automated planning and scheduling
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    Intelligent agents must be able to set goals and achieve them.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Planning_67-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Planning-67">
      [67]
     </a>
    </sup>
    They need a way to visualize the future—a representation of the state of the world and be able to make predictions about how their actions will change it—and be able to make choices that maximize the
    <a href="/wiki/Utility" title="Utility">
     utility
    </a>
    (or "value") of available choices.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Information_value_theory_68-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Information_value_theory-68">
      [68]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    In classical planning problems, it is usually assumed that the agent is the only system acting in the world, and that its actions have certain (i.e., deterministic) consequences which can be fully observed by the agent.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Classical_planning_69-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Classical_planning-69">
      [69]
     </a>
    </sup>
    However, if the agent is not the only actor in the world, or if the agent is unable to fully perceive the world with certainty, then the agent must be able to reason under uncertainty. This calls for an agent that can not only assess its environment and make predictions, but also evaluate its predictions and adapt based on its assessment.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Non-deterministic_planning_70-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Non-deterministic_planning-70">
      [70]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    <a href="/wiki/Multi-agent_planning" title="Multi-agent planning">
     Multi-agent planning
    </a>
    uses the
    <a href="/wiki/Cooperation" title="Cooperation">
     cooperation
    </a>
    and competition of multiple agents to achieve a given goal.
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Emergent_behavior" title="Emergent behavior">
     Emergent behavior
    </a>
    is used by
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Evolutionary_algorithms" title="Evolutionary algorithms">
     evolutionary algorithms
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Swarm_intelligence" title="Swarm intelligence">
     swarm intelligence
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Multi-agent_planning_71-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Multi-agent_planning-71">
      [71]
     </a>
    </sup>
    An important and widely studied problem in multi-agent systems is how an agent may reason about the unknown beliefs, intentions, and decision making of other agents.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72">
     <a href="#cite_note-72">
      [72]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Learning">
     Learning
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Learning">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a href="/wiki/Machine_learning" title="Machine learning">
     Machine learning
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    Machine learning, a fundamental concept of AI research since the field's inception,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73">
     <a href="#cite_note-73">
      [73]
     </a>
    </sup>
    is the study of computer algorithms that improve automatically through experience.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
     <a href="#cite_note-74">
      [74]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Machine_learning_75-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Machine_learning-75">
      [75]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    <a href="/wiki/Unsupervised_learning" title="Unsupervised learning">
     Unsupervised learning
    </a>
    is the ability to find patterns in a stream of input.
    <a href="/wiki/Supervised_learning" title="Supervised learning">
     Supervised learning
    </a>
    includes both
    <a href="/wiki/Statistical_classification" title="Statistical classification">
     classification
    </a>
    and numerical
    <a href="/wiki/Regression_analysis" title="Regression analysis">
     regression
    </a>
    . Classification is used to determine what category something belongs in, after seeing a number of examples of things from several categories. Regression is the attempt to produce a function that describes the relationship between inputs and outputs and predicts how the outputs should change as the inputs change. In
    <a href="/wiki/Reinforcement_learning" title="Reinforcement learning">
     reinforcement learning
    </a>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Reinforcement_learning_76-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Reinforcement_learning-76">
      [76]
     </a>
    </sup>
    the agent is rewarded for good responses and punished for bad ones. The agent uses this sequence of rewards and punishments to form a strategy for operating in its problem space. These three types of learning can be analyzed in terms of
    <a href="/wiki/Decision_theory" title="Decision theory">
     decision theory
    </a>
    , using concepts like
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Utility_(economics)" title="Utility (economics)">
     utility
    </a>
    . The mathematical analysis of machine learning algorithms and their performance is a branch of
    <a href="/wiki/Theoretical_computer_science" title="Theoretical computer science">
     theoretical computer science
    </a>
    known as
    <a href="/wiki/Computational_learning_theory" title="Computational learning theory">
     computational learning theory
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
     [
     <i>
      <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
       <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2017)">
        citation needed
       </span>
      </a>
     </i>
     ]
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Within
    <a href="/wiki/Developmental_robotics" title="Developmental robotics">
     developmental robotics
    </a>
    , developmental learning approaches are elaborated upon to allow robots to accumulate repertoires of novel skills through autonomous self-exploration, social interaction with human teachers, and the use of guidance mechanisms (active learning, maturation, motor synergies, etc.).
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWengMcClellandPentlandSporns2001_77-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWengMcClellandPentlandSporns2001-77">
      [77]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELungarellaMettaPfeiferSandini2003_78-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELungarellaMettaPfeiferSandini2003-78">
      [78]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAsadaHosodaKuniyoshiIshiguro2009_79-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsadaHosodaKuniyoshiIshiguro2009-79">
      [79]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOudeyer2010_80-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOudeyer2010-80">
      [80]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Natural_language_processing">
     Natural language processing
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Natural language processing">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="thumb tright">
    <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
     <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ParseTree.svg">
      <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="120" data-file-width="120" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/ParseTree.svg/220px-ParseTree.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/ParseTree.svg/330px-ParseTree.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/ParseTree.svg/440px-ParseTree.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
     </a>
     <div class="thumbcaption">
      <div class="magnify">
       <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ParseTree.svg" title="Enlarge">
       </a>
      </div>
      A
      <a href="/wiki/Parse_tree" title="Parse tree">
       parse tree
      </a>
      represents the
      <a href="/wiki/Syntax" title="Syntax">
       syntactic
      </a>
      structure of a sentence according to some
      <a href="/wiki/Formal_grammar" title="Formal grammar">
       formal grammar
      </a>
      .
     </div>
    </div>
   </div>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Natural_language_processing" title="Natural language processing">
     Natural language processing
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Natural_language_processing" title="Natural language processing">
     Natural language processing
    </a>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Natural_language_processing_81-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Natural_language_processing-81">
      [81]
     </a>
    </sup>
    gives machines the ability to read and
    <a href="/wiki/Natural_language_understanding" title="Natural language understanding">
     understand
    </a>
    human language. A sufficiently powerful natural language processing system would enable
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Natural_language_user_interface" title="Natural language user interface">
     natural language user interfaces
    </a>
    and the acquisition of knowledge directly from human-written sources, such as newswire texts. Some straightforward applications of natural language processing include
    <a href="/wiki/Information_retrieval" title="Information retrieval">
     information retrieval
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Text_mining" title="Text mining">
     text mining
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Question_answering" title="Question answering">
     question answering
    </a>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82">
     <a href="#cite_note-82">
      [82]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Machine_translation" title="Machine translation">
     machine translation
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Applications_of_natural_language_processing_83-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Applications_of_natural_language_processing-83">
      [83]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    A common method of processing and extracting meaning from natural language is through
    <a href="/wiki/Latent_semantic_analysis" title="Latent semantic analysis">
     semantic indexing
    </a>
    . Although these indexes require a large volume of user input, it is expected that increases in processor speeds and decreases in data storage costs will result in greater efficiency.
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Perception">
     Perception
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Perception">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main articles:
    <a href="/wiki/Machine_perception" title="Machine perception">
     Machine perception
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Computer_vision" title="Computer vision">
     Computer vision
    </a>
    , and
    <a href="/wiki/Speech_recognition" title="Speech recognition">
     Speech recognition
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    <a href="/wiki/Machine_perception" title="Machine perception">
     Machine perception
    </a>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Machine_perception_84-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Machine_perception-84">
      [84]
     </a>
    </sup>
    is the ability to use input from sensors (such as cameras, microphones,
    <a href="/wiki/Tactile_sensor" title="Tactile sensor">
     tactile sensors
    </a>
    , sonar and others) to deduce aspects of the world.
    <a href="/wiki/Computer_vision" title="Computer vision">
     Computer vision
    </a>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Computer_vision_85-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Computer_vision-85">
      [85]
     </a>
    </sup>
    is the ability to analyze visual input. A few selected subproblems are
    <a href="/wiki/Speech_recognition" title="Speech recognition">
     speech recognition
    </a>
    ,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Speech_recognition_86-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Speech_recognition-86">
      [86]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <a href="/wiki/Facial_recognition_system" title="Facial recognition system">
     facial recognition
    </a>
    and
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Object_recognition" title="Object recognition">
     object recognition
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Object_recognition_87-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Object_recognition-87">
      [87]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Motion_and_manipulation">
     Motion and manipulation
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Motion and manipulation">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a href="/wiki/Robotics" title="Robotics">
     Robotics
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    The field of
    <a href="/wiki/Robotics" title="Robotics">
     robotics
    </a>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Robotics_88-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Robotics-88">
      [88]
     </a>
    </sup>
    is closely related to AI. Intelligence is required for robots to handle tasks such as object manipulation
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Configuration_space_89-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Configuration_space-89">
      [89]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Motion_planning" title="Motion planning">
     navigation
    </a>
    , with sub-problems such as
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Robot_localization" title="Robot localization">
     localization
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Robotic_mapping" title="Robotic mapping">
     mapping
    </a>
    , and
    <a href="/wiki/Motion_planning" title="Motion planning">
     motion planning
    </a>
    . These systems require that an agent is able to: Be spatially cognizant of its surroundings, learn from and build a map of its environment, figure out how to get from one point in space to another, and execute that movement (which often involves compliant motion, a process where movement requires maintaining physical contact with an object).
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETecuci2012_90-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETecuci2012-90">
      [90]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Robotic_mapping_91-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Robotic_mapping-91">
      [91]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Social_intelligence">
     Social intelligence
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Social intelligence">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a href="/wiki/Affective_computing" title="Affective computing">
     Affective computing
    </a>
   </div>
   <div class="thumb tright">
    <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
     <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kismet_robot_at_MIT_Museum.jpg">
      <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1704" data-file-width="2272" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Kismet_robot_at_MIT_Museum.jpg/220px-Kismet_robot_at_MIT_Museum.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Kismet_robot_at_MIT_Museum.jpg/330px-Kismet_robot_at_MIT_Museum.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Kismet_robot_at_MIT_Museum.jpg/440px-Kismet_robot_at_MIT_Museum.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
     </a>
     <div class="thumbcaption">
      <div class="magnify">
       <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kismet_robot_at_MIT_Museum.jpg" title="Enlarge">
       </a>
      </div>
      <a href="/wiki/Kismet_(robot)" title="Kismet (robot)">
       Kismet
      </a>
      , a robot with rudimentary social skills
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''Kismet''_92-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''Kismet''-92">
        [92]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </div>
    </div>
   </div>
   <p>
    Affective computing is the study and development of systems that can recognize, interpret, process, and simulate human
    <a href="/wiki/Affect_(psychology)" title="Affect (psychology)">
     affects
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThro1993_93-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThro1993-93">
      [93]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEdelson1991_94-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEdelson1991-94">
      [94]
     </a>
    </sup>
    It is an interdisciplinary field spanning
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Computer_sciences" title="Computer sciences">
     computer sciences
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Psychology" title="Psychology">
     psychology
    </a>
    , and
    <a href="/wiki/Cognitive_science" title="Cognitive science">
     cognitive science
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaoTan2005_95-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaoTan2005-95">
      [95]
     </a>
    </sup>
    While the origins of the field may be traced as far back as the early philosophical inquiries into
    <a href="/wiki/Emotion#The_James-Lange_Theory" title="Emotion">
     emotion
    </a>
    ,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJames1884_96-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJames1884-96">
      [96]
     </a>
    </sup>
    the more modern branch of computer science originated with
    <a href="/wiki/Rosalind_Picard" title="Rosalind Picard">
     Rosalind Picard
    </a>
    's 1995 paper
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPicard1995_97-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPicard1995-97">
      [97]
     </a>
    </sup>
    on "affective computing".
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98">
     <a href="#cite_note-98">
      [98]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99">
     <a href="#cite_note-99">
      [99]
     </a>
    </sup>
    A motivation for the research is the ability to simulate
    <a href="/wiki/Empathy" title="Empathy">
     empathy
    </a>
    , where the machine would be able to interpret human emotions and adapts its behavior to give an appropriate response to those emotions.
   </p>
   <p>
    Emotion and social skills
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Emotion_and_affective_computing_100-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Emotion_and_affective_computing-100">
      [100]
     </a>
    </sup>
    are important to an intelligent agent for two reasons. First, being able to predict the actions of others by understanding their motives and emotional states allow an agent to make better decisions. Concepts such as
    <a href="/wiki/Game_theory" title="Game theory">
     game theory
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Decision_theory" title="Decision theory">
     decision theory
    </a>
    , necessitate that an agent be able to detect and model human emotions. Second, in an effort to facilitate
    <a href="/wiki/Human%E2%80%93computer_interaction" title="Human–computer interaction">
     human–computer interaction
    </a>
    , an intelligent machine may want to display emotions (even if it does not experience those emotions itself) to appear more sensitive to the emotional dynamics of human interaction.
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Creativity">
     Creativity
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Creativity">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a href="/wiki/Computational_creativity" title="Computational creativity">
     Computational creativity
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    A sub-field of AI addresses
    <a href="/wiki/Creativity" title="Creativity">
     creativity
    </a>
    both theoretically (the philosophical psychological perspective) and practically (the specific implementation of systems that generate novel and useful outputs).
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="General_intelligence">
     General intelligence
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: General intelligence">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main articles:
    <a href="/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence" title="Artificial general intelligence">
     Artificial general intelligence
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/AI-complete" title="AI-complete">
     AI-complete
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    Many researchers think that their work will eventually be incorporated into a machine with
    <a href="/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence" title="Artificial general intelligence">
     artificial general intelligence
    </a>
    , combining all the skills mentioned above and even exceeding human ability in most or all these areas.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-General_intelligence_17-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-General_intelligence-17">
      [17]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Roberts_101-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Roberts-101">
      [101]
     </a>
    </sup>
    A few believe that
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anthropomorphic" title="Anthropomorphic">
     anthropomorphic
    </a>
    features like
    <a href="/wiki/Artificial_consciousness" title="Artificial consciousness">
     artificial consciousness
    </a>
    or an
    <a href="/wiki/Artificial_brain" title="Artificial brain">
     artificial brain
    </a>
    may be required for such a project.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Artificial_consciousness_102-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Artificial_consciousness-102">
      [102]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brain_simulation_103-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Brain_simulation-103">
      [103]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Many of the problems above also require that general intelligence be solved. For example, even specific straightforward tasks, like
    <a href="/wiki/Machine_translation" title="Machine translation">
     machine translation
    </a>
    , require that a machine read and write in both languages (
    <a href="#Natural_language_processing">
     NLP
    </a>
    ), follow the author's argument (
    <a href="#Deduction,_reasoning,_problem_solving">
     reason
    </a>
    ), know what is being talked about (
    <a href="#Knowledge_representation">
     knowledge
    </a>
    ), and faithfully reproduce the author's original intent (
    <a href="#Social_intelligence">
     social intelligence
    </a>
    ). A problem like machine translation is considered "
    <a href="/wiki/AI-complete" title="AI-complete">
     AI-complete
    </a>
    ", but all of these problems need to be solved simultaneously in order to reach human-level machine performance.
   </p>
   <h2>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Approaches">
     Approaches
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Approaches">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h2>
   <p>
    There is no established unifying theory or
    <a href="/wiki/Paradigm" title="Paradigm">
     paradigm
    </a>
    that guides AI research. Researchers disagree about many issues.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104">
     <a href="#cite_note-104">
      [104]
     </a>
    </sup>
    A few of the most long standing questions that have remained unanswered are these: should artificial intelligence simulate natural intelligence by studying
    <a href="/wiki/Psychology" title="Psychology">
     psychology
    </a>
    or
    <a href="/wiki/Neurology" title="Neurology">
     neurology
    </a>
    ? Or is
    <a href="/wiki/Human_biology" title="Human biology">
     human biology
    </a>
    as irrelevant to AI research as bird biology is to
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aeronautical_engineering" title="Aeronautical engineering">
     aeronautical engineering
    </a>
    ?
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Biological_intelligence_vs._intelligence_in_general_14-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-Biological_intelligence_vs._intelligence_in_general-14">
      [14]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Can intelligent behavior be described using simple, elegant principles (such as
    <a href="/wiki/Logic" title="Logic">
     logic
    </a>
    or
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Optimization_(mathematics)" title="Optimization (mathematics)">
     optimization
    </a>
    )? Or does it necessarily require solving a large number of completely unrelated problems?
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Neats_vs._scruffies_15-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-Neats_vs._scruffies-15">
      [15]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Can intelligence be reproduced using high-level symbols, similar to words and ideas? Or does it require "sub-symbolic" processing?
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Symbolic_vs._sub-symbolic_16-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-Symbolic_vs._sub-symbolic-16">
      [16]
     </a>
    </sup>
    John Haugeland, who coined the term GOFAI (Good Old-Fashioned Artificial Intelligence), also proposed that AI should more properly be referred to as
    <a href="/wiki/Synthetic_intelligence" title="Synthetic intelligence">
     synthetic intelligence
    </a>
    ,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHaugeland1985255_105-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHaugeland1985255-105">
      [105]
     </a>
    </sup>
    a term which has since been adopted by some non-GOFAI researchers.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELaw1994_106-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELaw1994-106">
      [106]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBach2008_107-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBach2008-107">
      [107]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Stuart Shapiro divides AI research into three approaches, which he calls computational psychology, computational philosophy, and computer science. Computational psychology is used to make computer programs that mimic human behavior.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_108-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-:2-108">
      [108]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Computational philosophy, is used to develop an adaptive, free-flowing computer mind.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_108-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-:2-108">
      [108]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Implementing computer science serves the goal of creating computers that can perform tasks that only people could previously accomplish.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_108-2">
     <a href="#cite_note-:2-108">
      [108]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Together, the humanesque behavior, mind, and actions make up artificial intelligence.
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Cybernetics_and_brain_simulation">
     Cybernetics and brain simulation
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Cybernetics and brain simulation">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main articles:
    <a href="/wiki/Cybernetics" title="Cybernetics">
     Cybernetics
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Computational_neuroscience" title="Computational neuroscience">
     Computational neuroscience
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    In the 1940s and 1950s, a number of researchers explored the connection between
    <a href="/wiki/Neurology" title="Neurology">
     neurology
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Information_theory" title="Information theory">
     information theory
    </a>
    , and
    <a href="/wiki/Cybernetics" title="Cybernetics">
     cybernetics
    </a>
    . Some of them built machines that used electronic networks to exhibit rudimentary intelligence, such as
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/W._Grey_Walter" title="W. Grey Walter">
     W. Grey Walter
    </a>
    's
    <a href="/wiki/Turtle_(robot)" title="Turtle (robot)">
     turtles
    </a>
    and the
    <a href="/wiki/Johns_Hopkins_Beast" title="Johns Hopkins Beast">
     Johns Hopkins Beast
    </a>
    . Many of these researchers gathered for meetings of the Teleological Society at
    <a href="/wiki/Princeton_University" title="Princeton University">
     Princeton University
    </a>
    and the
    <a href="/wiki/Ratio_Club" title="Ratio Club">
     Ratio Club
    </a>
    in England.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AI's_immediate_precursors_27-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-AI's_immediate_precursors-27">
      [27]
     </a>
    </sup>
    By 1960, this approach was largely abandoned, although elements of it would be revived in the 1980s.
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Symbolic">
     Symbolic
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Symbolic">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Symbolic_AI" title="Symbolic AI">
     Symbolic AI
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    When access to digital computers became possible in the middle 1950s, AI research began to explore the possibility that human intelligence could be reduced to symbol manipulation. The research was centered in three institutions:
    <a href="/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University" title="Carnegie Mellon University">
     Carnegie Mellon University
    </a>
    ,
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stanford" title="Stanford">
     Stanford
    </a>
    and
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MIT" title="MIT">
     MIT
    </a>
    , and each one developed its own style of research.
    <a href="/wiki/John_Haugeland" title="John Haugeland">
     John Haugeland
    </a>
    named these approaches to AI "good old fashioned AI" or "
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GOFAI" title="GOFAI">
     GOFAI
    </a>
    ".
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GOFAI_109-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-GOFAI-109">
      [109]
     </a>
    </sup>
    During the 1960s, symbolic approaches had achieved great success at simulating high-level thinking in small demonstration programs. Approaches based on
    <a href="/wiki/Cybernetics" title="Cybernetics">
     cybernetics
    </a>
    or
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neural_network" title="Neural network">
     neural networks
    </a>
    were abandoned or pushed into the background.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110">
     <a href="#cite_note-110">
      [110]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Researchers in the 1960s and the 1970s were convinced that symbolic approaches would eventually succeed in creating a machine with
    <a href="/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence" title="Artificial general intelligence">
     artificial general intelligence
    </a>
    and considered this the goal of their field.
   </p>
   <h4>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Cognitive_simulation">
     Cognitive simulation
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Cognitive simulation">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h4>
   <p>
    Economist
    <a href="/wiki/Herbert_A._Simon" title="Herbert A. Simon">
     Herbert Simon
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Allen_Newell" title="Allen Newell">
     Allen Newell
    </a>
    studied human problem-solving skills and attempted to formalize them, and their work laid the foundations of the field of artificial intelligence, as well as
    <a href="/wiki/Cognitive_science" title="Cognitive science">
     cognitive science
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Operations_research" title="Operations research">
     operations research
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Management_science" title="Management science">
     management science
    </a>
    . Their research team used the results of
    <a href="/wiki/Psychology" title="Psychology">
     psychological
    </a>
    experiments to develop programs that simulated the techniques that people used to solve problems. This tradition, centered at
    <a href="/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University" title="Carnegie Mellon University">
     Carnegie Mellon University
    </a>
    would eventually culminate in the development of the
    <a href="/wiki/Soar_(cognitive_architecture)" title="Soar (cognitive architecture)">
     Soar
    </a>
    architecture in the middle 1980s.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AI_at_CMU_in_the_60s_111-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-AI_at_CMU_in_the_60s-111">
      [111]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Soar_112-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Soar-112">
      [112]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h4>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Logic-based">
     Logic-based
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Logic-based">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h4>
   <p>
    Unlike
    <a href="/wiki/Allen_Newell" title="Allen Newell">
     Newell
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Herbert_A._Simon" title="Herbert A. Simon">
     Simon
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/John_McCarthy_(computer_scientist)" title="John McCarthy (computer scientist)">
     John McCarthy
    </a>
    felt that machines did not need to simulate human thought, but should instead try to find the essence of abstract reasoning and problem solving, regardless of whether people used the same algorithms.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Biological_intelligence_vs._intelligence_in_general_14-2">
     <a href="#cite_note-Biological_intelligence_vs._intelligence_in_general-14">
      [14]
     </a>
    </sup>
    His laboratory at
    <a href="/wiki/Stanford_University" title="Stanford University">
     Stanford
    </a>
    (
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stanford_Artificial_Intelligence_Laboratory" title="Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory">
     SAIL
    </a>
    ) focused on using formal
    <a href="/wiki/Logic" title="Logic">
     logic
    </a>
    to solve a wide variety of problems, including
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Knowledge_representation" title="Knowledge representation">
     knowledge representation
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Automated_planning_and_scheduling" title="Automated planning and scheduling">
     planning
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Machine_learning" title="Machine learning">
     learning
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AI_at_Stanford_in_the_60s_113-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-AI_at_Stanford_in_the_60s-113">
      [113]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Logic was also the focus of the work at the
    <a href="/wiki/University_of_Edinburgh" title="University of Edinburgh">
     University of Edinburgh
    </a>
    and elsewhere in Europe which led to the development of the programming language
    <a href="/wiki/Prolog" title="Prolog">
     Prolog
    </a>
    and the science of
    <a href="/wiki/Logic_programming" title="Logic programming">
     logic programming
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AI_at_Edinburgh_and_France_in_the_60s_114-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-AI_at_Edinburgh_and_France_in_the_60s-114">
      [114]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h4>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Anti-logic_or_scruffy">
     Anti-logic or scruffy
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Anti-logic or scruffy">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h4>
   <p>
    Researchers at
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MIT" title="MIT">
     MIT
    </a>
    (such as
    <a href="/wiki/Marvin_Minsky" title="Marvin Minsky">
     Marvin Minsky
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Seymour_Papert" title="Seymour Papert">
     Seymour Papert
    </a>
    )
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AI_at_MIT_in_the_60s_115-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-AI_at_MIT_in_the_60s-115">
      [115]
     </a>
    </sup>
    found that solving difficult problems in
    <a href="/wiki/Computer_vision" title="Computer vision">
     vision
    </a>
    and
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Natural_language_processing" title="Natural language processing">
     natural language processing
    </a>
    required ad-hoc solutions – they argued that there was no simple and general principle (like
    <a href="/wiki/Logic" title="Logic">
     logic
    </a>
    ) that would capture all the aspects of intelligent behavior.
    <a href="/wiki/Roger_Schank" title="Roger Schank">
     Roger Schank
    </a>
    described their "anti-logic" approaches as "
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neats_vs._scruffies" title="Neats vs. scruffies">
     scruffy
    </a>
    " (as opposed to the "
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neats_vs._scruffies" title="Neats vs. scruffies">
     neat
    </a>
    " paradigms at
    <a href="/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University" title="Carnegie Mellon University">
     CMU
    </a>
    and
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stanford" title="Stanford">
     Stanford
    </a>
    ).
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Neats_vs._scruffies_15-2">
     <a href="#cite_note-Neats_vs._scruffies-15">
      [15]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Commonsense_knowledge_bases" title="Commonsense knowledge bases">
     Commonsense knowledge bases
    </a>
    (such as
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doug_Lenat" title="Doug Lenat">
     Doug Lenat
    </a>
    's
    <a href="/wiki/Cyc" title="Cyc">
     Cyc
    </a>
    ) are an example of "scruffy" AI, since they must be built by hand, one complicated concept at a time.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cyc_116-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Cyc-116">
      [116]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h4>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Knowledge-based">
     Knowledge-based
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Knowledge-based">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h4>
   <p>
    When computers with large memories became available around 1970, researchers from all three traditions began to build
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Knowledge_representation" title="Knowledge representation">
     knowledge
    </a>
    into AI applications.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Knowledge_revolution_117-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Knowledge_revolution-117">
      [117]
     </a>
    </sup>
    This "knowledge revolution" led to the development and deployment of
    <a href="/wiki/Expert_system" title="Expert system">
     expert systems
    </a>
    (introduced by
    <a href="/wiki/Edward_Feigenbaum" title="Edward Feigenbaum">
     Edward Feigenbaum
    </a>
    ), the first truly successful form of AI software.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Expert_systems_37-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-Expert_systems-37">
      [37]
     </a>
    </sup>
    The knowledge revolution was also driven by the realization that enormous amounts of knowledge would be required by many simple AI applications.
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Sub-symbolic">
     Sub-symbolic
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Sub-symbolic">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <p>
    By the 1980s progress in symbolic AI seemed to stall and many believed that symbolic systems would never be able to imitate all the processes of human cognition, especially
    <a href="/wiki/Machine_perception" title="Machine perception">
     perception
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Robotics" title="Robotics">
     robotics
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Machine_learning" title="Machine learning">
     learning
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Pattern_recognition" title="Pattern recognition">
     pattern recognition
    </a>
    . A number of researchers began to look into "sub-symbolic" approaches to specific AI problems.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Symbolic_vs._sub-symbolic_16-2">
     <a href="#cite_note-Symbolic_vs._sub-symbolic-16">
      [16]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Sub-symbolic methods manage to approach intelligence without specific representations of knowledge.
   </p>
   <h4>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Embodied_intelligence">
     Embodied intelligence
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Embodied intelligence">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h4>
   <p>
    This includes
    <a href="/wiki/Embodied_agent" title="Embodied agent">
     embodied
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Situated" title="Situated">
     situated
    </a>
    ,
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Behavior-based_AI" title="Behavior-based AI">
     behavior-based
    </a>
    , and
    <a href="/wiki/Nouvelle_AI" title="Nouvelle AI">
     nouvelle AI
    </a>
    . Researchers from the related field of
    <a href="/wiki/Robotics" title="Robotics">
     robotics
    </a>
    , such as
    <a href="/wiki/Rodney_Brooks" title="Rodney Brooks">
     Rodney Brooks
    </a>
    , rejected symbolic AI and focused on the basic engineering problems that would allow robots to move and survive.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Embodied_AI_118-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Embodied_AI-118">
      [118]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Their work revived the non-symbolic viewpoint of the early
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cybernetic" title="Cybernetic">
     cybernetics
    </a>
    researchers of the 1950s and reintroduced the use of
    <a href="/wiki/Control_theory" title="Control theory">
     control theory
    </a>
    in AI. This coincided with the development of the
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Embodied_mind_thesis" title="Embodied mind thesis">
     embodied mind thesis
    </a>
    in the related field of
    <a href="/wiki/Cognitive_science" title="Cognitive science">
     cognitive science
    </a>
    : the idea that aspects of the body (such as movement, perception and visualization) are required for higher intelligence.
   </p>
   <h4>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Computational_intelligence_and_soft_computing">
     Computational intelligence and soft computing
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Computational intelligence and soft computing">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h4>
   <p>
    Interest in
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neural_networks" title="Neural networks">
     neural networks
    </a>
    and "
    <a href="/wiki/Connectionism" title="Connectionism">
     connectionism
    </a>
    " was revived by
    <a href="/wiki/David_Rumelhart" title="David Rumelhart">
     David Rumelhart
    </a>
    and others in the middle of the 1980s.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Revival_of_connectionism_119-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Revival_of_connectionism-119">
      [119]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Neural networks are an example of
    <a href="/wiki/Soft_computing" title="Soft computing">
     soft computing
    </a>
    --- they are solutions to problems which cannot be solved with complete logical certainty, and where an approximate solution is often sufficient. Other
    <a href="/wiki/Soft_computing" title="Soft computing">
     soft computing
    </a>
    approaches to AI include
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fuzzy_system" title="Fuzzy system">
     fuzzy systems
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Evolutionary_computation" title="Evolutionary computation">
     evolutionary computation
    </a>
    and many statistical tools. The application of soft computing to AI is studied collectively by the emerging discipline of
    <a href="/wiki/Computational_intelligence" title="Computational intelligence">
     computational intelligence
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Computational_intelligence_120-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Computational_intelligence-120">
      [120]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Statistical">
     Statistical
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Statistical">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <p>
    In the 1990s, AI researchers developed sophisticated mathematical tools to solve specific subproblems. These tools are truly
    <a href="/wiki/Scientific_method" title="Scientific method">
     scientific
    </a>
    , in the sense that their results are both measurable and verifiable, and they have been responsible for many of AI's recent successes. The shared mathematical language has also permitted a high level of collaboration with more established fields (like
    <a href="/wiki/Mathematics" title="Mathematics">
     mathematics
    </a>
    , economics or
    <a href="/wiki/Operations_research" title="Operations research">
     operations research
    </a>
    ).
    <a href="/wiki/Stuart_J._Russell" title="Stuart J. Russell">
     Stuart Russell
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Peter_Norvig" title="Peter Norvig">
     Peter Norvig
    </a>
    describe this movement as nothing less than a "revolution" and "the victory of the
    <a href="/wiki/Neats_and_scruffies" title="Neats and scruffies">
     neats
    </a>
    ".
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Formal_methods_in_AI_38-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-Formal_methods_in_AI-38">
      [38]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Critics argue that these techniques (with few exceptions
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHutter2012_121-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHutter2012-121">
      [121]
     </a>
    </sup>
    ) are too focused on particular problems and have failed to address the long-term goal of general intelligence.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELangley2011_122-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELangley2011-122">
      [122]
     </a>
    </sup>
    There is an ongoing debate about the relevance and validity of statistical approaches in AI, exemplified in part by exchanges between
    <a href="/wiki/Peter_Norvig" title="Peter Norvig">
     Peter Norvig
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Noam_Chomsky" title="Noam Chomsky">
     Noam Chomsky
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKatz2012_123-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKatz2012-123">
      [123]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENorvig2012_124-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorvig2012-124">
      [124]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Integrating_the_approaches">
     Integrating the approaches
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Integrating the approaches">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <dl>
    <dt>
     Intelligent agent paradigm
    </dt>
    <dd>
     An
     <a href="/wiki/Intelligent_agent" title="Intelligent agent">
      intelligent agent
     </a>
     is a system that perceives its environment and takes actions which maximize its chances of success. The simplest intelligent agents are programs that solve specific problems. More complicated agents include human beings and organizations of human beings (such as
     <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Firm" title="Firm">
      firms
     </a>
     ). The paradigm gives researchers license to study isolated problems and find solutions that are both verifiable and useful, without agreeing on one single approach. An agent that solves a specific problem can use any approach that works – some agents are symbolic and logical, some are sub-symbolic
     <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neural_network" title="Neural network">
      neural networks
     </a>
     and others may use new approaches. The paradigm also gives researchers a common language to communicate with other fields—such as
     <a href="/wiki/Decision_theory" title="Decision theory">
      decision theory
     </a>
     and economics—that also use concepts of abstract agents. The intelligent agent paradigm became widely accepted during the 1990s.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Intelligent_agents_125-0">
      <a href="#cite_note-Intelligent_agents-125">
       [125]
      </a>
     </sup>
    </dd>
   </dl>
   <dl>
    <dt>
     <a href="/wiki/Agent_architecture" title="Agent architecture">
      Agent architectures
     </a>
     and
     <a href="/wiki/Cognitive_architecture" title="Cognitive architecture">
      cognitive architectures
     </a>
    </dt>
    <dd>
     Researchers have designed systems to build intelligent systems out of interacting
     <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Intelligent_agents" title="Intelligent agents">
      intelligent agents
     </a>
     in a
     <a href="/wiki/Multi-agent_system" title="Multi-agent system">
      multi-agent system
     </a>
     .
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Agent_architectures_126-0">
      <a href="#cite_note-Agent_architectures-126">
       [126]
      </a>
     </sup>
     A system with both symbolic and sub-symbolic components is a
     <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_intelligent_system" title="Hybrid intelligent system">
      hybrid intelligent system
     </a>
     , and the study of such systems is
     <a href="/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_systems_integration" title="Artificial intelligence systems integration">
      artificial intelligence systems integration
     </a>
     . A
     <a href="/wiki/Hierarchical_control_system" title="Hierarchical control system">
      hierarchical control system
     </a>
     provides a bridge between sub-symbolic AI at its lowest, reactive levels and traditional symbolic AI at its highest levels, where relaxed time constraints permit planning and world modelling.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hierarchical_control_system_127-0">
      <a href="#cite_note-Hierarchical_control_system-127">
       [127]
      </a>
     </sup>
     <a href="/wiki/Rodney_Brooks" title="Rodney Brooks">
      Rodney Brooks
     </a>
     '
     <a href="/wiki/Subsumption_architecture" title="Subsumption architecture">
      subsumption architecture
     </a>
     was an early proposal for such a hierarchical system.
     <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
      [
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
        <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2017)">
         citation needed
        </span>
       </a>
      </i>
      ]
     </sup>
    </dd>
   </dl>
   <h2>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Tools">
     Tools
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Tools">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h2>
   <p>
    In the course of 60 or so years of research, AI has developed a large number of tools to solve the most difficult problems in
    <a href="/wiki/Computer_science" title="Computer science">
     computer science
    </a>
    . A few of the most general of these methods are discussed below.
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Search_and_optimization">
     Search and optimization
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Search and optimization">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main articles:
    <a href="/wiki/Search_algorithm" title="Search algorithm">
     Search algorithm
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Mathematical_optimization" title="Mathematical optimization">
     Mathematical optimization
    </a>
    , and
    <a href="/wiki/Evolutionary_computation" title="Evolutionary computation">
     Evolutionary computation
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    Many problems in AI can be solved in theory by intelligently searching through many possible solutions:
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Search_128-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Search-128">
      [128]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <a href="#Deduction,_reasoning,_problem_solving">
     Reasoning
    </a>
    can be reduced to performing a search. For example, logical proof can be viewed as searching for a path that leads from
    <a href="/wiki/Premise" title="Premise">
     premises
    </a>
    to
    <a href="/wiki/Logical_consequence" title="Logical consequence">
     conclusions
    </a>
    , where each step is the application of an
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Inference_rule" title="Inference rule">
     inference rule
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Logic_as_search_129-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Logic_as_search-129">
      [129]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <a href="/wiki/Automated_planning_and_scheduling" title="Automated planning and scheduling">
     Planning
    </a>
    algorithms search through trees of goals and subgoals, attempting to find a path to a target goal, a process called
    <a href="/wiki/Means-ends_analysis" title="Means-ends analysis">
     means-ends analysis
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Planning_as_search_130-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Planning_as_search-130">
      [130]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <a href="/wiki/Robotics" title="Robotics">
     Robotics
    </a>
    algorithms for moving limbs and grasping objects use
    <a href="/wiki/Local_search_(optimization)" title="Local search (optimization)">
     local searches
    </a>
    in
    <a href="/wiki/Configuration_space_(physics)" title="Configuration space (physics)">
     configuration space
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Configuration_space_89-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-Configuration_space-89">
      [89]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Many
    <a href="/wiki/Machine_learning" title="Machine learning">
     learning
    </a>
    algorithms use search algorithms based on
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Optimization_(mathematics)" title="Optimization (mathematics)">
     optimization
    </a>
    .
   </p>
   <p>
    Simple exhaustive searches
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Uninformed_search_131-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Uninformed_search-131">
      [131]
     </a>
    </sup>
    are rarely sufficient for most real world problems: the
    <a href="/wiki/Search_algorithm" title="Search algorithm">
     search space
    </a>
    (the number of places to search) quickly grows to
    <a href="/wiki/Large_numbers#Astronomically_large_numbers" title="Large numbers">
     astronomical numbers
    </a>
    . The result is a search that is
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Computation_time" title="Computation time">
     too slow
    </a>
    or never completes. The solution, for many problems, is to use "
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Heuristics" title="Heuristics">
     heuristics
    </a>
    " or "rules of thumb" that prioritize choices in favor of those that are more likely to reach a goal, and to do so in a shorter number of steps. In some search methodologies heuristics can also serve to entirely eliminate some choices that are unlikely to lead to a goal (called "
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pruning_(algorithm)" title="Pruning (algorithm)">
     pruning
    </a>
    the
    <a href="/wiki/Search_tree" title="Search tree">
     search tree
    </a>
    ").
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Heuristics" title="Heuristics">
     Heuristics
    </a>
    supply the program with a "best guess" for the path on which the solution lies.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Informed_search_132-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Informed_search-132">
      [132]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Heuristics limit the search for solutions into a smaller sample size.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETecuci2012_90-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETecuci2012-90">
      [90]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    A very different kind of search came to prominence in the 1990s, based on the mathematical theory of
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Optimization_(mathematics)" title="Optimization (mathematics)">
     optimization
    </a>
    . For many problems, it is possible to begin the search with some form of a guess and then refine the guess incrementally until no more refinements can be made. These algorithms can be visualized as blind
    <a href="/wiki/Hill_climbing" title="Hill climbing">
     hill climbing
    </a>
    : we begin the search at a random point on the landscape, and then, by jumps or steps, we keep moving our guess uphill, until we reach the top. Other optimization algorithms are
    <a href="/wiki/Simulated_annealing" title="Simulated annealing">
     simulated annealing
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Beam_search" title="Beam search">
     beam search
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Random_optimization" title="Random optimization">
     random optimization
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Optimization_search_133-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Optimization_search-133">
      [133]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    <a href="/wiki/Evolutionary_computation" title="Evolutionary computation">
     Evolutionary computation
    </a>
    uses a form of optimization search. For example, they may begin with a population of organisms (the guesses) and then allow them to mutate and recombine,
    <a href="/wiki/Natural_selection" title="Natural selection">
     selecting
    </a>
    only the fittest to survive each generation (refining the guesses). Forms of
    <a href="/wiki/Evolutionary_computation" title="Evolutionary computation">
     evolutionary computation
    </a>
    include
    <a href="/wiki/Swarm_intelligence" title="Swarm intelligence">
     swarm intelligence
    </a>
    algorithms (such as
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ant_colony_optimization" title="Ant colony optimization">
     ant colony
    </a>
    or
    <a href="/wiki/Particle_swarm_optimization" title="Particle swarm optimization">
     particle swarm optimization
    </a>
    )
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Society_based_learning_134-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Society_based_learning-134">
      [134]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Evolutionary_algorithms" title="Evolutionary algorithms">
     evolutionary algorithms
    </a>
    (such as
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Genetic_algorithms" title="Genetic algorithms">
     genetic algorithms
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Gene_expression_programming" title="Gene expression programming">
     gene expression programming
    </a>
    , and
    <a href="/wiki/Genetic_programming" title="Genetic programming">
     genetic programming
    </a>
    ).
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Genetic_programming_135-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Genetic_programming-135">
      [135]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Logic">
     Logic
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Logic">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main articles:
    <a href="/wiki/Logic_programming" title="Logic programming">
     Logic programming
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Automated_reasoning" title="Automated reasoning">
     Automated reasoning
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    <a href="/wiki/Logic" title="Logic">
     Logic
    </a>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Logic_136-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Logic-136">
      [136]
     </a>
    </sup>
    is used for knowledge representation and problem solving, but it can be applied to other problems as well. For example, the
    <a href="/wiki/Satplan" title="Satplan">
     satplan
    </a>
    algorithm uses logic for
    <a href="/wiki/Automated_planning_and_scheduling" title="Automated planning and scheduling">
     planning
    </a>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Satplan_137-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Satplan-137">
      [137]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Inductive_logic_programming" title="Inductive logic programming">
     inductive logic programming
    </a>
    is a method for
    <a href="/wiki/Machine_learning" title="Machine learning">
     learning
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Symbolic_learning_techniques_138-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Symbolic_learning_techniques-138">
      [138]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Several different forms of logic are used in AI research.
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Propositional_logic" title="Propositional logic">
     Propositional
    </a>
    or
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sentential_logic" title="Sentential logic">
     sentential logic
    </a>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Propositional_logic_139-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Propositional_logic-139">
      [139]
     </a>
    </sup>
    is the logic of statements which can be true or false.
    <a href="/wiki/First-order_logic" title="First-order logic">
     First-order logic
    </a>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-First-order_logic_140-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-First-order_logic-140">
      [140]
     </a>
    </sup>
    also allows the use of
    <a href="/wiki/Quantifier_(logic)" title="Quantifier (logic)">
     quantifiers
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Predicate_(mathematical_logic)" title="Predicate (mathematical logic)">
     predicates
    </a>
    , and can express facts about objects, their properties, and their relations with each other.
    <a href="/wiki/Fuzzy_logic" title="Fuzzy logic">
     Fuzzy logic
    </a>
    ,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fuzzy_logic_141-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Fuzzy_logic-141">
      [141]
     </a>
    </sup>
    is a version of first-order logic which allows the truth of a statement to be represented as a value between 0 and 1, rather than simply True (1) or False (0).
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fuzzy_system" title="Fuzzy system">
     Fuzzy systems
    </a>
    can be used for uncertain reasoning and have been widely used in modern industrial and consumer
    <a href="/wiki/Pattern_recognition" title="Pattern recognition">
     product control systems
    </a>
    .
    <a href="/wiki/Subjective_logic" title="Subjective logic">
     Subjective logic
    </a>
