    <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
     [
     <i>
      <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
       <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2017)">
        citation needed
       </span>
      </a>
     </i>
     ]
    </sup>
    models uncertainty in a different and more explicit manner than fuzzy-logic: a given binomial opinion satisfies belief + disbelief + uncertainty = 1 within a
    <a href="/wiki/Beta_distribution" title="Beta distribution">
     Beta distribution
    </a>
    . By this method, ignorance can be distinguished from probabilistic statements that an agent makes with high confidence.
   </p>
   <p>
    <a href="/wiki/Default_logic" title="Default logic">
     Default logics
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Non-monotonic_logic" title="Non-monotonic logic">
     non-monotonic logics
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Circumscription_(logic)" title="Circumscription (logic)">
     circumscription
    </a>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Default_reasoning_and_non-monotonic_logic_62-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-Default_reasoning_and_non-monotonic_logic-62">
      [62]
     </a>
    </sup>
    are forms of logic designed to help with default reasoning and the
    <a href="/wiki/Qualification_problem" title="Qualification problem">
     qualification problem
    </a>
    . Several extensions of logic have been designed to handle specific domains of
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Knowledge_representation" title="Knowledge representation">
     knowledge
    </a>
    , such as:
    <a href="/wiki/Description_logic" title="Description logic">
     description logics
    </a>
    ;
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Representing_categories_and_relations_54-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-Representing_categories_and_relations-54">
      [54]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <a href="/wiki/Situation_calculus" title="Situation calculus">
     situation calculus
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Event_calculus" title="Event calculus">
     event calculus
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Fluent_calculus" title="Fluent calculus">
     fluent calculus
    </a>
    (for representing events and time);
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Representing_time_55-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-Representing_time-55">
      [55]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <a href="/wiki/Causality#Causal_calculus" title="Causality">
     causal calculus
    </a>
    ;
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Representing_causation_56-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-Representing_causation-56">
      [56]
     </a>
    </sup>
    belief calculus;
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142">
     <a href="#cite_note-142">
      [142]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Modal_logic" title="Modal logic">
     modal logics
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Representing_knowledge_about_knowledge_57-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-Representing_knowledge_about_knowledge-57">
      [57]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Probabilistic_methods_for_uncertain_reasoning">
     Probabilistic methods for uncertain reasoning
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Probabilistic methods for uncertain reasoning">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main articles:
    <a href="/wiki/Bayesian_network" title="Bayesian network">
     Bayesian network
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Hidden_Markov_model" title="Hidden Markov model">
     Hidden Markov model
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Kalman_filter" title="Kalman filter">
     Kalman filter
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Particle_filter" title="Particle filter">
     Particle filter
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Decision_theory" title="Decision theory">
     Decision theory
    </a>
    , and
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Utility_theory" title="Utility theory">
     Utility theory
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    Many problems in AI (in reasoning, planning, learning, perception and robotics) require the agent to operate with incomplete or uncertain information. AI researchers have devised a number of powerful tools to solve these problems using methods from
    <a href="/wiki/Probability" title="Probability">
     probability
    </a>
    theory and economics.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stochastic_methods_for_uncertain_reasoning_143-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Stochastic_methods_for_uncertain_reasoning-143">
      [143]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    <a href="/wiki/Bayesian_network" title="Bayesian network">
     Bayesian networks
    </a>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bayesian_networks_144-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Bayesian_networks-144">
      [144]
     </a>
    </sup>
    are a very general tool that can be used for a large number of problems: reasoning (using the
    <a href="/wiki/Bayesian_inference" title="Bayesian inference">
     Bayesian inference
    </a>
    algorithm),
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bayesian_inference_145-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Bayesian_inference-145">
      [145]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <a href="/wiki/Machine_learning" title="Machine learning">
     learning
    </a>
    (using the
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Expectation-maximization_algorithm" title="Expectation-maximization algorithm">
     expectation-maximization algorithm
    </a>
    ),
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bayesian_learning_146-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Bayesian_learning-146">
      [146]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <a href="/wiki/Automated_planning_and_scheduling" title="Automated planning and scheduling">
     planning
    </a>
    (using
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Decision_network" title="Decision network">
     decision networks
    </a>
    )
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bayesian_decision_networks_147-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Bayesian_decision_networks-147">
      [147]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Machine_perception" title="Machine perception">
     perception
    </a>
    (using
    <a href="/wiki/Dynamic_Bayesian_network" title="Dynamic Bayesian network">
     dynamic Bayesian networks
    </a>
    ).
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stochastic_temporal_models_148-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Stochastic_temporal_models-148">
      [148]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Probabilistic algorithms can also be used for filtering, prediction, smoothing and finding explanations for streams of data, helping
    <a href="/wiki/Machine_perception" title="Machine perception">
     perception
    </a>
    systems to analyze processes that occur over time (e.g.,
    <a href="/wiki/Hidden_Markov_model" title="Hidden Markov model">
     hidden Markov models
    </a>
    or
    <a href="/wiki/Kalman_filter" title="Kalman filter">
     Kalman filters
    </a>
    ).
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stochastic_temporal_models_148-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-Stochastic_temporal_models-148">
      [148]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    A key concept from the science of economics is "
    <a href="/wiki/Utility" title="Utility">
     utility
    </a>
    ": a measure of how valuable something is to an intelligent agent. Precise mathematical tools have been developed that analyze how an agent can make choices and plan, using
    <a href="/wiki/Decision_theory" title="Decision theory">
     decision theory
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Decision_analysis" title="Decision analysis">
     decision analysis
    </a>
    ,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Decisions_theory_and_analysis_149-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Decisions_theory_and_analysis-149">
      [149]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Applied_information_economics" title="Applied information economics">
     information value theory
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Information_value_theory_68-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-Information_value_theory-68">
      [68]
     </a>
    </sup>
    These tools include models such as
    <a href="/wiki/Markov_decision_process" title="Markov decision process">
     Markov decision processes
    </a>
    ,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Markov_decision_process_150-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Markov_decision_process-150">
      [150]
     </a>
    </sup>
    dynamic
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Decision_network" title="Decision network">
     decision networks
    </a>
    ,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stochastic_temporal_models_148-2">
     <a href="#cite_note-Stochastic_temporal_models-148">
      [148]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <a href="/wiki/Game_theory" title="Game theory">
     game theory
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Mechanism_design" title="Mechanism design">
     mechanism design
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Game_theory_and_mechanism_design_151-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Game_theory_and_mechanism_design-151">
      [151]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Classifiers_and_statistical_learning_methods">
     Classifiers and statistical learning methods
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Classifiers and statistical learning methods">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main articles:
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Classifier_(mathematics)" title="Classifier (mathematics)">
     Classifier (mathematics)
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Statistical_classification" title="Statistical classification">
     Statistical classification
    </a>
    , and
    <a href="/wiki/Machine_learning" title="Machine learning">
     Machine learning
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    The simplest AI applications can be divided into two types: classifiers ("if shiny then diamond") and controllers ("if shiny then pick up"). Controllers do, however, also classify conditions before inferring actions, and therefore classification forms a central part of many AI systems.
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Classifier_(mathematics)" title="Classifier (mathematics)">
     Classifiers
    </a>
    are functions that use
    <a href="/wiki/Pattern_matching" title="Pattern matching">
     pattern matching
    </a>
    to determine a closest match. They can be tuned according to examples, making them very attractive for use in AI. These examples are known as observations or patterns. In supervised learning, each pattern belongs to a certain predefined class. A class can be seen as a decision that has to be made. All the observations combined with their class labels are known as a data set. When a new observation is received, that observation is classified based on previous experience.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Classifiers_152-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Classifiers-152">
      [152]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    A classifier can be trained in various ways; there are many statistical and
    <a href="/wiki/Machine_learning" title="Machine learning">
     machine learning
    </a>
    approaches. The most widely used classifiers are the
    <a href="/wiki/Artificial_neural_network" title="Artificial neural network">
     neural network
    </a>
    ,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Neural_networks_153-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Neural_networks-153">
      [153]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kernel_methods" title="Kernel methods">
     kernel methods
    </a>
    such as the
    <a href="/wiki/Support_vector_machine" title="Support vector machine">
     support vector machine
    </a>
    ,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kernel_methods_154-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Kernel_methods-154">
      [154]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/K-nearest_neighbor_algorithm" title="K-nearest neighbor algorithm">
     k-nearest neighbor algorithm
    </a>
    ,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-K-nearest_neighbor_algorithm_155-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-K-nearest_neighbor_algorithm-155">
      [155]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gaussian_mixture_model" title="Gaussian mixture model">
     Gaussian mixture model
    </a>
    ,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gaussian_mixture_model_156-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Gaussian_mixture_model-156">
      [156]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <a href="/wiki/Naive_Bayes_classifier" title="Naive Bayes classifier">
     naive Bayes classifier
    </a>
    ,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Naive_Bayes_classifier_157-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Naive_Bayes_classifier-157">
      [157]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Decision_tree_learning" title="Decision tree learning">
     decision tree
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Decision_tree_158-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Decision_tree-158">
      [158]
     </a>
    </sup>
    The performance of these classifiers have been compared over a wide range of tasks. Classifier performance depends greatly on the characteristics of the data to be classified. There is no single classifier that works best on all given problems; this is also referred to as the "
    <a href="/wiki/No_free_lunch_in_search_and_optimization" title="No free lunch in search and optimization">
     no free lunch
    </a>
    " theorem. Determining a suitable classifier for a given problem is still more an art than science.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Classifier_performance_159-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Classifier_performance-159">
      [159]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Neural_networks">
     Neural networks
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Neural networks">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main articles:
    <a href="/wiki/Artificial_neural_network" title="Artificial neural network">
     Artificial neural network
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Connectionism" title="Connectionism">
     Connectionism
    </a>
   </div>
   <div class="thumb tright">
    <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
     <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Artificial_neural_network.svg">
      <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="560" height="196" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Artificial_neural_network.svg/220px-Artificial_neural_network.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Artificial_neural_network.svg/330px-Artificial_neural_network.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Artificial_neural_network.svg/440px-Artificial_neural_network.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
     </a>
     <div class="thumbcaption">
      <div class="magnify">
       <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Artificial_neural_network.svg" title="Enlarge">
       </a>
      </div>
      A neural network is an interconnected group of nodes, akin to the vast network of
      <a href="/wiki/Neuron" title="Neuron">
       neurons
      </a>
      in the
      <a href="/wiki/Human_brain" title="Human brain">
       human brain
      </a>
      .
     </div>
    </div>
   </div>
   <p>
    Neural networks are modeled after the neurons in the human brain, where a trained algorithm determines an output response for input signals.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160">
     <a href="#cite_note-160">
      [160]
     </a>
    </sup>
    The study of non-learning
    <a href="/wiki/Artificial_neural_network" title="Artificial neural network">
     artificial neural networks
    </a>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Neural_networks_153-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-Neural_networks-153">
      [153]
     </a>
    </sup>
    began in the decade before the field of AI research was founded, in the work of
    <a href="/wiki/Walter_Pitts" title="Walter Pitts">
     Walter Pitts
    </a>
    and
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Warren_McCullouch" title="Warren McCullouch">
     Warren McCullouch
    </a>
    .
    <a href="/wiki/Frank_Rosenblatt" title="Frank Rosenblatt">
     Frank Rosenblatt
    </a>
    invented the
    <a href="/wiki/Perceptron" title="Perceptron">
     perceptron
    </a>
    , a learning network with a single layer, similar to the old concept of
    <a href="/wiki/Linear_regression" title="Linear regression">
     linear regression
    </a>
    . Early pioneers also include
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alexey_Grigorevich_Ivakhnenko" title="Alexey Grigorevich Ivakhnenko">
     Alexey Grigorevich Ivakhnenko
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Teuvo_Kohonen" title="Teuvo Kohonen">
     Teuvo Kohonen
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Grossberg" title="Stephen Grossberg">
     Stephen Grossberg
    </a>
    ,
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kunihiko_Fukushima" title="Kunihiko Fukushima">
     Kunihiko Fukushima
    </a>
    , Christoph von der Malsburg, David Willshaw,
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shun-Ichi_Amari" title="Shun-Ichi Amari">
     Shun-Ichi Amari
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Bernard_Widrow" title="Bernard Widrow">
     Bernard Widrow
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/John_Hopfield" title="John Hopfield">
     John Hopfield
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Eduardo_R._Caianiello" title="Eduardo R. Caianiello">
     Eduardo R. Caianiello
    </a>
    , and others.
   </p>
   <p>
    The main categories of networks are acyclic or
    <a href="/wiki/Feedforward_neural_network" title="Feedforward neural network">
     feedforward neural networks
    </a>
    (where the signal passes in only one direction) and
    <a href="/wiki/Recurrent_neural_network" title="Recurrent neural network">
     recurrent neural networks
    </a>
    (which allow feedback and short-term memories of previous input events). Among the most popular feedforward networks are
    <a href="/wiki/Perceptron" title="Perceptron">
     perceptrons
    </a>
    ,
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Multi-layer_perceptron" title="Multi-layer perceptron">
     multi-layer perceptrons
    </a>
    and
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Radial_basis_network" title="Radial basis network">
     radial basis networks
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Feedforward_neural_networks_161-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Feedforward_neural_networks-161">
      [161]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Neural networks can be applied to the problem of
    <a href="/wiki/Intelligent_control" title="Intelligent control">
     intelligent control
    </a>
    (for robotics) or
    <a href="/wiki/Machine_learning" title="Machine learning">
     learning
    </a>
    , using such techniques as
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hebbian_learning" title="Hebbian learning">
     Hebbian learning
    </a>
    ,
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GMDH" title="GMDH">
     GMDH
    </a>
    or
    <a href="/wiki/Competitive_learning" title="Competitive learning">
     competitive learning
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Learning_in_neural_networks_162-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Learning_in_neural_networks-162">
      [162]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Today, neural networks are often trained by the
    <a href="/wiki/Backpropagation" title="Backpropagation">
     backpropagation
    </a>
    algorithm, which had been around since 1970 as the reverse mode of
    <a href="/wiki/Automatic_differentiation" title="Automatic differentiation">
     automatic differentiation
    </a>
    published by
    <a href="/wiki/Seppo_Linnainmaa" title="Seppo Linnainmaa">
     Seppo Linnainmaa
    </a>
    ,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lin1970_163-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-lin1970-163">
      [163]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-grie2012_164-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-grie2012-164">
      [164]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and was introduced to neural networks by
    <a href="/wiki/Paul_Werbos" title="Paul Werbos">
     Paul Werbos
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WERBOS1974_165-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-WERBOS1974-165">
      [165]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-werbos1982_166-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-werbos1982-166">
      [166]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Backpropagation_167-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Backpropagation-167">
      [167]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    <a href="/wiki/Hierarchical_temporal_memory" title="Hierarchical temporal memory">
     Hierarchical temporal memory
    </a>
    is an approach that models some of the structural and algorithmic properties of the
    <a href="/wiki/Neocortex" title="Neocortex">
     neocortex
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hierarchical_temporal_memory_168-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Hierarchical_temporal_memory-168">
      [168]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    In short, most neural networks use some form of
    <a href="/wiki/Gradient_descent" title="Gradient descent">
     gradient descent
    </a>
    on a hand-created neural topology. However, some research groups, such as
    <a href="/wiki/Uber" title="Uber">
     Uber
    </a>
    , argue that simple
    <a href="/wiki/Neuroevolution" title="Neuroevolution">
     neuroevolution
    </a>
    to mutate new neural network topologies and weights may be competitive with sophisticated gradient descent approaches. One advantage of neuroevolution is that it may be less prone to get caught in "dead ends".
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169">
     <a href="#cite_note-169">
      [169]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h4>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Deep_feedforward_neural_networks">
     Deep feedforward neural networks
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Deep feedforward neural networks">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h4>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a href="/wiki/Deep_learning" title="Deep learning">
     Deep learning
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    <a href="/wiki/Deep_learning" title="Deep learning">
     Deep learning
    </a>
    is any
    <a href="/wiki/Artificial_neural_network" title="Artificial neural network">
     artificial neural network
    </a>
    that can learn a long chain of causal links. For example, a feedforward network with six hidden layers can learn a seven-link causal chain (six hidden layers + output layer) and has a
    <a href="/wiki/Deep_learning#Credit_assignment" title="Deep learning">
     "credit assignment path"
    </a>
    (CAP) depth of seven. Many deep learning systems need to be able to learn chains ten or more causal links in length.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-schmidhuber2015_170-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-schmidhuber2015-170">
      [170]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Deep learning has transformed many important subfields of artificial intelligence, including
    <a href="/wiki/Computer_vision" title="Computer vision">
     computer vision
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Speech_recognition" title="Speech recognition">
     speech recognition
    </a>
    ,
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Natural_language_processing" title="Natural language processing">
     natural language processing
    </a>
    and others.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-goodfellow2016_171-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-goodfellow2016-171">
      [171]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HintonDengYu2012_172-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-HintonDengYu2012-172">
      [172]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-schmidhuber2015_170-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-schmidhuber2015-170">
      [170]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    According to one overview,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-scholarpedia_173-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-scholarpedia-173">
      [173]
     </a>
    </sup>
    the expression "Deep Learning" was introduced to the
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Machine_Learning" title="Machine Learning">
     Machine Learning
    </a>
    community by
    <a href="/wiki/Rina_Dechter" title="Rina Dechter">
     Rina Dechter
    </a>
    in 1986
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dechter1986_174-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-dechter1986-174">
      [174]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and gained traction after Igor Aizenberg and colleagues introduced it to
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Artificial_Neural_Networks" title="Artificial Neural Networks">
     Artificial Neural Networks
    </a>
    in 2000.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aizenberg2000_175-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-aizenberg2000-175">
      [175]
     </a>
    </sup>
    The first functional Deep Learning networks were published by
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alexey_Grigorevich_Ivakhnenko" title="Alexey Grigorevich Ivakhnenko">
     Alexey Grigorevich Ivakhnenko
    </a>
    and V. G. Lapa in 1965.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176">
     <a href="#cite_note-176">
      [176]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
     [
     <i>
      <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">
       <span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific page or range of pages in which the material appears. (December 2016)">
        page needed
       </span>
      </a>
     </i>
     ]
    </sup>
    These networks are trained one layer at a time. Ivakhnenko's 1971 paper
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ivak1971_177-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-ivak1971-177">
      [177]
     </a>
    </sup>
    describes the learning of a deep feedforward multilayer perceptron with eight layers, already much deeper than many later networks. In 2006, a publication by
    <a href="/wiki/Geoffrey_Hinton" title="Geoffrey Hinton">
     Geoffrey Hinton
    </a>
    and Ruslan Salakhutdinov introduced another way of pre-training many-layered
    <a href="/wiki/Feedforward_neural_network" title="Feedforward neural network">
     feedforward neural networks
    </a>
    (FNNs) one layer at a time, treating each layer in turn as an
    <a href="/wiki/Unsupervised_learning" title="Unsupervised learning">
     unsupervised
    </a>
    <a href="/wiki/Restricted_Boltzmann_machine" title="Restricted Boltzmann machine">
     restricted Boltzmann machine
    </a>
    , then using
    <a href="/wiki/Supervised_learning" title="Supervised learning">
     supervised
    </a>
    <a href="/wiki/Backpropagation" title="Backpropagation">
     backpropagation
    </a>
    for fine-tuning.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHinton2007_178-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHinton2007-178">
      [178]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Similar to shallow artificial neural networks, deep neural networks can model complex non-linear relationships. Over the last few years, advances in both machine learning algorithms and computer hardware have led to more efficient methods for training deep neural networks that contain many layers of non-linear hidden units and a very large output layer.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179">
     <a href="#cite_note-179">
      [179]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Deep learning often uses
    <a href="/wiki/Convolutional_neural_network" title="Convolutional neural network">
     convolutional neural networks
    </a>
    (CNNs), whose origins can be traced back to the
    <a href="/wiki/Neocognitron" title="Neocognitron">
     Neocognitron
    </a>
    introduced by
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kunihiko_Fukushima" title="Kunihiko Fukushima">
     Kunihiko Fukushima
    </a>
    in 1980.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FUKU1980_180-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-FUKU1980-180">
      [180]
     </a>
    </sup>
    In 1989,
    <a href="/wiki/Yann_LeCun" title="Yann LeCun">
     Yann LeCun
    </a>
    and colleagues applied
    <a href="/wiki/Backpropagation" title="Backpropagation">
     backpropagation
    </a>
    to such an architecture. In the early 2000s, in an industrial application CNNs already processed an estimated 10% to 20% of all the checks written in the US.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lecun2016slides_181-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-lecun2016slides-181">
      [181]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Since 2011, fast implementations of CNNs on GPUs have won many visual pattern recognition competitions.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-schmidhuber2015_170-2">
     <a href="#cite_note-schmidhuber2015-170">
      [170]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    CNNs with 12 convolutional layers were used in conjunction with
    <a href="/wiki/Reinforcement_learning" title="Reinforcement learning">
     reinforcement learning
    </a>
    by Deepmind's "
    <a href="/wiki/AlphaGo" title="AlphaGo">
     AlphaGo
    </a>
    Lee", the program that beat a top
    <a href="/wiki/Go_(game)" title="Go (game)">
     Go
    </a>
    champion in 2016.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nature2017_182-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Nature2017-182">
      [182]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h4>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Deep_recurrent_neural_networks">
     Deep recurrent neural networks
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: Deep recurrent neural networks">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h4>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Recurrent_neural_networks" title="Recurrent neural networks">
     Recurrent neural networks
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    Early on, deep learning was also applied to sequence learning with
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Recurrent_neural_networks" title="Recurrent neural networks">
     recurrent neural networks
    </a>
    (RNNs)
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Recurrent_neural_networks_183-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Recurrent_neural_networks-183">
      [183]
     </a>
    </sup>
    which are in theory Turing complete
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184">
     <a href="#cite_note-184">
      [184]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and can run arbitrary programs to process arbitrary sequences of inputs. The depth of an RNN is unlimited and depends on the length of its input sequence; thus, an RNN is an example of deep learning.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-schmidhuber2015_170-3">
     <a href="#cite_note-schmidhuber2015-170">
      [170]
     </a>
    </sup>
    RNNs can be trained by
    <a href="/wiki/Gradient_descent" title="Gradient descent">
     gradient descent
    </a>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185">
     <a href="#cite_note-185">
      [185]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186">
     <a href="#cite_note-186">
      [186]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187">
     <a href="#cite_note-187">
      [187]
     </a>
    </sup>
    but suffer from the
    <a href="/wiki/Vanishing_gradient_problem" title="Vanishing gradient problem">
     vanishing gradient problem
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-goodfellow2016_171-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-goodfellow2016-171">
      [171]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hochreiter1991_188-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-hochreiter1991-188">
      [188]
     </a>
    </sup>
    In 1992, it was shown that unsupervised pre-training of a stack of
    <a href="/wiki/Recurrent_neural_network" title="Recurrent neural network">
     recurrent neural networks
    </a>
    can speed up subsequent supervised learning of deep sequential problems.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SCHMID1992_189-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-SCHMID1992-189">
      [189]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Numerous researchers now use variants of a deep learning recurrent NN called the
    <a href="/wiki/Long_short-term_memory" title="Long short-term memory">
     long short-term memory
    </a>
    (LSTM) network published by Hochreiter &amp; Schmidhuber in 1997.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lstm_190-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-lstm-190">
      [190]
     </a>
    </sup>
    LSTM is often trained by Connectionist Temporal Classification (CTC).
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-graves2006_191-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-graves2006-191">
      [191]
     </a>
    </sup>
    At Google, Microsoft and Baidu this approach has revolutionised
    <a href="/wiki/Speech_recognition" title="Speech recognition">
     speech recognition
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hannun2014_192-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-hannun2014-192">
      [192]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sak2014_193-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-sak2014-193">
      [193]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-liwu2015_194-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-liwu2015-194">
      [194]
     </a>
    </sup>
    For example, in 2015, Google's speech recognition experienced a dramatic performance jump of 49% through CTC-trained LSTM, which is now available through
    <a href="/wiki/Google_Voice" title="Google Voice">
     Google Voice
    </a>
    to billions of smartphone users.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sak2015_195-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-sak2015-195">
      [195]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Google also used LSTM to improve machine translation,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sutskever2014_196-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-sutskever2014-196">
      [196]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Language Modeling
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vinyals2016_197-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-vinyals2016-197">
      [197]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and Multilingual Language Processing.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gillick2015_198-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-gillick2015-198">
      [198]
     </a>
    </sup>
    LSTM combined with CNNs also improved automatic image captioning
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vinyals2015_199-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-vinyals2015-199">
      [199]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and a plethora of other applications.
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Control_theory">
     Control theory
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=33" title="Edit section: Control theory">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a href="/wiki/Intelligent_control" title="Intelligent control">
     Intelligent control
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    <a href="/wiki/Control_theory" title="Control theory">
     Control theory
    </a>
    , the grandchild of
    <a href="/wiki/Cybernetics" title="Cybernetics">
     cybernetics
    </a>
    , has many important applications, especially in
    <a href="/wiki/Robotics" title="Robotics">
     robotics
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Control_theory_200-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Control_theory-200">
      [200]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">
     Languages
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: Languages">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a href="/wiki/List_of_programming_languages_for_artificial_intelligence" title="List of programming languages for artificial intelligence">
     List of programming languages for artificial intelligence
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    AI researchers have developed several specialized languages for AI research, including
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lisp_programming_language" title="Lisp programming language">
     Lisp
    </a>
    ,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lisp_201-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Lisp-201">
      [201]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <a href="/wiki/Prolog" title="Prolog">
     Prolog
    </a>
    ,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Prolog_202-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Prolog-202">
      [202]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <a href="/wiki/Python_(programming_language)" title="Python (programming language)">
     Python
    </a>
    ,
    <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
     [
     <i>
      <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
       <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2017)">
        citation needed
       </span>
      </a>
     </i>
     ]
    </sup>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/C%2B%2B" title="C++">
     C++
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-C++_203-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-C++-203">
      [203]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Evaluating_progress">
     Evaluating progress
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: Evaluating progress">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a href="/wiki/Progress_in_artificial_intelligence" title="Progress in artificial intelligence">
     Progress in artificial intelligence
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    In 1950,
    <a href="/wiki/Alan_Turing" title="Alan Turing">
     Alan Turing
    </a>
    proposed a general procedure to test the intelligence of an agent now known as the
    <a href="/wiki/Turing_test" title="Turing test">
     Turing test
    </a>
    . This procedure allows almost all the major problems of artificial intelligence to be tested. However, it is a very difficult challenge and at present all agents fail.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Turing_test_204-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Turing_test-204">
      [204]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Artificial intelligence can also be evaluated on specific problems such as small problems in chemistry, hand-writing recognition and game-playing. Such tests have been termed
    <a href="/wiki/Subject_matter_expert_Turing_test" title="Subject matter expert Turing test">
     subject matter expert Turing tests
    </a>
    . Smaller problems provide more achievable goals and there are an ever-increasing number of positive results.
    <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
     [
     <i>
      <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
       <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2017)">
        citation needed
       </span>
      </a>
     </i>
     ]
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    For example, performance at
    <a href="/wiki/Draughts" title="Draughts">
     draughts
    </a>
    (i.e. checkers) is optimal,
    <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
     [
     <i>
      <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
       <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2017)">
        citation needed
       </span>
      </a>
     </i>
     ]
    </sup>
    performance at chess is high-human and nearing super-human (see
    <a href="/wiki/Computer_chess#Computers_versus_humans" title="Computer chess">
     computer chess: computers versus human
    </a>
    ) and performance at many everyday tasks (such as recognizing a face or crossing a room without bumping into something) is sub-human.
   </p>
   <p>
    A quite different approach measures machine intelligence through tests which are developed from
    <i>
     mathematical
    </i>
    definitions of intelligence. Examples of these kinds of tests start in the late nineties devising intelligence tests using notions from
    <a href="/wiki/Kolmogorov_complexity" title="Kolmogorov complexity">
     Kolmogorov complexity
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Data_compression" title="Data compression">
     data compression
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mathematical_definitions_of_intelligence_205-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Mathematical_definitions_of_intelligence-205">
      [205]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Two major advantages of mathematical definitions are their applicability to nonhuman intelligences and their absence of a requirement for human testers.
   </p>
   <p>
    A derivative of the Turing test is the Completely Automated Public Turing test to tell Computers and Humans Apart (
    <a href="/wiki/CAPTCHA" title="CAPTCHA">
     CAPTCHA
    </a>
    ). As the name implies, this helps to determine that a user is an actual person and not a computer posing as a human. In contrast to the standard Turing test, CAPTCHA is administered by a machine and targeted to a human as opposed to being administered by a human and targeted to a machine. A computer asks a user to complete a simple test then generates a grade for that test. Computers are unable to solve the problem, so correct solutions are deemed to be the result of a person taking the test. A common type of CAPTCHA is the test that requires the typing of distorted letters, numbers or symbols that appear in an image undecipherable by a computer.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEO'BrienMarakas2011_206-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEO'BrienMarakas2011-206">
      [206]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h2>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Applications">
     Applications
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=36" title="Edit section: Applications">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="thumb tright">
    <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
     <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Automated_online_assistant.png">
      <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="501" data-file-width="400" height="276" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Automated_online_assistant.png/220px-Automated_online_assistant.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Automated_online_assistant.png/330px-Automated_online_assistant.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/8b/Automated_online_assistant.png 2x" width="220"/>
     </a>
     <div class="thumbcaption">
      <div class="magnify">
       <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Automated_online_assistant.png" title="Enlarge">
       </a>
      </div>
      An
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Automated_online_assistant" title="Automated online assistant">
       automated online assistant
      </a>
      providing customer service on a web page – one of many very primitive applications of artificial intelligence.
     </div>
    </div>
   </div>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a href="/wiki/Applications_of_artificial_intelligence" title="Applications of artificial intelligence">
     Applications of artificial intelligence
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    AI is relevant to any intellectual task.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERussellNorvig20091_207-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERussellNorvig20091-207">
      [207]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Modern artificial intelligence techniques are pervasive and are too numerous to list here. Frequently, when a technique reaches mainstream use, it is no longer considered artificial intelligence; this phenomenon is described as the
    <a href="/wiki/AI_effect" title="AI effect">
     AI effect
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''CNN''2006_208-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''CNN''2006-208">
      [208]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    High-profile examples of AI include autonomous vehicles (such as
    <a href="/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle" title="Unmanned aerial vehicle">
     drones
    </a>
    and
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Self-driving_cars" title="Self-driving cars">
     self-driving cars
    </a>
    ), medical diagnosis, creating art (such as poetry), proving mathematical theorems, playing games (such as Chess or Go), search engines (such as
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Google_search" title="Google search">
     Google search
    </a>
    ), online assistants (such as
    <a href="/wiki/Siri" title="Siri">
     Siri
    </a>
    ), image recognition in photographs, spam filtering, prediction of judicial decisions
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ecthr2016_209-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-ecthr2016-209">
      [209]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and targeting online advertisements.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERussellNorvig20091_207-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERussellNorvig20091-207">
      [207]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210">
     <a href="#cite_note-210">
      [210]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211">
     <a href="#cite_note-211">
      [211]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    With social media sites overtaking TV as a source for news for young people and news organisations increasingly reliant on social media platforms for generating distribution,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212">
     <a href="#cite_note-212">
      [212]
     </a>
    </sup>
    major publishers now use artificial intelligence (AI) technology to post stories more effectively and generate higher volumes of traffic.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213">
     <a href="#cite_note-213">
      [213]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Competitions_and_prizes">
     Competitions and prizes
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=37" title="Edit section: Competitions and prizes">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a href="/wiki/Competitions_and_prizes_in_artificial_intelligence" title="Competitions and prizes in artificial intelligence">
     Competitions and prizes in artificial intelligence
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    There are a number of competitions and prizes to promote research in artificial intelligence. The main areas promoted are: general machine intelligence, conversational behavior, data-mining,
    <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_car" title="Autonomous car">
     robotic cars
    </a>
    , robot soccer and games.
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Healthcare">
     Healthcare
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=38" title="Edit section: Healthcare">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a href="/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_in_healthcare" title="Artificial intelligence in healthcare">
     Artificial intelligence in healthcare
    </a>
   </div>
   <div class="thumb tright">
    <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
     <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Laproscopic_Surgery_Robot.jpg">
      <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1296" data-file-width="891" height="320" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Laproscopic_Surgery_Robot.jpg/220px-Laproscopic_Surgery_Robot.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Laproscopic_Surgery_Robot.jpg/330px-Laproscopic_Surgery_Robot.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Laproscopic_Surgery_Robot.jpg/440px-Laproscopic_Surgery_Robot.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
     </a>
     <div class="thumbcaption">
      <div class="magnify">
       <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Laproscopic_Surgery_Robot.jpg" title="Enlarge">
       </a>
      </div>
      A patient side surgical arm of
      <a href="/wiki/Da_Vinci_Surgical_System" title="Da Vinci Surgical System">
       Da Vinci Surgical System
      </a>
      .
      <a class="external autonumber" href="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Laproscopic_Surgery_Robot.jpg">
       [2]
      </a>
     </div>
    </div>
   </div>
   <div class="thumb tright">
    <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
     <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:X-ray_of_a_hand_with_automatic_bone_age_calculation.jpg">
      <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1827" data-file-width="1303" height="308" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/X-ray_of_a_hand_with_automatic_bone_age_calculation.jpg/220px-X-ray_of_a_hand_with_automatic_bone_age_calculation.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/X-ray_of_a_hand_with_automatic_bone_age_calculation.jpg/330px-X-ray_of_a_hand_with_automatic_bone_age_calculation.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/X-ray_of_a_hand_with_automatic_bone_age_calculation.jpg/440px-X-ray_of_a_hand_with_automatic_bone_age_calculation.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
     </a>
     <div class="thumbcaption">
      <div class="magnify">
       <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:X-ray_of_a_hand_with_automatic_bone_age_calculation.jpg" title="Enlarge">
       </a>
      </div>
      <a href="/wiki/Projectional_radiography" title="Projectional radiography">
       X-ray
      </a>
      of a hand, with automatic calculation of
      <a href="/wiki/Bone_age" title="Bone age">
       bone age
      </a>
      by a computer software.
     </div>
    </div>
   </div>
   <p>
    Artificial intelligence is breaking into the healthcare industry by assisting doctors. According to Bloomberg Technology, Microsoft has developed AI to help doctors find the right treatments for cancer.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214">
     <a href="#cite_note-214">
      [214]
     </a>
    </sup>
    There is a great amount of research and drugs developed relating to cancer. In detail, there are more than 800 medicines and vaccines to treat cancer. This negatively affects the doctors, because there are too many options to choose from, making it more difficult to choose the right drugs for the patients. Microsoft is working on a project to develop a machine called "Hanover". Its goal is to memorize all the papers necessary to cancer and help predict which combinations of drugs will be most effective for each patient. One project that is being worked on at the moment is fighting
    <a href="/wiki/Acute_myeloid_leukemia" title="Acute myeloid leukemia">
     myeloid leukemia
    </a>
    , a fatal cancer where the treatment has not improved in decades. Another study was reported to have found that artificial intelligence was as good as trained doctors in identifying skin cancers.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215">
     <a href="#cite_note-215">
      [215]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Another study is using artificial intelligence to try and monitor multiple high-risk patients, and this is done by asking each patient numerous questions based on data acquired from live doctor to patient interactions.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216">
     <a href="#cite_note-216">
      [216]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    According to
    <a href="/wiki/CNN" title="CNN">
     CNN
    </a>
    , there was a recent study by surgeons at the Children's National Medical Center in Washington which successfully demonstrated surgery with an autonomous robot. The team supervised the robot while it performed soft-tissue surgery, stitching together a pig's bowel during open surgery, and doing so better than a human surgeon, the team claimed.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217">
     <a href="#cite_note-217">
      [217]
     </a>
    </sup>
    IBM has created its own artificial intelligence computer, the
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IBM_Watson" title="IBM Watson">
     IBM Watson
    </a>
    , which has beaten human intelligence (at some levels). Watson not only won at the game show
    <i>
     Jeopardy!
    </i>
    against former champions,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218">
     <a href="#cite_note-218">
      [218]
     </a>
    </sup>
    but, was declared a hero after successfully diagnosing a women who was suffering from leukemia.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219">
     <a href="#cite_note-219">
      [219]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Automotive">
     Automotive
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=39" title="Edit section: Automotive">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <p>
    Advancements in AI have contributed to the growth of the automotive industry through the creation and evolution of self-driving vehicles. As of 2016, there are over 30 companies utilizing AI into the creation of
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Driverless_cars" title="Driverless cars">
     driverless cars
    </a>
    . A few companies involved with AI include
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tesla_Motors" title="Tesla Motors">
     Tesla
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">
     Google
    </a>
    , and
    <a href="/wiki/Apple_Inc." title="Apple Inc.">
     Apple
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220">
     <a href="#cite_note-220">
      [220]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Many components contribute to the functioning of self-driving cars. These vehicles incorporate systems such as braking, lane changing, collision prevention, navigation and mapping. Together, these systems, as well as high performance computers, are integrated into one complex vehicle.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221">
     <a href="#cite_note-221">
      [221]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Recent developments in autonomous automobiles have made the innovation of self-driving trucks possible, though they are still in the testing phase. The UK government has passed legislation to begin testing of self-driving truck platoons in 2018.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222">
     <a href="#cite_note-222">
      [222]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Self-driving truck platoons are a fleet of self-driving trucks following the lead of one non-self-driving truck, so the truck platoons aren't entirely autonomous yet. Meanwhile, the Daimler, a German automobile corporation, is testing the Freightliner Inspiration which is a semi-autonomous truck that will only be used on the highway.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223">
     <a href="#cite_note-223">
      [223]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    One main factor that influences the ability for a driver-less automobile to function is mapping. In general, the vehicle would be pre-programmed with a map of the area being driven. This map would include data on the approximations of street light and curb heights in order for the vehicle to be aware of its surroundings. However, Google has been working on an algorithm with the purpose of eliminating the need for pre-programmed maps and instead, creating a device that would be able to adjust to a variety of new surroundings.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224">
     <a href="#cite_note-224">
      [224]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Some self-driving cars are not equipped with steering wheels or brake pedals, so there has also been research focused on creating an algorithm that is capable of maintaining a safe environment for the passengers in the vehicle through awareness of speed and driving conditions.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225">
     <a href="#cite_note-225">
      [225]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Another factor that is influencing the ability for a driver-less automobile is the safety of the passenger. To make a driver-less automobile, engineers must program it to handle high risk situations. These situations could include a head on collision with pedestrians. The car's main goal should be to make a decision that would avoid hitting the pedestrians and saving the passengers in the car. But there is a possibility the car would need to make a decision that would put someone in danger. In other words, the car would need to decide to save the pedestrians or the passengers.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226">
     <a href="#cite_note-226">
      [226]
     </a>
    </sup>
    The programing of the car in these situations is crucial to a successful driver-less automobile.
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Finance_and_Economics">
     Finance and Economics
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=40" title="Edit section: Finance and Economics">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <p>
    <a href="/wiki/Financial_institution" title="Financial institution">
     Financial institutions
    </a>
    have long used
    <a href="/wiki/Artificial_neural_network" title="Artificial neural network">
     artificial neural network
    </a>
    systems to detect charges or claims outside of the norm, flagging these for human investigation. The use of AI in
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Banking" title="Banking">
     banking
    </a>
    can be traced back to 1987 when
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Security_Pacific_National_Bank" title="Security Pacific National Bank">
     Security Pacific National Bank
    </a>
    in USA set-up a Fraud Prevention Task force to counter the unauthorised use of debit cards. Programs like Kasisto and Moneystream are using AI in financial services.
   </p>
   <p>
    Banks use artificial intelligence systems today to organize operations, maintain book-keeping, invest in stocks, and manage properties. AI can react to changes overnight or when business is not taking place.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Eleanor_227-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Eleanor-227">
      [227]
     </a>
    </sup>
    In August 2001, robots beat humans in a simulated
    <a href="/wiki/Stock_trader" title="Stock trader">
     financial trading
    </a>
    competition.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228">
     <a href="#cite_note-228">
      [228]
     </a>
    </sup>
    AI has also reduced fraud and financial crimes by monitoring
    <a href="/wiki/Behavioral_pattern" title="Behavioral pattern">
     behavioral patterns
    </a>
    of users for any abnormal changes or anomalies.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fsroundtable.org_229-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-fsroundtable.org-229">
      [229]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    The use of AI machines in the market in applications such as online trading and decision making has changed major economic theories.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230">
     <a href="#cite_note-230">
      [230]
     </a>
    </sup>
    For example, AI based buying and selling platforms have changed the law of
    <a href="/wiki/Supply_and_demand" title="Supply and demand">
     supply and demand
    </a>
    in that it is now possible to easily estimate individualized demand and supply curves and thus individualized pricing. Furthermore, AI machines reduce
    <a href="/wiki/Information_asymmetry" title="Information asymmetry">
     information asymmetry
    </a>
    in the market and thus making markets more efficient while reducing the volume of trades. Furthermore, AI in the markets limits the consequences of behavior in the markets again making markets more efficient. Other theories where AI has had impact include in
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rational_choice" title="Rational choice">
     rational choice
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Rational_expectations" title="Rational expectations">
     rational expectations
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Game_theory" title="Game theory">
     game theory
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Lewis_turning_point" title="Lewis turning point">
     Lewis turning point
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Portfolio_optimization" title="Portfolio optimization">
     portfolio optimization
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Counterfactual_thinking" title="Counterfactual thinking">
     counterfactual thinking
    </a>
    .
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Video_games">
     Video games
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=41" title="Edit section: Video games">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a href="/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_(video_games)" title="Artificial intelligence (video games)">
     Artificial intelligence (video games)
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    In video games, artificial intelligence is routinely used to generate dynamic purposeful behavior in
    <a href="/wiki/Non-player_character" title="Non-player character">
     non-player characters
    </a>
    (NPCs). In addition, well-understood AI techniques are routinely used for
    <a href="/wiki/Pathfinding" title="Pathfinding">
     pathfinding
    </a>
    . Some researchers consider NPC AI in games to be a "solved problem" for most production tasks. Games with more atypical AI include the AI director of
    <a href="/wiki/Left_4_Dead" title="Left 4 Dead">
     Left 4 Dead
    </a>
    (2008) and the neuroevolutionary training of platoons in
    <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Commander_2" title="Supreme Commander 2">
     Supreme Commander 2
    </a>
    (2010).
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231">
     <a href="#cite_note-231">
      [231]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232">
     <a href="#cite_note-232">
      [232]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h2>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Platforms">
     Platforms
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=42" title="Edit section: Platforms">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h2>
   <p>
    A
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Platform_(computing)" title="Platform (computing)">
     platform
    </a>
    (or "
    <a href="/wiki/Computing_platform" title="Computing platform">
     computing platform
    </a>
    ") is defined as "some sort of hardware architecture or software framework (including application frameworks), that allows software to run". As Rodney Brooks pointed out many years ago,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrooks1991_233-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrooks1991-233">
      [233]
     </a>
    </sup>
    it is not just the artificial intelligence software that defines the AI features of the platform, but rather the actual platform itself that affects the AI that results, i.e., there needs to be work in AI problems on real-world platforms rather than in isolation.
   </p>
   <p>
    A wide variety of platforms has allowed different aspects of AI to develop, ranging from
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Expert_systems" title="Expert systems">
     expert systems
    </a>
    such as
    <a href="/wiki/Cyc" title="Cyc">
     Cyc
    </a>
    to
    <a href="/wiki/Deep_learning#Software_libraries" title="Deep learning">
     deep-learning frameworks
    </a>
    to robot platforms such as the
    <a href="/wiki/Roomba" title="Roomba">
     Roomba
    </a>
    with open interface.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234">
     <a href="#cite_note-234">
      [234]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Recent advances in deep
    <a href="/wiki/Artificial_neural_network" title="Artificial neural network">
     artificial neural networks
    </a>
    and distributed computing have led to a proliferation of software libraries, including
    <a href="/wiki/Deeplearning4j" title="Deeplearning4j">
     Deeplearning4j
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/TensorFlow" title="TensorFlow">
     TensorFlow
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Theano_(software)" title="Theano (software)">
     Theano
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Torch_(machine_learning)" title="Torch (machine learning)">
     Torch
    </a>
    .
   </p>
   <p>
    Collective AI is a platform architecture that combines individual AI into a collective entity, in order to achieve global results from individual behaviors.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235">
     <a href="#cite_note-235">
      [235]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vice.com_236-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-vice.com-236">
      [236]
     </a>
    </sup>
    With its collective structure, developers can crowdsource information and extend the functionality of existing AI domains on the platform for their own use, as well as continue to create and share new domains and capabilities for the wider community and greater good.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237">
     <a href="#cite_note-237">
      [237]
     </a>
    </sup>
    As developers continue to contribute, the overall platform grows more intelligent and is able to perform more requests, providing a scalable model for greater communal benefit.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vice.com_236-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-vice.com-236">
      [236]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Organizations like
    <a href="/wiki/SoundHound" title="SoundHound">
     SoundHound
    </a>
    Inc. and the
    <a href="/wiki/Harvard_John_A._Paulson_School_of_Engineering_and_Applied_Sciences" title="Harvard John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences">
     Harvard John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences
    </a>
    have used this collaborative AI model.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238">
     <a href="#cite_note-238">
      [238]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vice.com_236-2">
     <a href="#cite_note-vice.com-236">
      [236]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Education_in_AI">
     Education in AI
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=43" title="Edit section: Education in AI">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <p>
    A
    <a href="/wiki/McKinsey_%26_Company" title="McKinsey &amp; Company">
     McKinsey Global Institute
    </a>
    study found a shortage of 1.5 million highly trained data and AI professionals and managers
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McKinsey_239-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-McKinsey-239">
      [239]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and a number of private bootcamps have developed programs to meet that demand, including free programs like
    <a href="/wiki/The_Data_Incubator" title="The Data Incubator">
     The Data Incubator
    </a>
    or paid programs like
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/General_Assembly" title="General Assembly">
     General Assembly
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240">
     <a href="#cite_note-240">
      [240]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Partnership_on_AI">
     Partnership on AI
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=44" title="Edit section: Partnership on AI">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <p>
    Amazon, Google, Facebook, IBM, and Microsoft have established a non-profit partnership to formulate best practices on artificial intelligence technologies, advance the public's understanding, and to serve as a platform about artificial intelligence.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_241-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-:1-241">
      [241]
     </a>
    </sup>
    They stated: "This partnership on AI will conduct research, organize discussions, provide thought leadership, consult with relevant third parties, respond to questions from the public and media, and create educational material that advance the understanding of AI technologies including machine perception, learning, and automated reasoning."
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_241-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-:1-241">
      [241]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Apple joined other tech companies as a founding member of the Partnership on AI in January 2017. The corporate members will make financial and research contributions to the group, while engaging with the scientific community to bring academics onto the board.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242">
     <a href="#cite_note-242">
      [242]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vice.com_236-3">
     <a href="#cite_note-vice.com-236">
      [236]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h2>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Philosophy_and_ethics">
     Philosophy and ethics
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=45" title="Edit section: Philosophy and ethics">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main articles:
    <a href="/wiki/Philosophy_of_artificial_intelligence" title="Philosophy of artificial intelligence">
     Philosophy of artificial intelligence
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Ethics_of_artificial_intelligence" title="Ethics of artificial intelligence">
     Ethics of artificial intelligence
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    There are three philosophical questions related to AI:
   </p>
   <ol>
    <li>
     Is
     <a href="/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence" title="Artificial general intelligence">
      artificial general intelligence
     </a>
     possible? Can a machine solve any problem that a human being can solve using intelligence? Or are there hard limits to what a machine can accomplish?
    </li>
    <li>
     Are intelligent machines dangerous? How can we ensure that machines behave ethically and that they are used ethically?
    </li>
    <li>
     Can a machine have a
     <a href="/wiki/Mind" title="Mind">
      mind
     </a>
     ,
     <a href="/wiki/Consciousness" title="Consciousness">
      consciousness
     </a>
     and
     <a href="/wiki/Philosophy_of_mind" title="Philosophy of mind">
      mental states
     </a>
     in exactly the same sense that human beings do? Can a machine be
     <a href="/wiki/Sentience" title="Sentience">
      sentient
     </a>
     , and thus deserve certain rights? Can a machine
     <a href="/wiki/Intention" title="Intention">
      intentionally
     </a>
     cause harm?
    </li>
   </ol>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="The_limits_of_artificial_general_intelligence">
     The limits of artificial general intelligence
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=46" title="Edit section: The limits of artificial general intelligence">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main articles:
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Philosophy_of_AI" title="Philosophy of AI">
     Philosophy of AI
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Turing_test" title="Turing test">
     Turing test
    </a>
    ,
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Physical_symbol_systems_hypothesis" title="Physical symbol systems hypothesis">
     Physical symbol systems hypothesis
    </a>
    ,
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dreyfus%27_critique_of_AI" title="Dreyfus' critique of AI">
     Dreyfus' critique of AI
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/The_Emperor%27s_New_Mind" title="The Emperor's New Mind">
     The Emperor's New Mind
    </a>
    , and
    <a href="/wiki/AI_effect" title="AI effect">
     AI effect
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    Can a machine be intelligent? Can it "think"?
   </p>
   <dl>
    <dt>
     <i>
      <a href="/wiki/Computing_Machinery_and_Intelligence" title="Computing Machinery and Intelligence">
       Alan Turing's "polite convention"
      </a>
     </i>
    </dt>
    <dd>
     We need not decide if a machine can "think"; we need only decide if a machine can act as intelligently as a human being. This approach to the philosophical problems associated with artificial intelligence forms the basis of the
     <a href="/wiki/Turing_test" title="Turing test">
      Turing test
     </a>
     .
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Turing_test_204-1">
      <a href="#cite_note-Turing_test-204">
       [204]
      </a>
     </sup>
    </dd>
   </dl>
   <dl>
    <dt>
     <i>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dartmouth_Workshop" title="Dartmouth Workshop">
       Dartmouth proposal
      </a>
     </i>
    </dt>
    <dd>
     "Every aspect of learning or any other feature of intelligence can be so precisely described that a machine can be made to simulate it." This conjecture was printed in the proposal for the Dartmouth Conference of 1956, and represents the position of most working AI researchers.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dartmouth_proposal_243-0">
      <a href="#cite_note-Dartmouth_proposal-243">
       [243]
      </a>
     </sup>
    </dd>
   </dl>
   <dl>
    <dt>
     <i>
      <a href="/wiki/Physical_symbol_system" title="Physical symbol system">
       Newell and Simon's physical symbol system hypothesis
      </a>
     </i>
    </dt>
    <dd>
     "A physical symbol system has the necessary and sufficient means of general intelligent action." Newell and Simon argue that intelligence consists of formal operations on symbols.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Physical_symbol_system_hypothesis_244-0">
      <a href="#cite_note-Physical_symbol_system_hypothesis-244">
       [244]
      </a>
     </sup>
     <a href="/wiki/Hubert_Dreyfus" title="Hubert Dreyfus">
      Hubert Dreyfus
     </a>
     argued that, on the contrary, human expertise depends on unconscious instinct rather than conscious symbol manipulation and on having a "feel" for the situation rather than explicit symbolic knowledge. (See
     <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dreyfus%27_critique_of_AI" title="Dreyfus' critique of AI">
      Dreyfus' critique of AI
     </a>
     .)
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245">
      <a href="#cite_note-245">
       [245]
      </a>
     </sup>
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dreyfus'_critique_246-0">
      <a href="#cite_note-Dreyfus'_critique-246">
       [246]
      </a>
     </sup>
    </dd>
   </dl>
   <dl>
    <dt>
     <i>
      Gödelian arguments
     </i>
    </dt>
    <dd>
     <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G%C3%B6del" title="Gödel">
      Gödel
     </a>
     himself,
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gödel_himself_247-0">
      <a href="#cite_note-Gödel_himself-247">
       [247]
      </a>
     </sup>
     <a href="/wiki/John_Lucas_(philosopher)" title="John Lucas (philosopher)">
      John Lucas
     </a>
     (in 1961) and
     <a href="/wiki/Roger_Penrose" title="Roger Penrose">
      Roger Penrose
     </a>
     (in a more detailed argument from 1989 onwards) made highly technical arguments that human mathematicians can consistently see the truth of their own "Gödel statements" and therefore have computational abilities beyond that of mechanical Turing machines.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_mathematical_objection_248-0">
      <a href="#cite_note-The_mathematical_objection-248">
       [248]
      </a>
     </sup>
     However, the modern consensus in the scientific and mathematical community is that these "Gödelian arguments" fail.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249">
      <a href="#cite_note-249">
       [249]
      </a>
     </sup>
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250">
      <a href="#cite_note-250">
       [250]
      </a>
     </sup>
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251">
      <a href="#cite_note-251">
       [251]
      </a>
     </sup>
    </dd>
   </dl>
   <dl>
    <dt>
     <i>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Artificial_brain" title="Artificial brain">
       artificial brain
      </a>
      argument
     </i>
    </dt>
    <dd>
     The brain can be simulated by machines and because brains are intelligent, simulated brains must also be intelligent; thus machines can be intelligent.
     <a href="/wiki/Hans_Moravec" title="Hans Moravec">
      Hans Moravec
     </a>
     ,
     <a href="/wiki/Ray_Kurzweil" title="Ray Kurzweil">
      Ray Kurzweil
     </a>
