     and others have argued that it is technologically feasible to copy the brain directly into hardware and software, and that such a simulation will be essentially identical to the original.
     <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brain_simulation_103-1">
      <a href="#cite_note-Brain_simulation-103">
       [103]
      </a>
     </sup>
    </dd>
   </dl>
   <dl>
    <dt>
     <i>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/AI_effect" title="AI effect">
       AI effect
      </a>
     </i>
    </dt>
    <dd>
     Machines are
     <i>
      already
     </i>
     intelligent, but observers have failed to recognize it. When
     <a href="/wiki/Deep_Blue_(chess_computer)" title="Deep Blue (chess computer)">
      Deep Blue
     </a>
     beat
     <a href="/wiki/Garry_Kasparov" title="Garry Kasparov">
      Garry Kasparov
     </a>
     in chess, the machine was acting intelligently. However, onlookers commonly discount the behavior of an artificial intelligence program by arguing that it is not "real" intelligence after all; thus "real" intelligence is whatever intelligent behavior people can do that machines still cannot. This is known as the AI Effect: "AI is whatever hasn't been done yet."
    </dd>
   </dl>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Potential_risks_and_moral_reasoning">
     Potential risks and moral reasoning
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=47" title="Edit section: Potential risks and moral reasoning">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <p>
    Widespread use of artificial intelligence could have unintended consequences that are dangerous or undesirable. Scientists from the
    <a href="/wiki/Future_of_Life_Institute" title="Future of Life Institute">
     Future of Life Institute
    </a>
    , among others, described some short-term research goals to see how AI influences the economy, the laws and ethics that are involved with AI and how to minimize AI security risks. In the long-term, the scientists have proposed to continue optimizing function while minimizing possible security risks that come along with new technologies.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252">
     <a href="#cite_note-252">
      [252]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Machines with intelligence have the potential to use their intelligence to make ethical decisions. Research in this area includes "machine ethics", "artificial moral agents", and the study of "malevolent vs. friendly AI".
   </p>
   <h4>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Existential_risk">
     Existential risk
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=48" title="Edit section: Existential risk">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h4>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a href="/wiki/Existential_risk_from_artificial_general_intelligence" title="Existential risk from artificial general intelligence">
     Existential risk from artificial general intelligence
    </a>
   </div>
   <blockquote class="templatequote">
    <p>
     The development of full artificial intelligence could spell the end of the human race. Once humans develop artificial intelligence, it will take off on its own and redesign itself at an ever-increasing rate. Humans, who are limited by slow biological evolution, couldn't compete and would be superseded.
    </p>
    <div class="templatequotecite">
     —
     <cite>
      <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Hawking" title="Stephen Hawking">
       Stephen Hawking
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253">
       <a href="#cite_note-253">
        [253]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </cite>
    </div>
   </blockquote>
   <p>
    A common concern about the development of artificial intelligence is the potential threat it could pose to humanity. This concern has recently gained attention after mentions by celebrities including
    <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Hawking" title="Stephen Hawking">
     Stephen Hawking
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Bill_Gates" title="Bill Gates">
     Bill Gates
    </a>
    ,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Holley_254-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Holley-254">
      [254]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Elon_Musk" title="Elon Musk">
     Elon Musk
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255">
     <a href="#cite_note-255">
      [255]
     </a>
    </sup>
    A group of prominent tech titans including
    <a href="/wiki/Peter_Thiel" title="Peter Thiel">
     Peter Thiel
    </a>
    , Amazon Web Services and Musk have committed $1billion to
    <a href="/wiki/OpenAI" title="OpenAI">
     OpenAI
    </a>
    a nonprofit company aimed at championing responsible AI development.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256">
     <a href="#cite_note-256">
      [256]
     </a>
    </sup>
    The opinion of experts within the field of artificial intelligence is mixed, with sizable fractions both concerned and unconcerned by risk from eventual superhumanly-capable AI.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257">
     <a href="#cite_note-257">
      [257]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    In his book
    <i>
     <a href="/wiki/Superintelligence:_Paths,_Dangers,_Strategies" title="Superintelligence: Paths, Dangers, Strategies">
      Superintelligence
     </a>
    </i>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Nick_Bostrom" title="Nick Bostrom">
     Nick Bostrom
    </a>
    provides an argument that artificial intelligence will pose a threat to mankind. He argues that sufficiently intelligent AI, if it chooses actions based on achieving some goal, will exhibit
    <a href="/wiki/Instrumental_convergence" title="Instrumental convergence">
     convergent
    </a>
    behavior such as acquiring resources or protecting itself from being shut down. If this AI's goals do not reflect humanity's – one example is an AI told to compute as many digits of pi as possible – it might harm humanity in order to acquire more resources or prevent itself from being shut down, ultimately to better achieve its goal.
   </p>
   <p>
    For this danger to be realized, the hypothetical AI would have to overpower or out-think all of humanity, which a minority of experts argue is a possibility far enough in the future to not be worth researching.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258">
     <a href="#cite_note-258">
      [258]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259">
     <a href="#cite_note-259">
      [259]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Other counterarguments revolve around humans being either intrinsically or convergently valuable from the perspective of an artificial intelligence.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260">
     <a href="#cite_note-260">
      [260]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Concern over risk from artificial intelligence has led to some high-profile donations and investments. In January 2015,
    <a href="/wiki/Elon_Musk" title="Elon Musk">
     Elon Musk
    </a>
    donated ten million dollars to the
    <a href="/wiki/Future_of_Life_Institute" title="Future of Life Institute">
     Future of Life Institute
    </a>
    to fund research on understanding AI decision making. The goal of the institute is to "grow wisdom with which we manage" the growing power of technology. Musk also funds companies developing artificial intelligence such as
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Google_DeepMind" title="Google DeepMind">
     Google DeepMind
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Vicarious_(company)" title="Vicarious (company)">
     Vicarious
    </a>
    to "just keep an eye on what's going on with artificial intelligence.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261">
     <a href="#cite_note-261">
      [261]
     </a>
    </sup>
    I think there is potentially a dangerous outcome there."
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262">
     <a href="#cite_note-262">
      [262]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263">
     <a href="#cite_note-263">
      [263]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Development of militarized artificial intelligence is a related concern. Currently, 50+ countries are researching battlefield robots, including the United States, China, Russia, and the United Kingdom. Many people concerned about risk from superintelligent AI also want to limit the use of artificial soldiers.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264">
     <a href="#cite_note-264">
      [264]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h4>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Devaluation_of_humanity">
     Devaluation of humanity
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=49" title="Edit section: Devaluation of humanity">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h4>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a href="/wiki/Computer_Power_and_Human_Reason" title="Computer Power and Human Reason">
     Computer Power and Human Reason
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Weizenbaum" title="Joseph Weizenbaum">
     Joseph Weizenbaum
    </a>
    wrote that AI applications cannot, by definition, successfully simulate genuine human empathy and that the use of AI technology in fields such as
    <a href="/wiki/Customer_service" title="Customer service">
     customer service
    </a>
    or
    <a href="/wiki/Psychotherapy" title="Psychotherapy">
     psychotherapy
    </a>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265">
     <a href="#cite_note-265">
      [265]
     </a>
    </sup>
    was deeply misguided. Weizenbaum was also bothered that AI researchers (and some philosophers) were willing to view the human mind as nothing more than a computer program (a position now known as
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Computationalism" title="Computationalism">
     computationalism
    </a>
    ). To Weizenbaum these points suggest that AI research devalues human life.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Weizenbaum's_critique_266-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Weizenbaum's_critique-266">
      [266]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h4>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Decrease_in_demand_for_human_labor">
     Decrease in demand for human labor
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=50" title="Edit section: Decrease in demand for human labor">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h4>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Further information:
    <a href="/wiki/Technological_unemployment#21st_century" title="Technological unemployment">
     Technological unemployment § 21st century
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    The relationship between automation and employment is complicated. While automation eliminates old jobs, it also creates new jobs through micro-economic and macro-economic effects.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267">
     <a href="#cite_note-267">
      [267]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Unlike previous waves of automation, many middle-class jobs may be eliminated by artificial intelligence;
    <i>
     <a href="/wiki/The_Economist" title="The Economist">
      The Economist
     </a>
    </i>
    states that "the worry that AI could do to white-collar jobs what steam power did to blue-collar ones during the Industrial Revolution" is "worth taking seriously".
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268">
     <a href="#cite_note-268">
      [268]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Subjective estimates of the risk vary widely; for example, Michael Osborne and
    <a href="/wiki/Carl_Benedikt_Frey" title="Carl Benedikt Frey">
     Carl Benedikt Frey
    </a>
    estimate 47% of U.S. jobs are at "high risk" of potential automation, while an OECD report classifies only 9% of U.S. jobs as "high risk".
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269">
     <a href="#cite_note-269">
      [269]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270">
     <a href="#cite_note-270">
      [270]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271">
     <a href="#cite_note-271">
      [271]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Jobs at extreme risk range from paralegals to fast food cooks, while job demand is likely to increase for care-related professions ranging from personal healthcare to the clergy.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272">
     <a href="#cite_note-272">
      [272]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Author
    <a href="/wiki/Martin_Ford_(author)" title="Martin Ford (author)">
     Martin Ford
    </a>
    and others go further and argue that a large number of jobs are routine, repetitive and (to an AI) predictable; Ford warns that these jobs may be automated in the next couple of decades, and that many of the new jobs may not be "accessible to people with average capability", even with retraining. Economists point out that in the past technology has tended to increase rather than reduce total employment, but acknowledge that "we're in uncharted territory" with AI.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-guardian_jobs_debate_21-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-guardian_jobs_debate-21">
      [21]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h4>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Artificial_moral_agents">
     Artificial moral agents
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=51" title="Edit section: Artificial moral agents">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h4>
   <p>
    This raises the issue of how ethically the machine should behave towards both humans and other AI agents. This issue was addressed by Wendell Wallach in his book titled
    <i>
     Moral Machines
    </i>
    in which he introduced the concept of
    <a href="/wiki/Moral_agency#Artificial_moral_agents" title="Moral agency">
     artificial moral agents
    </a>
    (AMA).
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273">
     <a href="#cite_note-273">
      [273]
     </a>
    </sup>
    For Wallach, AMAs have become a part of the research landscape of artificial intelligence as guided by its two central questions which he identifies as "Does Humanity Want Computers Making Moral Decisions"
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274">
     <a href="#cite_note-274">
      [274]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and "Can (Ro)bots Really Be Moral".
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275">
     <a href="#cite_note-275">
      [275]
     </a>
    </sup>
    For Wallach the question is not centered on the issue of
    <i>
     whether
    </i>
    machines can demonstrate the equivalent of moral behavior in contrast to the
    <i>
     constraints
    </i>
    which society may place on the development of AMAs.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276">
     <a href="#cite_note-276">
      [276]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h4>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Machine_ethics">
     Machine ethics
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=52" title="Edit section: Machine ethics">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h4>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a href="/wiki/Machine_ethics" title="Machine ethics">
     Machine ethics
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    The field of machine ethics is concerned with giving machines ethical principles, or a procedure for discovering a way to resolve the ethical dilemmas they might encounter, enabling them to function in an ethically responsible manner through their own ethical decision making.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_277-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-277">
      [277]
     </a>
    </sup>
    The field was delineated in the AAAI Fall 2005 Symposium on Machine Ethics: "Past research concerning the relationship between technology and ethics has largely focused on responsible and irresponsible use of technology by human beings, with a few people being interested in how human beings ought to treat machines. In all cases, only human beings have engaged in ethical reasoning. The time has come for adding an ethical dimension to at least some machines. Recognition of the ethical ramifications of behavior involving machines, as well as recent and potential developments in machine autonomy, necessitate this. In contrast to computer hacking, software property issues, privacy issues and other topics normally ascribed to computer ethics, machine ethics is concerned with the behavior of machines towards human users and other machines. Research in machine ethics is key to alleviating concerns with autonomous systems—it could be argued that the notion of autonomous machines without such a dimension is at the root of all fear concerning machine intelligence. Further, investigation of machine ethics could enable the discovery of problems with current ethical theories, advancing our thinking about Ethics."
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_278-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-278">
      [278]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Machine ethics is sometimes referred to as machine morality, computational ethics or computational morality. A variety of perspectives of this nascent field can be found in the collected edition "Machine Ethics"
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_277-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-277">
      [277]
     </a>
    </sup>
    that stems from the AAAI Fall 2005 Symposium on Machine Ethics.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_278-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-278">
      [278]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h4>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Malevolent_and_friendly_AI">
     Malevolent and friendly AI
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=53" title="Edit section: Malevolent and friendly AI">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h4>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Friendly_AI" title="Friendly AI">
     Friendly AI
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    Political scientist
    <a href="/wiki/Charles_T._Rubin" title="Charles T. Rubin">
     Charles T. Rubin
    </a>
    believes that AI can be neither designed nor guaranteed to be benevolent.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279">
     <a href="#cite_note-279">
      [279]
     </a>
    </sup>
    He argues that "any sufficiently advanced benevolence may be indistinguishable from malevolence." Humans should not assume machines or robots would treat us favorably, because there is no
    <i>
     a priori
    </i>
    reason to believe that they would be sympathetic to our system of morality, which has evolved along with our particular biology (which AIs would not share). Hyper-intelligent software may not necessarily decide to support the continued existence of humanity, and would be extremely difficult to stop. This topic has also recently begun to be discussed in academic publications as a real source of risks to civilization, humans, and planet Earth.
   </p>
   <p>
    Physicist
    <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Hawking" title="Stephen Hawking">
     Stephen Hawking
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Microsoft" title="Microsoft">
     Microsoft
    </a>
    founder
    <a href="/wiki/Bill_Gates" title="Bill Gates">
     Bill Gates
    </a>
    , and
    <a href="/wiki/SpaceX" title="SpaceX">
     SpaceX
    </a>
    founder
    <a href="/wiki/Elon_Musk" title="Elon Musk">
     Elon Musk
    </a>
    have expressed concerns about the possibility that AI could evolve to the point that humans could not control it, with Hawking theorizing that this could "
    <a href="/wiki/Global_catastrophic_risk" title="Global catastrophic risk">
     spell the end of the human race
    </a>
    ".
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280">
     <a href="#cite_note-280">
      [280]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    One proposal to deal with this is to ensure that the first generally intelligent AI is '
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Friendly_AI" title="Friendly AI">
     Friendly AI
    </a>
    ', and will then be able to control subsequently developed AIs. Some question whether this kind of check could really remain in place.
   </p>
   <p>
    Leading AI researcher
    <a href="/wiki/Rodney_Brooks" title="Rodney Brooks">
     Rodney Brooks
    </a>
    writes, "I think it is a mistake to be worrying about us developing malevolent AI anytime in the next few hundred years. I think the worry stems from a fundamental error in not distinguishing the difference between the very real recent advances in a particular aspect of AI, and the enormity and complexity of building sentient volitional intelligence."
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281">
     <a href="#cite_note-281">
      [281]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span id="Machine_consciousness.2C_sentience_and_mind">
    </span>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Machine_consciousness,_sentience_and_mind">
     Machine consciousness, sentience and mind
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=54" title="Edit section: Machine consciousness, sentience and mind">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a href="/wiki/Artificial_consciousness" title="Artificial consciousness">
     Artificial consciousness
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    If an AI system replicates all key aspects of human intelligence, will that system also be
    <a href="/wiki/Sentience" title="Sentience">
     sentient
    </a>
    – will it have a
    <a href="/wiki/Mind" title="Mind">
     mind
    </a>
    which has
    <a href="/wiki/Consciousness" title="Consciousness">
     conscious experiences
    </a>
    ? This question is closely related to the philosophical problem as to the nature of human consciousness, generally referred to as the
    <a href="/wiki/Hard_problem_of_consciousness" title="Hard problem of consciousness">
     hard problem of consciousness
    </a>
    .
   </p>
   <h4>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Consciousness">
     Consciousness
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=55" title="Edit section: Consciousness">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h4>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main articles:
    <a href="/wiki/Hard_problem_of_consciousness" title="Hard problem of consciousness">
     Hard problem of consciousness
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Theory_of_mind" title="Theory of mind">
     Theory of mind
    </a>
   </div>
   <table class="plainlinks metadata ambox mbox-small-left ambox-content" role="presentation">
    <tr>
     <td class="mbox-image">
      <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg">
       <img alt="[icon]" data-file-height="31" data-file-width="44" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/30px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/40px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 2x" width="20"/>
      </a>
     </td>
     <td class="mbox-text">
      <div class="mbox-text-span">
       <b>
        This section needs expansion
       </b>
       .
       <small>
        You can help by
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=">
         adding to it
        </a>
        .
       </small>
       <small>
        <i>
         (March 2016)
        </i>
       </small>
      </div>
     </td>
    </tr>
   </table>
   <h4>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Computationalism_and_functionalism">
     Computationalism and functionalism
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=56" title="Edit section: Computationalism and functionalism">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h4>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main articles:
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Computationalism" title="Computationalism">
     Computationalism
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Functionalism_(philosophy_of_mind)" title="Functionalism (philosophy of mind)">
     Functionalism (philosophy of mind)
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    Computationalism is the position in the
    <a href="/wiki/Philosophy_of_mind" title="Philosophy of mind">
     philosophy of mind
    </a>
    that the human mind or the human brain (or both) is an information processing system and that thinking is a form of computing.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282">
     <a href="#cite_note-282">
      [282]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Computationalism argues that the relationship between mind and body is similar or identical to the relationship between software and hardware and thus may be a solution to the
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mind-body_problem" title="Mind-body problem">
     mind-body problem
    </a>
    . This philosophical position was inspired by the work of AI researchers and cognitive scientists in the 1960s and was originally proposed by philosophers
    <a href="/wiki/Jerry_Fodor" title="Jerry Fodor">
     Jerry Fodor
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Hilary_Putnam" title="Hilary Putnam">
     Hilary Putnam
    </a>
    .
   </p>
   <h4>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Strong_AI_hypothesis">
     Strong AI hypothesis
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=57" title="Edit section: Strong AI hypothesis">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h4>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a href="/wiki/Chinese_room" title="Chinese room">
     Chinese room
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    The philosophical position that John Searle has named
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Strong_AI_hypothesis" title="Strong AI hypothesis">
     "strong AI"
    </a>
    states: "The appropriately programmed computer with the right inputs and outputs would thereby have a mind in exactly the same sense human beings have minds."
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Searle's_strong_AI_283-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Searle's_strong_AI-283">
      [283]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Searle counters this assertion with his
    <a href="/wiki/Chinese_room" title="Chinese room">
     Chinese room
    </a>
    argument, which asks us to look
    <i>
     inside
    </i>
    the computer and try to find where the "mind" might be.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chinese_room_284-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Chinese_room-284">
      [284]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h4>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Robot_rights">
     Robot rights
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=58" title="Edit section: Robot rights">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h4>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Robot_rights" title="Robot rights">
     Robot rights
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    <a href="/wiki/Mary_Shelley" title="Mary Shelley">
     Mary Shelley
    </a>
    's
    <i>
     <a href="/wiki/Frankenstein" title="Frankenstein">
      Frankenstein
     </a>
    </i>
    considers a key issue in the
    <a href="/wiki/Ethics_of_artificial_intelligence" title="Ethics of artificial intelligence">
     ethics of artificial intelligence
    </a>
    : if a machine can be created that has intelligence, could it also
    <i>
     <a href="/wiki/Sentience" title="Sentience">
      feel
     </a>
    </i>
    ? If it can feel, does it have the same rights as a human? The idea also appears in modern science fiction, such as the film
    <i>
     <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/A.I.:_Artificial_Intelligence" title="A.I.: Artificial Intelligence">
      A.I.: Artificial Intelligence
     </a>
    </i>
    , in which humanoid machines have the ability to feel emotions. This issue, now known as "
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Robot_rights" title="Robot rights">
     robot rights
    </a>
    ", is currently being considered by, for example, California's
    <a href="/wiki/Institute_for_the_Future" title="Institute for the Future">
     Institute for the Future
    </a>
    , although many critics believe that the discussion is premature.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Robot_rights_285-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Robot_rights-285">
      [285]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Some critics of
    <a href="/wiki/Transhumanism" title="Transhumanism">
     transhumanism
    </a>
    argue that any hypothetical robot rights would lie on a spectrum with
    <a href="/wiki/Animal_rights" title="Animal rights">
     animal rights
    </a>
    and human rights.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Evans_2015_286-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Evans_2015-286">
      [286]
     </a>
    </sup>
    The subject is profoundly discussed in the 2010 documentary film
    <i>
     <a href="/wiki/Plug_%26_Pray" title="Plug &amp; Pray">
      Plug &amp; Pray
     </a>
    </i>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287">
     <a href="#cite_note-287">
      [287]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Superintelligence">
     Superintelligence
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=59" title="Edit section: Superintelligence">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h3>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a href="/wiki/Superintelligence" title="Superintelligence">
     Superintelligence
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    Are there limits to how intelligent machines – or human-machine hybrids – can be? A superintelligence, hyperintelligence, or superhuman intelligence is a hypothetical agent that would possess intelligence far surpassing that of the brightest and most gifted human mind. ‘’Superintelligence’’ may also refer to the form or degree of intelligence possessed by such an agent.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Roberts_101-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-Roberts-101">
      [101]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h4>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Technological_singularity">
     Technological singularity
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=60" title="Edit section: Technological singularity">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h4>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main articles:
    <a href="/wiki/Technological_singularity" title="Technological singularity">
     Technological singularity
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Moore%27s_law" title="Moore's law">
     Moore's law
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    If research into
    <a href="/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence" title="Artificial general intelligence">
     Strong AI
    </a>
    produced sufficiently intelligent software, it might be able to reprogram and improve itself. The improved software would be even better at improving itself, leading to
    <a href="/wiki/Intelligence_explosion" title="Intelligence explosion">
     recursive self-improvement
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-recurse_288-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-recurse-288">
      [288]
     </a>
    </sup>
    The new intelligence could thus increase exponentially and dramatically surpass humans. Science fiction writer
    <a href="/wiki/Vernor_Vinge" title="Vernor Vinge">
     Vernor Vinge
    </a>
    named this scenario "
    <a href="/wiki/Technological_singularity" title="Technological singularity">
     singularity
    </a>
    ".
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Singularity_289-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Singularity-289">
      [289]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Technological singularity is when accelerating progress in technologies will cause a runaway effect wherein artificial intelligence will exceed human intellectual capacity and control, thus radically changing or even ending civilization. Because the capabilities of such an intelligence may be impossible to comprehend, the technological singularity is an occurrence beyond which events are unpredictable or even unfathomable.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Singularity_289-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-Singularity-289">
      [289]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Roberts_101-2">
     <a href="#cite_note-Roberts-101">
      [101]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    <a href="/wiki/Ray_Kurzweil" title="Ray Kurzweil">
     Ray Kurzweil
    </a>
    has used
    <a href="/wiki/Moore%27s_law" title="Moore's law">
     Moore's law
    </a>
    (which describes the relentless exponential improvement in digital technology) to calculate that
    <a href="/wiki/Desktop_computer" title="Desktop computer">
     desktop computers
    </a>
    will have the same processing power as human brains by the year 2029, and predicts that the singularity will occur in 2045.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Singularity_289-2">
     <a href="#cite_note-Singularity-289">
      [289]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h4>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Transhumanism">
     Transhumanism
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=61" title="Edit section: Transhumanism">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h4>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a href="/wiki/Transhumanism" title="Transhumanism">
     Transhumanism
    </a>
   </div>
   <blockquote class="templatequote">
    <p>
     You awake one morning to find your brain has another lobe functioning. Invisible, this auxiliary lobe answers your questions with information beyond the realm of your own memory, suggests plausible courses of action, and asks questions that help bring out relevant facts. You quickly come to rely on the new lobe so much that you stop wondering how it works. You just use it. This is the dream of artificial intelligence.
    </p>
    <div class="templatequotecite">
     —
     <cite>
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Byte_(magazine)" title="Byte (magazine)">
        Byte
       </a>
      </i>
      , April 1985
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lemmon198504_290-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-lemmon198504-290">
        [290]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </cite>
    </div>
   </blockquote>
   <p>
    Robot designer
    <a href="/wiki/Hans_Moravec" title="Hans Moravec">
     Hans Moravec
    </a>
    , cyberneticist
    <a href="/wiki/Kevin_Warwick" title="Kevin Warwick">
     Kevin Warwick
    </a>
    and inventor
    <a href="/wiki/Ray_Kurzweil" title="Ray Kurzweil">
     Ray Kurzweil
    </a>
    have predicted that humans and machines will merge in the future into
    <a href="/wiki/Cyborg" title="Cyborg">
     cyborgs
    </a>
    that are more capable and powerful than either.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Transhumanism_291-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Transhumanism-291">
      [291]
     </a>
    </sup>
    This idea, called
    <a href="/wiki/Transhumanism" title="Transhumanism">
     transhumanism
    </a>
    , which has roots in
    <a href="/wiki/Aldous_Huxley" title="Aldous Huxley">
     Aldous Huxley
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Robert_Ettinger" title="Robert Ettinger">
     Robert Ettinger
    </a>
    , has been illustrated in fiction as well, for example in the
    <a href="/wiki/Manga" title="Manga">
     manga
    </a>
    <i>
     <a href="/wiki/Ghost_in_the_Shell" title="Ghost in the Shell">
      Ghost in the Shell
     </a>
    </i>
    and the science-fiction series
    <i>
     <a href="/wiki/Dune_(novel)" title="Dune (novel)">
      Dune
     </a>
    </i>
    .
   </p>
   <p>
    In the 1980s artist
    <a href="/wiki/Hajime_Sorayama" title="Hajime Sorayama">
     Hajime Sorayama
    </a>
    's Sexy Robots series were painted and published in Japan depicting the actual organic human form with lifelike muscular metallic skins and later "the Gynoids" book followed that was used by or influenced movie makers including
    <a href="/wiki/George_Lucas" title="George Lucas">
     George Lucas
    </a>
    and other creatives. Sorayama never considered these organic robots to be real part of nature but always unnatural product of the human mind, a fantasy existing in the mind even when realized in actual form.
   </p>
   <p>
    <a href="/wiki/Edward_Fredkin" title="Edward Fredkin">
     Edward Fredkin
    </a>
    argues that "artificial intelligence is the next stage in evolution", an idea first proposed by
    <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Butler_(novelist)" title="Samuel Butler (novelist)">
     Samuel Butler
    </a>
    's "
    <a href="/wiki/Darwin_among_the_Machines" title="Darwin among the Machines">
     Darwin among the Machines
    </a>
    " (1863), and expanded upon by
    <a href="/wiki/George_Dyson_(science_historian)" title="George Dyson (science historian)">
     George Dyson
    </a>
    in his book of the same name in 1998.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AI_as_evolution_292-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-AI_as_evolution-292">
      [292]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h2>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="In_fiction">
     In fiction
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=62" title="Edit section: In fiction">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a href="/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_in_fiction" title="Artificial intelligence in fiction">
     Artificial intelligence in fiction
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    Thought-capable artificial beings appeared as storytelling devices since antiquity.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AI_in_myth_23-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-AI_in_myth-23">
      [23]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    The implications of a constructed machine exhibiting artificial intelligence have been a persistent theme in
    <a href="/wiki/Science_fiction" title="Science fiction">
     science fiction
    </a>
    since the twentieth century. Early stories typically revolved around intelligent robots. The word "robot" itself was coined by
    <a href="/wiki/Karel_%C4%8Capek" title="Karel Čapek">
     Karel Čapek
    </a>
    in his 1921 play
    <i>
     <a href="/wiki/R.U.R." title="R.U.R.">
      R.U.R.
     </a>
    </i>
    , the title standing for "
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rossum%27s_Universal_Robots" title="Rossum's Universal Robots">
     Rossum's Universal Robots
    </a>
    ". Later, the SF writer
    <a href="/wiki/Isaac_Asimov" title="Isaac Asimov">
     Isaac Asimov
    </a>
    developed the
    <a href="/wiki/Three_Laws_of_Robotics" title="Three Laws of Robotics">
     Three Laws of Robotics
    </a>
    . He subsequently explored these in his many books, most notably the "Multivac" series about a super-intelligent computer of the same name. Asimov's laws are often brought up during layman discussions of machine ethics;
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293">
     <a href="#cite_note-293">
      [293]
     </a>
    </sup>
    while almost all artificial intelligence researchers are familiar with Asimov's laws through popular culture, they generally consider the laws useless for many reasons, one of which is their ambiguity.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294">
     <a href="#cite_note-294">
      [294]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    The novel
    <i>
     <a href="/wiki/Do_Androids_Dream_of_Electric_Sheep%3F" title="Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?">
      Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?
     </a>
    </i>
    , by
    <a href="/wiki/Philip_K._Dick" title="Philip K. Dick">
     Philip K. Dick
    </a>
    , tells a science fiction story about Androids and humans clashing in a futuristic world. Elements of artificial intelligence include the empathy box, mood organ, and the androids themselves. Throughout the novel, Dick portrays the idea that human subjectivity is altered by technology created with artificial intelligence.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295">
     <a href="#cite_note-295">
      [295]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Nowadays AI is firmly rooted in popular culture; intelligent robots appear in innumerable works.
    <a href="/wiki/HAL_9000" title="HAL 9000">
     HAL 9000
    </a>
    , the murderous computer in charge of the
    <i>
     <a href="/wiki/Discovery_One" title="Discovery One">
      Discovery One
     </a>
    </i>
    spaceship in
    <a href="/wiki/2001:_A_Space_Odyssey_(novel)" title="2001: A Space Odyssey (novel)">
     Arthur C. Clarke's
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/2001:_A_Space_Odyssey_(film)" title="2001: A Space Odyssey (film)">
     Stanley Kubrick's
    </a>
    <i>
     <a href="/wiki/2001:_A_Space_Odyssey" title="2001: A Space Odyssey">
      2001: A Space Odyssey
     </a>
    </i>
    (both 1968), is an example of the common "robotic rampage" archetype in science fiction movies.
    <i>
     <a href="/wiki/The_Terminator" title="The Terminator">
      The Terminator
     </a>
    </i>
    (1984) and
    <i>
     <a href="/wiki/The_Matrix" title="The Matrix">
      The Matrix
     </a>
    </i>
    (1999) provide additional widely familiar examples. In contrast, the rare loyal robots such as Gort from
    <i>
     <a href="/wiki/The_Day_the_Earth_Stood_Still" title="The Day the Earth Stood Still">
      The Day the Earth Stood Still
     </a>
    </i>
    (1951) and Bishop from
    <i>
     <a href="/wiki/Aliens_(film)" title="Aliens (film)">
      Aliens
     </a>
    </i>
    (1986) are less prominent in popular culture.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296">
     <a href="#cite_note-296">
      [296]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <h2>

   <h2>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">
     Notes
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=64" title="Edit section: Notes">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h2>

       Definition of AI as the study of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Intelligent_agents" title="Intelligent agents">
        intelligent agents
       </a>
       :
      </span>

       <li>

          p. 1
         </a>
         , which provides the version that is used in this article. Note that they use the term "computational intelligence" as a synonym for artificial intelligence.
        </span>

     <li id="cite_note-AI_in_2000s-11">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       ^
       <a href="#cite_ref-AI_in_2000s_11-0">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           a
          </b>
         </i>

       </a>
       <a href="#cite_ref-AI_in_2000s_11-1">

       <a href="#cite_ref-AI_in_2000s_11-2">
        <sup>

          <b>
           c
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       AI becomes hugely successful in the early 21st century
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFClark2015">
          Clark 2015
         </a>
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-Fragmentation_of_AI-12">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       ^
       <a href="#cite_ref-Fragmentation_of_AI_12-0">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           a
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
       <a href="#cite_ref-Fragmentation_of_AI_12-1">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           b
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       Pamela
       <a href="#CITEREFMcCorduck2004">
        McCorduck (2004
       </a>
       , pp. 424) writes of "the rough shattering of AI in subfields—vision, natural language, decision theory, genetic algorithms, robotics ... and these with own sub-subfield—that would hardly have anything to say to each other."
      </span>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-Problems_of_AI-13">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       ^
       <a href="#cite_ref-Problems_of_AI_13-0">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           a
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
       <a href="#cite_ref-Problems_of_AI_13-1">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           b
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
       <a href="#cite_ref-Problems_of_AI_13-2">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           c
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       This list of intelligent traits is based on the topics covered by the major AI textbooks, including:
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFRussellNorvig2003">
          Russell &amp; Norvig 2003
         </a>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFLugerStubblefield2004">
          Luger &amp; Stubblefield 2004
         </a>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFPooleMackworthGoebel1998">
          Poole, Mackworth &amp; Goebel 1998
         </a>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFNilsson1998">
          Nilsson 1998
         </a>
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-Biological_intelligence_vs._intelligence_in_general-14">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       ^
       <a href="#cite_ref-Biological_intelligence_vs._intelligence_in_general_14-0">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           a
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
       <a href="#cite_ref-Biological_intelligence_vs._intelligence_in_general_14-1">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           b
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
       <a href="#cite_ref-Biological_intelligence_vs._intelligence_in_general_14-2">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           c
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       Biological intelligence vs. intelligence in general:
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFRussellNorvig2003">
          Russell &amp; Norvig 2003
         </a>
         , pp. 2–3, who make the analogy with
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aeronautical_engineering" title="Aeronautical engineering">
          aeronautical engineering
         </a>
         .
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFMcCorduck2004">
          McCorduck 2004
         </a>
         , pp. 100–101, who writes that there are "two major branches of artificial intelligence: one aimed at producing intelligent behavior regardless of how it was accomplished, and the other aimed at modeling intelligent processes found in nature, particularly human ones."
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFKolata1982">
          Kolata 1982
         </a>
         , a paper in
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Science_(journal)" title="Science (journal)">
           Science
          </a>
         </i>
         , which describes
         <a href="/wiki/John_McCarthy_(computer_scientist)" title="John McCarthy (computer scientist)">
          McCarthy's
         </a>
         indifference to biological models. Kolata quotes McCarthy as writing: "This is AI, so we don't care if it's psychologically real"
         <cite class="citation web">
          <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=PEkqAAAAMAAJ&amp;q=%22we+don't+care+if+it's+psychologically+real%22&amp;dq=%22we+don't+care+if+it's+psychologically+real%22&amp;output=html&amp;pgis=1" rel="nofollow">
           "Archived copy"
          </a>
          .
          <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160707182203/https://books.google.com/books?id=PEkqAAAAMAAJ&amp;q=%22we+don't+care+if+it's+psychologically+real%22&amp;dq=%22we+don't+care+if+it's+psychologically+real%22&amp;output=html&amp;pgis=1" rel="nofollow">
           Archived
          </a>
          from the original on 7 July 2016
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            16 February
           </span>
           2016
          </span>
          .
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Archived+copy&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DPEkqAAAAMAAJ%26q%3D%2522we%2Bdon%27t%2Bcare%2Bif%2Bit%27s%2Bpsychologically%2Breal%2522%26dq%3D%2522we%2Bdon%27t%2Bcare%2Bif%2Bit%27s%2Bpsychologically%2Breal%2522%26output%3Dhtml%26pgis%3D1&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArtificial+intelligence">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
         . McCarthy recently reiterated his position at the
         <a href="/wiki/AI@50" title="AI@50">
          AI@50
         </a>
         conference where he said "Artificial intelligence is not, by definition, simulation of human intelligence" (
         <a href="#CITEREFMaker2006">
          Maker 2006
         </a>
         ).
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-Neats_vs._scruffies-15">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       ^
       <a href="#cite_ref-Neats_vs._scruffies_15-0">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           a
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
       <a href="#cite_ref-Neats_vs._scruffies_15-1">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           b
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
       <a href="#cite_ref-Neats_vs._scruffies_15-2">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           c
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neats_vs._scruffies" title="Neats vs. scruffies">
        Neats vs. scruffies
       </a>
       :
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFMcCorduck2004">
          McCorduck 2004
         </a>
         , pp. 421–424, 486–489
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFCrevier1993">
          Crevier 1993
         </a>
         , pp. 168
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFNilsson1983">
          Nilsson 1983
         </a>
         , pp. 10–11
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-Symbolic_vs._sub-symbolic-16">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       ^
       <a href="#cite_ref-Symbolic_vs._sub-symbolic_16-0">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           a
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
       <a href="#cite_ref-Symbolic_vs._sub-symbolic_16-1">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           b
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
       <a href="#cite_ref-Symbolic_vs._sub-symbolic_16-2">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           c
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       Symbolic vs. sub-symbolic AI:
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFNilsson1998">
          Nilsson (1998
         </a>
         , p. 7), who uses the term "sub-symbolic".
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-General_intelligence-17">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       ^
       <a href="#cite_ref-General_intelligence_17-0">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           a
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
       <a href="#cite_ref-General_intelligence_17-1">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           b
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       General intelligence (
       <a href="/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence" title="Artificial general intelligence">
        strong AI
       </a>
       ) is discussed in popular introductions to AI:
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFKurzweil1999">
          Kurzweil 1999
         </a>
         and
         <a href="#CITEREFKurzweil2005">
          Kurzweil 2005
         </a>
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-18">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-18">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       See the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dartmouth_Workshop" title="Dartmouth Workshop">
        Dartmouth proposal
       </a>
       , under
       <a href="#Philosophy">
        Philosophy
       </a>
       , below.
      </span>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-McCorduck's_thesis-19">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-McCorduck's_thesis_19-0">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       This is a central idea of
       <a href="/wiki/Pamela_McCorduck" title="Pamela McCorduck">
        Pamela McCorduck
       </a>
       's
       <i>
        Machines Who Think
       </i>
       . She writes: "I like to think of artificial intelligence as the scientific apotheosis of a venerable cultural tradition." (
       <a href="#CITEREFMcCorduck2004">
        McCorduck 2004
       </a>
       , p. 34) "Artificial intelligence in one form or another is an idea that has pervaded Western intellectual history, a dream in urgent need of being realized." (
       <a href="#CITEREFMcCorduck2004">
        McCorduck 2004
       </a>
       , p. xviii) "Our history is full of attempts—nutty, eerie, comical, earnest, legendary and real—to make artificial intelligences, to reproduce what is the essential us—bypassing the ordinary means. Back and forth between myth and reality, our imaginations supplying what our workshops couldn't, we have engaged for a long time in this odd form of self-reproduction." (
       <a href="#CITEREFMcCorduck2004">
        McCorduck 2004
       </a>
       , p. 3) She traces the desire back to its
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hellenistic" title="Hellenistic">
        Hellenistic
       </a>
       roots and calls it the urge to "forge the Gods." (
       <a href="#CITEREFMcCorduck2004">
        McCorduck 2004
       </a>
       , pp. 340–400)
      </span>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-20">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-20">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <cite class="citation web">

        from the original on 28 August 2017.
       </cite>
       <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=BetaNews&amp;rft.atitle=Stephen+Hawking+believes+AI+could+be+mankind%27s+last+accomplishment&amp;rft.date=2016-10-21&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbetanews.com%2F2016%2F10%2F21%2Fartificial-intelligence-stephen-hawking%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArtificial+intelligence">

     <li id="cite_note-AI's_immediate_precursors-27">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

        <sup>

          <b>

          </b>

     <li id="cite_note-Dartmouth_conference-28">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-Dartmouth_conference_28-0">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dartmouth_Workshop" title="Dartmouth Workshop">
        Dartmouth conference
       </a>
       :
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFMcCorduck2004">
          McCorduck 2004
         </a>
         , pp. 111–136
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFCrevier1993">
          Crevier 1993
         </a>
         , pp. 47–49, who writes "the conference is generally recognized as the official birthdate of the new science."
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFRussellNorvig2003">
          Russell &amp; Norvig 2003
         </a>
         , p. 17, who call the conference "the birth of artificial intelligence."
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFNRC1999">
          NRC 1999
         </a>
         , pp. 200–201
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-Hegemony_of_the_Dartmouth_conference_attendees-29">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-Hegemony_of_the_Dartmouth_conference_attendees_29-0">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       Hegemony of the Dartmouth conference attendees:
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFRussellNorvig2003">
          Russell &amp; Norvig 2003
         </a>
         , p. 17, who write "for the next 20 years the field would be dominated by these people and their students."
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFMcCorduck2004">
          McCorduck 2004
         </a>
         , pp. 129–130

     </li>

     <li id="cite_note-32">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-32">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <cite class="citation journal">
        Samuel, A. L. (July 1959). "Some Studies in Machine Learning Using the Game of Checkers".
        <i>
         IBM Journal of Research and Development
        </i>
        .
        <b>
         3
        </b>
        (3): 210–229.
        <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">
         doi
        </a>
        :
        <a class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.1147%2Frd.33.0210" rel="nofollow">
         10.1147/rd.33.0210
        </a>
        .
       </cite>
       <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=IBM+Journal+of+Research+and+Development&amp;rft.atitle=Some+Studies+in+Machine+Learning+Using+the+Game+of+Checkers&amp;rft.volume=3&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.pages=210-229&amp;rft.date=1959-07&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1147%2Frd.33.0210&amp;rft.aulast=Samuel&amp;rft.aufirst=A.+L.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArtificial+intelligence">
        <span style="display:none;">
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-Golden_years_of_AI-33">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-Golden_years_of_AI_33-0">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       "
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_AI#The_golden_years_1956–1974" title="History of AI">
        Golden years
       </a>
       " of AI (successful symbolic reasoning programs 1956–1973):
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFMcCorduck2004">
          McCorduck 2004
         </a>
         , pp. 243–252
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFCrevier1993">
          Crevier 1993
         </a>
         , pp. 52–107
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFMoravec1988">
          Moravec 1988
         </a>
         , p. 9
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFRussellNorvig2003">
          Russell &amp; Norvig 2003
         </a>
         , pp. 18–21
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <span class="reference-text">
       The programs described are
       <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Samuel" title="Arthur Samuel">
        Arthur Samuel
       </a>
       's checkers program for the
       <a href="/wiki/IBM_701" title="IBM 701">
        IBM 701
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Daniel_Bobrow" title="Daniel Bobrow">
        Daniel Bobrow
       </a>
       's
       <a href="/wiki/STUDENT_(computer_program)" title="STUDENT (computer program)">
        STUDENT
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Allen_Newell" title="Allen Newell">
        Newell
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Herbert_A._Simon" title="Herbert A. Simon">
        Simon
       </a>
       's
       <a href="/wiki/Logic_Theorist" title="Logic Theorist">
        Logic Theorist
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Terry_Winograd" title="Terry Winograd">
        Terry Winograd
       </a>
       's
       <a href="/wiki/SHRDLU" title="SHRDLU">
        SHRDLU
       </a>
       .
      </span>
     </li>

     <li id="cite_note-:0-47">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       ^
       <a href="#cite_ref-:0_47-0">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           a
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
       <a href="#cite_ref-:0_47-1">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           b
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <cite class="citation web">
        Clark, Jack (8 December 2015).
        <a class="external text" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-12-08/why-2015-was-a-breakthrough-year-in-artificial-intelligence" rel="nofollow">
         "Why 2015 Was a Breakthrough Year in Artificial Intelligence"
        </a>
        .
        <i>
         Bloomberg News
        </i>
        .
        <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20161123053855/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-12-08/why-2015-was-a-breakthrough-year-in-artificial-intelligence" rel="nofollow">
         Archived
        </a>
        from the original on 23 November 2016
        <span class="reference-accessdate">
         . Retrieved
         <span class="nowrap">
          23 November
         </span>
         2016
        </span>
        .
        <q>
         After a half-decade of quiet breakthroughs in artificial intelligence, 2015 has been a landmark year. Computers are smarter and learning faster than ever.
        </q>
       </cite>
       <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Bloomberg+News&amp;rft.atitle=Why+2015+Was+a+Breakthrough+Year+in+Artificial+Intelligence&amp;rft.date=2015-12-08&amp;rft.aulast=Clark&amp;rft.aufirst=Jack&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bloomberg.com%2Fnews%2Farticles%2F2015-12-08%2Fwhy-2015-was-a-breakthrough-year-in-artificial-intelligence&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArtificial+intelligence">
        <span style="display:none;">
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-Reasoning-48">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-Reasoning_48-0">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       Problem solving, puzzle solving, game playing and deduction:
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFRussellNorvig2003">
          Russell &amp; Norvig 2003
         </a>
         , chpt. 3–9,
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFPooleMackworthGoebel1998">
          Poole, Mackworth &amp; Goebel 1998
         </a>
         , chpt. 2,3,7,9,
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFLugerStubblefield2004">
          Luger &amp; Stubblefield 2004
         </a>
         , chpt. 3,4,6,8,
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFNilsson1998">
          Nilsson 1998
         </a>
         , chpt. 7–12
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-Uncertain_reasoning-49">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-Uncertain_reasoning_49-0">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       Uncertain reasoning:
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">

          Russell &amp; Norvig 2003
         </a>
         , pp. 452–644,
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFPooleMackworthGoebel1998">
          Poole, Mackworth &amp; Goebel 1998
         </a>
         , pp. 345–395,
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">

          Luger &amp; Stubblefield 2004
         </a>
         , pp. 333–381,
        </span>
       </li>

     <li id="cite_note-Intractability-50">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-Intractability_50-0">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Intractably" title="Intractably">
        Intractability and efficiency
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Combinatorial_explosion" title="Combinatorial explosion">
        combinatorial explosion
       </a>
       :
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFRussellNorvig2003">
          Russell &amp; Norvig 2003
         </a>
         , pp. 9, 21–22
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-Psychological_evidence_of_sub-symbolic_reasoning-51">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-Psychological_evidence_of_sub-symbolic_reasoning_51-0">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       Psychological evidence of sub-symbolic reasoning:
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFWasonShapiro1966">
          Wason &amp; Shapiro (1966)
         </a>
         showed that people do poorly on completely abstract problems, but if the problem is restated to allow the use of intuitive
         <a href="/wiki/Social_intelligence" title="Social intelligence">
          social intelligence
         </a>
         , performance dramatically improves. (See
         <a href="/wiki/Wason_selection_task" title="Wason selection task">
          Wason selection task
         </a>
         )
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFKahnemanSlovicTversky1982">
          Kahneman, Slovic &amp; Tversky (1982)
         </a>
         have shown that people are terrible at elementary problems that involve uncertain reasoning. (See
         <a href="/wiki/List_of_cognitive_biases" title="List of cognitive biases">
          list of cognitive biases
         </a>
         for several examples).
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFLakoffNúñez2000">
          Lakoff &amp; Núñez (2000)
         </a>
         have controversially argued that even our skills at mathematics depend on knowledge and skills that come from "the body", i.e. sensorimotor and perceptual skills. (See
         <a href="/wiki/Where_Mathematics_Comes_From" title="Where Mathematics Comes From">
          Where Mathematics Comes From
         </a>
         )
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-Knowledge_representation-52">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-Knowledge_representation_52-0">

         , pp. 320–363,
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFPooleMackworthGoebel1998">
          Poole, Mackworth &amp; Goebel 1998
         </a>
         , pp. 23–46, 69–81, 169–196, 235–277, 281–298, 319–345,
        </span>

     <li id="cite_note-58">

        <a href="#cite_ref-58">
         ^

         Archived
        </a>
        from the original on 29 August 2017.
       </cite>
       <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Description+Logics+in+Multimedia+Reasoning&amp;rft.place=Cham&amp;rft.pub=Springer&amp;rft.date=2017-06&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1007%2F978-3-319-54066-5&amp;rft.isbn=978-3-319-54066-5&amp;rft.aulast=Sikos&amp;rft.aufirst=Leslie+F.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.springer.com%2Fus%2Fbook%2F9783319540658&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArtificial+intelligence">
        <span style="display:none;">

     <li id="cite_note-Ontology-59">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-Ontology_59-0">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ontology_(computer_science)" title="Ontology (computer science)">
        Ontology
       </a>
       :
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFRussellNorvig2003">
          Russell &amp; Norvig 2003
         </a>
         , pp. 320–328
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-60">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-60">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <cite class="citation conference">
        Bertini, M; Del Bimbo, A; Torniai, C (2006). "Automatic annotation and semantic retrieval of video sequences using multimedia ontologies".
        <i>
         MM ‘06 Proceedings of the 14th ACM international conference on Multimedia
        </i>
        . 14th ACM international conference on Multimedia. Santa Barbara: ACM. pp. 679–682.
       </cite>
       <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=conference&amp;rft.atitle=Automatic+annotation+and+semantic+retrieval+of+video+sequences+using+multimedia+ontologies&amp;rft.btitle=MM+%E2%80%9806+Proceedings+of+the+14th+ACM+international+conference+on+Multimedia&amp;rft.place=Santa+Barbara&amp;rft.pages=679-682&amp;rft.pub=ACM&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.aulast=Bertini&amp;rft.aufirst=M&amp;rft.au=Del+Bimbo%2C+A&amp;rft.au=Torniai%2C+C&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArtificial+intelligence">
        <span style="display:none;">
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-Qualification_problem-61">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-Qualification_problem_61-0">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <a href="/wiki/Qualification_problem" title="Qualification problem">
        Qualification problem
       </a>
       :
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFMcCarthyHayes1969">
          McCarthy &amp; Hayes 1969
         </a>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFRussellNorvig2003">
          Russell &amp; Norvig 2003
         </a>
         <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
          [
          <i>
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">
            <span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific page or range of pages in which the material appears. (February 2011)">
             page needed
            </span>
           </a>
          </i>
          ]
         </sup>
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
      While McCarthy was primarily concerned with issues in the logical representation of actions,
      <a href="#CITEREFRussellNorvig2003">
       Russell &amp; Norvig 2003
      </a>
      apply the term to the more general issue of default reasoning in the vast network of assumptions underlying all our commonsense knowledge.
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-Default_reasoning_and_non-monotonic_logic-62">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       ^
       <a href="#cite_ref-Default_reasoning_and_non-monotonic_logic_62-0">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           a
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
       <a href="#cite_ref-Default_reasoning_and_non-monotonic_logic_62-1">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           b
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       Default reasoning and
       <a href="/wiki/Default_logic" title="Default logic">
        default logic
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Non-monotonic_logic" title="Non-monotonic logic">
        non-monotonic logics
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Circumscription_(logic)" title="Circumscription (logic)">
        circumscription
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Closed_world_assumption" title="Closed world assumption">
        closed world assumption
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Abductive_reasoning" title="Abductive reasoning">
        abduction
       </a>
       (Poole
       <i>
        et al.
       </i>
       places abduction under "default reasoning". Luger
       <i>
        et al.
       </i>
       places this under "uncertain reasoning"):
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFRussellNorvig2003">
          Russell &amp; Norvig 2003
         </a>
         , pp. 354–360,
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFPooleMackworthGoebel1998">
          Poole, Mackworth &amp; Goebel 1998
         </a>
         , pp. 248–256, 323–335,
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFLugerStubblefield2004">
          Luger &amp; Stubblefield 2004
         </a>
         , pp. 335–363,
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFNilsson1998">
          Nilsson 1998
         </a>
         , ~18.3.3
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-Breadth_of_commonsense_knowledge-63">
