     <li id="cite_note-Intuition-66">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       ^
       <a href="#cite_ref-Intuition_66-0">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           a
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
       <a href="#cite_ref-Intuition_66-1">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           b
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       Expert knowledge as
       <a href="/wiki/Embodied_cognition" title="Embodied cognition">
        embodied
       </a>
       intuition:
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFDreyfusDreyfus1986">
          Dreyfus &amp; Dreyfus 1986
         </a>
         (
         <a href="/wiki/Hubert_Dreyfus" title="Hubert Dreyfus">
          Hubert Dreyfus
         </a>
         is a philosopher and critic of AI who was among the first to argue that most useful human knowledge was encoded sub-symbolically. See
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dreyfus%27_critique_of_AI" title="Dreyfus' critique of AI">
          Dreyfus' critique of AI
         </a>
         )
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFGladwell2005">
          Gladwell 2005
         </a>
         (Gladwell's
         <i>
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Blink_(book)" title="Blink (book)">
           Blink
          </a>
         </i>
         is a popular introduction to sub-symbolic reasoning and knowledge.)
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFHawkinsBlakeslee2005">
          Hawkins &amp; Blakeslee 2005
         </a>
         (Hawkins argues that sub-symbolic knowledge should be the primary focus of AI research.)
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-Planning-67">

     <li id="cite_note-72">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-72">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       Stefano Albrecht and Peter Stone. Autonomous agents modelling other agents: A comprehensive survey and open problems. Artificial Intelligence, Vol. 258, pp. 66-95, 2018.
       <a class="external free" href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.artint.2018.01.002" rel="nofollow">
        https://doi.org/10.1016/j.artint.2018.01.002
       </a>
      </span>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-73">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-73">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <a href="/wiki/Alan_Turing" title="Alan Turing">
        Alan Turing
       </a>
       discussed the centrality of learning as early as 1950, in his classic paper "
       <a href="/wiki/Computing_Machinery_and_Intelligence" title="Computing Machinery and Intelligence">
        Computing Machinery and Intelligence
       </a>
       ".(
       <a href="#CITEREFTuring1950">
        Turing 1950
       </a>
       ) In 1956, at the original Dartmouth AI summer conference,
       <a href="/wiki/Ray_Solomonoff" title="Ray Solomonoff">
        Ray Solomonoff
       </a>
       wrote a report on unsupervised probabilistic machine learning: "An Inductive Inference Machine".(
       <a href="#CITEREFSolomonoff1956">
        Solomonoff 1956
       </a>
       )
      </span>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-74">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-74">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       This is a form of
       <a href="/wiki/Tom_M._Mitchell" title="Tom M. Mitchell">
        Tom Mitchell
       </a>
       's widely quoted definition of machine learning: "A computer program is set to learn from an experience
       <i>
        E
       </i>
       with respect to some task
       <i>
        T
       </i>
       and some performance measure
       <i>
        P
       </i>
       if its performance on
       <i>
        T
       </i>
       as measured by
       <i>
        P
       </i>
       improves with experience
       <i>
        E
       </i>
       ."
      </span>
     </li>

         Kismet
        </i>
       </a>
       .
      </span>
     </li>

     <li id="cite_note-Roberts-101">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       ^
       <a href="#cite_ref-Roberts_101-0">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           a
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
       <a href="#cite_ref-Roberts_101-1">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           b
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
       <a href="#cite_ref-Roberts_101-2">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           c
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <cite class="citation journal">
        Roberts, Jacob (2016).
        <a class="external text" href="https://www.chemheritage.org/distillations/magazine/thinking-machines-the-search-for-artificial-intelligence" rel="nofollow">
         "Thinking Machines: The Search for Artificial Intelligence"
        </a>
        .
        <i>
         Distillations
        </i>
        .
        <b>
         2
        </b>
        (2): 14–23.
        <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170217223823/https://www.chemheritage.org/distillations/magazine/thinking-machines-the-search-for-artificial-intelligence" rel="nofollow">
         Archived
        </a>
        from the original on 17 February 2017
        <span class="reference-accessdate">
         . Retrieved
         <span class="nowrap">
          17 February
         </span>
         2017
        </span>
        .
       </cite>
       <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Distillations&amp;rft.atitle=Thinking+Machines%3A+The+Search+for+Artificial+Intelligence&amp;rft.volume=2&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.pages=14-23&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft.aulast=Roberts&amp;rft.aufirst=Jacob&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.chemheritage.org%2Fdistillations%2Fmagazine%2Fthinking-machines-the-search-for-artificial-intelligence&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArtificial+intelligence">
        <span style="display:none;">
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-Artificial_consciousness-102">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-Artificial_consciousness_102-0">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <a href="/wiki/Gerald_Edelman" title="Gerald Edelman">
        Gerald Edelman
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Igor_Aleksander" title="Igor Aleksander">
        Igor Aleksander
       </a>
       and others have argued that
       <a href="/wiki/Artificial_consciousness" title="Artificial consciousness">
        artificial consciousness
       </a>
       is required for strong AI. (
       <a href="#CITEREFAleksander1995">
        Aleksander 1995
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="#CITEREFEdelman2007">
        Edelman 2007
       </a>
       )
      </span>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-Brain_simulation-103">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       ^
       <a href="#cite_ref-Brain_simulation_103-0">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           a
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
       <a href="#cite_ref-Brain_simulation_103-1">
        <sup>
         <i>
          <b>
           b
          </b>
         </i>
        </sup>
       </a>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <a href="/wiki/Artificial_brain" title="Artificial brain">
        Artificial brain
       </a>
       arguments: AI requires a simulation of the operation of the human brain
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFRussellNorvig2003">
          Russell &amp; Norvig 2003
         </a>
         , p. 957
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFCrevier1993">
          Crevier 1993
         </a>
         , pp. 271 and 279
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <span class="reference-text">
       A few of the people who make some form of the argument:
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFMoravec1988">
          Moravec 1988
         </a>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFKurzweil2005">
          Kurzweil 2005
         </a>
         , p. 262
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFHawkinsBlakeslee2005">
          Hawkins &amp; Blakeslee 2005
         </a>
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <span class="reference-text">
       The most extreme form of this argument (the brain replacement scenario) was put forward by
       <a href="/wiki/Clark_Glymour" title="Clark Glymour">
        Clark Glymour
       </a>
       in the mid-1970s and was touched on by
       <a href="/wiki/Zenon_Pylyshyn" title="Zenon Pylyshyn">
        Zenon Pylyshyn
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/John_Searle" title="John Searle">
        John Searle
       </a>
       in 1980.
      </span>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-104">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-104">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nils_Nilsson_(researcher)" title="Nils Nilsson (researcher)">
        Nils Nilsson
       </a>
       writes: "Simply put, there is wide disagreement in the field about what AI is all about" (
       <a href="#CITEREFNilsson1983">
        Nilsson 1983
       </a>
       , p. 10).
      </span>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEHaugeland1985255-105">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHaugeland1985255_105-0">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <a href="#CITEREFHaugeland1985">
        Haugeland 1985
       </a>
       , p. 255.

     <li id="cite_note-110">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-110">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       The most dramatic case of sub-symbolic AI being pushed into the background was the devastating critique of
       <a href="/wiki/Perceptron" title="Perceptron">
        perceptrons
       </a>
       by
       <a href="/wiki/Marvin_Minsky" title="Marvin Minsky">
        Marvin Minsky
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Seymour_Papert" title="Seymour Papert">
        Seymour Papert
       </a>
       in 1969. See
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_AI" title="History of AI">
        History of AI
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/AI_winter" title="AI winter">
        AI winter
       </a>
       , or
       <a href="/wiki/Frank_Rosenblatt" title="Frank Rosenblatt">
        Frank Rosenblatt
       </a>
       .
      </span>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-AI_at_CMU_in_the_60s-111">

        <a href="#cite_ref-AI_at_CMU_in_the_60s_111-0">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       Cognitive simulation,
       <a href="/wiki/Allen_Newell" title="Allen Newell">
        Newell
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Herbert_A._Simon" title="Herbert A. Simon">
        Simon
       </a>

       <a href="/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University" title="Carnegie Mellon University">
        CMU
       </a>
       (then called

     <li id="cite_note-Computational_intelligence-120">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-Computational_intelligence_120-0">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">

       </a>

      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a class="external text" href="http://www.ieee-cis.org/" rel="nofollow">

     <li id="cite_note-Intelligent_agents-125">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-Intelligent_agents_125-0">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Intelligent_agent" title="Intelligent agent">
        intelligent agent
       </a>
       paradigm:
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFRussellNorvig2003">
          Russell &amp; Norvig 2003
         </a>
         , pp. 27, 32–58, 968–972
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFPooleMackworthGoebel1998">
          Poole, Mackworth &amp; Goebel 1998
         </a>
         , pp. 7–21
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFLugerStubblefield2004">
          Luger &amp; Stubblefield 2004
         </a>
         , pp. 235–240
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFHutter2005">
          Hutter 2005
         </a>
         , pp. 125–126
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <span class="reference-text">
       The definition used in this article, in terms of goals, actions, perception and environment, is due to
       <a href="#CITEREFRussellNorvig2003">
        Russell &amp; Norvig (2003)
       </a>
       . Other definitions also include knowledge and learning as additional criteria.
      </span>
     </li>

      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       Stochastic methods for uncertain reasoning:
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFACM1998">
          ACM 1998
         </a>
         , ~I.2.3,
        </span>
       </li>

          Russell &amp; Norvig 2003
         </a>
         , pp. 462–644,
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>

        </span>
       </li>
       <li>

     <li id="cite_note-werbos1982-166">

       .

     </li>

     <li id="cite_note-Nature2017-182">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-Nature2017_182-0">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <cite class="citation journal">
        <a href="/wiki/David_Silver_(programmer)" title="David Silver (programmer)">
         Silver, David
        </a>
        ; Schrittwieser, Julian; Simonyan, Karen; Antonoglou, Ioannis;
        <a href="/wiki/Aja_Huang" title="Aja Huang">
         Huang, Aja
        </a>
        ; Guez, Arthur; Hubert, Thomas; Baker, Lucas; Lai, Matthew; Bolton, Adrian;
        <a href="/wiki/Chen_Yutian" title="Chen Yutian">
         Chen, Yutian
        </a>
        ; Lillicrap, Timothy;
        <a href="/wiki/Fan_Hui" title="Fan Hui">

        </a>
        ; Sifre, Laurent; Driessche, George van den; Graepel, Thore;

         Hassabis, Demis
        </a>
        (19 October 2017).
        <a class="external text" href="https://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v550/n7676/full/nature24270.html" rel="nofollow">
         "Mastering the game of Go without human knowledge"
        </a>
        .
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Nature_(journal)" title="Nature (journal)">
          Nature
         </a>
        </i>

        <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">

        </a>
        :
        <a class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.1038%2Fnature24270" rel="nofollow">
         10.1038/nature24270
        </a>
        .
        <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Serial_Number" title="International Standard Serial Number">
         ISSN
        </a>
        <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/0028-0836" rel="nofollow">
         0028-0836
        </a>
        .
        <q>
         AlphaGo Lee... 12 convolutional layers
        </q>
       </cite>
       <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Nature&amp;rft.atitle=Mastering+the+game+of+Go+without+human+knowledge&amp;rft.volume=550&amp;rft.issue=7676&amp;rft.pages=354-359&amp;rft.date=2017-10-19&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1038%2Fnature24270&amp;rft.issn=0028-0836&amp;rft.aulast=Silver&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rft.au=Schrittwieser%2C+Julian&amp;rft.au=Simonyan%2C+Karen&amp;rft.au=Antonoglou%2C+Ioannis&amp;rft.au=Huang%2C+Aja&amp;rft.au=Guez%2C+Arthur&amp;rft.au=Hubert%2C+Thomas&amp;rft.au=Baker%2C+Lucas&amp;rft.au=Lai%2C+Matthew&amp;rft.au=Bolton%2C+Adrian&amp;rft.au=Chen%2C+Yutian&amp;rft.au=Lillicrap%2C+Timothy&amp;rft.au=Fan%2C+Hui&amp;rft.au=Sifre%2C+Laurent&amp;rft.au=Driessche%2C+George+van+den&amp;rft.au=Graepel%2C+Thore&amp;rft.au=Hassabis%2C+Demis&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nature.com%2Fnature%2Fjournal%2Fv550%2Fn7676%2Ffull%2Fnature24270.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArtificial+intelligence">
        <span style="display:none;">
        </span>
       </span>

        <a href="/wiki/Paywall" title="closed access publication – behind paywall">

       <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=preprint&amp;rft.jtitle=arXiv&amp;rft.atitle=Show+and+Tell%3A+A+Neural+Image+Caption+Generator&amp;rft.date=2015&amp;rft_id=info%3Aarxiv%2F1411.4555&amp;rft.aulast=Vinyals&amp;rft.aufirst=Oriol&amp;rft.au=Toshev%2C+Alexander&amp;rft.au=Bengio%2C+Samy&amp;rft.au=Erhan%2C+Dumitru&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArtificial+intelligence">

      </span>
     </li>

        from the original on 3 July 2017.
       </cite>
       <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Theme+2%3A+Good+things+lie+ahead&amp;rft.date=2017-02-08&amp;rft.aulast=Rainie&amp;rft.aufirst=Lee&amp;rft.au=Janna&amp;rft.au=erson&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.pewinternet.org%2F2017%2F02%2F08%2Ftheme-2-good-things-lie-ahead%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArtificial+intelligence">

     <li id="cite_note-Dartmouth_proposal-243">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-Dartmouth_proposal_243-0">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       Dartmouth proposal:
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFMcCarthyMinskyRochesterShannon1955">
          McCarthy et al. 1955
         </a>
         (the original proposal)
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFCrevier1993">
          Crevier 1993
         </a>
         , p. 49 (historical significance)
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-Physical_symbol_system_hypothesis-244">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-Physical_symbol_system_hypothesis_244-0">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Physical_symbol_system" title="Physical symbol system">
        physical symbol systems
       </a>
       hypothesis:
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFNewellSimon1976">
          Newell &amp; Simon 1976
         </a>
         , p. 116
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFMcCorduck2004">
          McCorduck 2004
         </a>
         , p. 153
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFRussellNorvig2003">
          Russell &amp; Norvig 2003
         </a>
         , p. 18
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-245">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-245">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       Dreyfus criticized the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Necessary_and_sufficient" title="Necessary and sufficient">
        necessary
       </a>
       condition of the
       <a href="/wiki/Physical_symbol_system" title="Physical symbol system">
        physical symbol system
       </a>
       hypothesis, which he called the "psychological assumption": "The mind can be viewed as a device operating on bits of information according to formal rules." (
       <a href="#CITEREFDreyfus1992">
        Dreyfus 1992
       </a>
       , p. 156)
      </span>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-Dreyfus'_critique-246">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-Dreyfus'_critique_246-0">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dreyfus%27_critique_of_artificial_intelligence" title="Dreyfus' critique of artificial intelligence">
        Dreyfus' critique of artificial intelligence
       </a>
       :
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFDreyfus1972">
          Dreyfus 1972
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="#CITEREFDreyfusDreyfus1986">
          Dreyfus &amp; Dreyfus 1986
         </a>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFCrevier1993">
          Crevier 1993
         </a>
         , pp. 120–132
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFMcCorduck2004">
          McCorduck 2004
         </a>
         , pp. 211–239
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFRussellNorvig2003">
          Russell &amp; Norvig 2003
         </a>
         , pp. 950–952,
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-Gödel_himself-247">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-Gödel_himself_247-0">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <a href="#CITEREFGödel1951">
        Gödel 1951
       </a>
       : in this lecture,
       <a href="/wiki/Kurt_G%C3%B6del" title="Kurt Gödel">
        Kurt Gödel
       </a>
       uses the incompleteness theorem to arrive at the following disjunction: (a) the human mind is not a consistent finite machine, or (b) there exist
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Diophantine_equations" title="Diophantine equations">
        Diophantine equations
       </a>
       for which it cannot decide whether solutions exist. Gödel finds (b) implausible, and thus seems to have believed the human mind was not equivalent to a finite machine, i.e., its power exceeded that of any finite machine. He recognized that this was only a conjecture, since one could never disprove (b). Yet he considered the disjunctive conclusion to be a "certain fact".
      </span>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-The_mathematical_objection-248">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-The_mathematical_objection_248-0">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       The Mathematical Objection:
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFRussellNorvig2003">
          Russell &amp; Norvig 2003
         </a>
         , p. 949
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFMcCorduck2004">
          McCorduck 2004
         </a>
         , pp. 448–449
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <span class="reference-text">
       Making the Mathematical Objection:
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFLucas1961">
          Lucas 1961
         </a>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFPenrose1989">
          Penrose 1989
         </a>
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <span class="reference-text">
       Refuting Mathematical Objection:
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFTuring1950">
          Turing 1950
         </a>
         under "(2) The Mathematical Objection"
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFHofstadter1979">
          Hofstadter 1979
         </a>
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <span class="reference-text">
       Background:
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         Gödel 1931, Church 1936, Kleene 1935, Turing 1937
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-249">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-249">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <cite class="citation web">
        <a href="/wiki/Graham_Oppy" title="Graham Oppy">
         Graham Oppy
        </a>
        (20 January 2015).
        <a class="external text" href="http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/goedel-incompleteness/#GdeArgAgaMec" rel="nofollow">
         "Gödel's Incompleteness Theorems"
        </a>
        .
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Stanford_Encyclopedia_of_Philosophy" title="Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy">
          Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy
         </a>
        </i>
        <span class="reference-accessdate">
         . Retrieved
         <span class="nowrap">
          27 April
         </span>
         2016
        </span>
        .
        <q>
         These Gödelian anti-mechanist arguments are, however, problematic, and there is wide consensus that they fail.
        </q>
       </cite>
       <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Stanford+Encyclopedia+of+Philosophy&amp;rft.atitle=G%C3%B6del%27s+Incompleteness+Theorems&amp;rft.date=2015-01-20&amp;rft.au=Graham+Oppy&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fplato.stanford.edu%2Fentries%2Fgoedel-incompleteness%2F%23GdeArgAgaMec&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArtificial+intelligence">
        <span style="display:none;">
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-250">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-250">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <cite class="citation book">
        <a href="/wiki/Stuart_J._Russell" title="Stuart J. Russell">
         Stuart J. Russell
        </a>
        ;
        <a href="/wiki/Peter_Norvig" title="Peter Norvig">
         Peter Norvig
        </a>
        (2010). "26.1.2: Philosophical Foundations/Weak AI: Can Machines Act Intelligently?/The mathematical objection".
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Artificial_Intelligence:_A_Modern_Approach" title="Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach">
          Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach
         </a>
        </i>
        (3rd ed.). Upper Saddle River, NJ:
        <a href="/wiki/Prentice_Hall" title="Prentice Hall">
         Prentice Hall
        </a>
        .
        <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
         ISBN
        </a>
        <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-13-604259-7" title="Special:BookSources/0-13-604259-7">
         0-13-604259-7
        </a>
        .
        <q>
         ...even if we grant that computers have limitations on what they can prove, there is no evidence that humans are immune from those limitations.
        </q>
       </cite>
       <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=26.1.2%3A+Philosophical+Foundations%2FWeak+AI%3A+Can+Machines+Act+Intelligently%3F%2FThe+mathematical+objection&amp;rft.btitle=Artificial+Intelligence%3A+A+Modern+Approach&amp;rft.place=Upper+Saddle+River%2C+NJ&amp;rft.edition=3rd&amp;rft.pub=Prentice+Hall&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=0-13-604259-7&amp;rft.au=Stuart+J.+Russell&amp;rft.au=Peter+Norvig&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArtificial+intelligence">
        <span style="display:none;">
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-251">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-251">
         ^
        </a>

        Cambridge University Press

     <li id="cite_note-255">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-255">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <cite class="citation web">

      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-264">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <cite class="citation web">
        <a class="external text" href="http://observer.com/2015/08/stephen-hawking-elon-musk-and-bill-gates-warn-about-artificial-intelligence/" rel="nofollow">

        </a>

       <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Observer&amp;rft.atitle=Stephen+Hawking%2C+Elon+Musk%2C+and+Bill+Gates+Warn+About+Artificial+Intelligence&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fobserver.com%2F2015%2F08%2Fstephen-hawking-elon-musk-and-bill-gates-warn-about-artificial-intelligence%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArtificial+intelligence">
        <span style="display:none;">
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-265">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-265">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       In the early 1970s,
       <a href="/wiki/Kenneth_Colby" title="Kenneth Colby">
        Kenneth Colby
       </a>
       presented a version of Weizenbaum's
       <a href="/wiki/ELIZA" title="ELIZA">
        ELIZA
       </a>
       known as DOCTOR which he promoted as a serious therapeutic tool. (
       <a href="#CITEREFCrevier1993">
        Crevier 1993
       </a>
       , pp. 132–144)
      </span>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-Weizenbaum's_critique-266">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-Weizenbaum's_critique_266-0">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Weizenbaum" title="Joseph Weizenbaum">
        Joseph Weizenbaum
       </a>
       's critique of AI:
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFWeizenbaum1976">
          Weizenbaum 1976
         </a>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFCrevier1993">
          Crevier 1993
         </a>
         , pp. 132–144
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFMcCorduck2004">
          McCorduck 2004
         </a>
         , pp. 356–373
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFRussellNorvig2003">
          Russell &amp; Norvig 2003
         </a>
         , p. 961
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <span class="reference-text">
       Weizenbaum (the AI researcher who developed the first
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chatterbot" title="Chatterbot">
        chatterbot
       </a>
       program,
       <a href="/wiki/ELIZA" title="ELIZA">
        ELIZA
       </a>
       ) argued in 1976 that the misuse of artificial intelligence has the potential to devalue human life.
      </span>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-267">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-267">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       E McGaughey, 'Will Robots Automate Your Job Away? Full Employment, Basic Income, and Economic Democracy' (2018)
       <a class="external text" href="https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3044448" rel="nofollow">
        SSRN, part 2(3)
       </a>
      </span>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-268">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-268">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <cite class="citation news">

        <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/12/technology/robots-will-take-jobs-but-not-as-fast-as-some-fear-new-report-says.html" rel="nofollow">

       <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+York+Times&amp;rft.atitle=Robots+Will+Take+Jobs%2C+but+Not+as+Fast+as+Some+Fear%2C+New+Report+Says&amp;rft.date=2017&amp;rft.aulast=Lohr&amp;rft.aufirst=Steve&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2017%2F01%2F12%2Ftechnology%2Frobots-will-take-jobs-but-not-as-fast-as-some-fear-new-report-says.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArtificial+intelligence">

     <li id="cite_note-270">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-270">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <cite class="citation journal">
        <a class="external text" href="https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0040162516302244" rel="nofollow">
         "The future of employment: How susceptible are jobs to computerisation?"
        </a>
        .
        <i>
         Technological Forecasting and Social Change
        </i>
        .
        <b>
         114
        </b>
        : 254–280. 1 January 2017.
        <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">
         doi
        </a>
        :
        <a class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.1016%2Fj.techfore.2016.08.019" rel="nofollow">
         10.1016/j.techfore.2016.08.019
        </a>
        .
        <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Serial_Number" title="International Standard Serial Number">
         ISSN
        </a>

         ^

        <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20141112130954/http://www.rethinkrobotics.com/artificial-intelligence-tool-threat/" rel="nofollow">
         "artificial intelligence is a tool, not a threat"
        </a>
        . Archived from

         the original

       <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=artificial+intelligence+is+a+tool%2C+not+a+threat&amp;rft.date=2014-11-10&amp;rft.aulast=Brooks&amp;rft.aufirst=Rodney&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.rethinkrobotics.com%2Fartificial-intelligence-tool-threat%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArtificial+intelligence">
        <span style="display:none;">
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-282">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-282">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Steven_Horst&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Steven Horst (page does not exist)">
        Horst, Steven
       </a>
       , (2005)
       <a class="external text" href="http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/computational-mind/" rel="nofollow">
        "The Computational Theory of Mind"
       </a>
       in
       <i>
        The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy
       </i>
      </span>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-Searle's_strong_AI-283">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-Searle's_strong_AI_283-0">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       This version is from
       <a href="#CITEREFSearle1999">
        Searle (1999)
       </a>
       , and is also quoted in
       <a href="#CITEREFDennett1991">
        Dennett 1991
       </a>
       , p. 435. Searle's original formulation was "The appropriately programmed computer really is a mind, in the sense that computers given the right programs can be literally said to understand and have other cognitive states." (
       <a href="#CITEREFSearle1980">
        Searle 1980
       </a>
       , p. 1). Strong AI is defined similarly by
       <a href="#CITEREFRussellNorvig2003">
        Russell &amp; Norvig (2003
       </a>
       , p. 947): "The assertion that machines could possibly act intelligently (or, perhaps better, act as if they were intelligent) is called the 'weak AI' hypothesis by philosophers, and the assertion that machines that do so are actually thinking (as opposed to simulating thinking) is called the 'strong AI' hypothesis."
      </span>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-Chinese_room-284">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-Chinese_room_284-0">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       Searle's
       <a href="/wiki/Chinese_room" title="Chinese room">
        Chinese room
       </a>
       argument:
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFSearle1980">
          Searle 1980
         </a>
         . Searle's original presentation of the thought experiment.
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFSearle1999">
          Searle 1999
         </a>
         .
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <span class="reference-text">
       Discussion:
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFRussellNorvig2003">
          Russell &amp; Norvig 2003
         </a>
         , pp. 958–960
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFMcCorduck2004">
          McCorduck 2004
         </a>
         , pp. 443–445
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFCrevier1993">
          Crevier 1993
         </a>
         , pp. 269–271
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
     </li>
     <li id="cite_note-Robot_rights-285">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-Robot_rights_285-0">
         ^
        </a>
       </b>
      </span>
      <span class="reference-text">
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Robot_rights" title="Robot rights">
        Robot rights
       </a>
       :
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFRussellNorvig2003">
          Russell &amp; Norvig 2003
         </a>
         , p. 964
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFBBC_News2006">
          <i>
           BBC News
          </i>
          2006
         </a>
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <span class="reference-text">
       Prematurity of:
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFHenderson2007">
          Henderson 2007
         </a>
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <span class="reference-text">
       In fiction:
      </span>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a href="#CITEREFMcCorduck2004">
          McCorduck (2004
         </a>
         , p. 190-25) discusses
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Frankenstein" title="Frankenstein">
           Frankenstein
          </a>
         </i>
         and identifies the key ethical issues as scientific hubris and the suffering of the monster, i.e.
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Robot_rights" title="Robot rights">
          robot rights
         </a>
         .
        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
     </li>

     <li id="cite_note-lemmon198504-290">
      <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
       <b>
        <a href="#cite_ref-lemmon198504_290-0">

      <span class="reference-text">
       <cite class="citation news">
        Lemmons, Phil (April 1985).
        <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/stream/byte-magazine-1985-04/1985_04_BYTE_10-04_Artificial_Intelligence#page/n125/mode/2up" rel="nofollow">
         "Artificial Intelligence"
        </a>
        .
        <i>
         BYTE
        </i>
        . p. 125.

        from the original on 20 April 2015

   <h3>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="History_of_AI">
     History of AI
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>

     </a>

      <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+York+Times&amp;rft.atitle=Computer+Wins+on+%27Jeopardy%21%27%3A+Trivial%2C+It%27s+Not&amp;rft.date=2011-02-16&amp;rft.aulast=Markoff&amp;rft.aufirst=John&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2011%2F02%2F17%2Fscience%2F17jeopardy-watson.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArtificial+intelligence">
       <span style="display:none;">
       </span>
      </span>
     </li>

       </a>
       .
      </cite>
      <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Computer+Power+and+Human+Reason&amp;rft.place=San+Francisco&amp;rft.pub=W.H.+Freeman+%26+Company&amp;rft.date=1976&amp;rft.isbn=0-7167-0464-1&amp;rft.aulast=Weizenbaum&amp;rft.aufirst=Joseph&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArtificial+intelligence">
       <span style="display:none;">
       </span>
      </span>
     </li>
     <li>
      <cite class="citation journal" id="CITEREFWengMcClellandPentlandSporns2001">
       Weng, J.; McClelland; Pentland, A.; Sporns, O.; Stockman, I.; Sur, M.; Thelen, E. (2001).
       <a class="external text" href="http://www.cse.msu.edu/dl/SciencePaper.pdf" rel="nofollow">
        "Autonomous mental development by robots and animals"
       </a>
       <span style="font-size:85%;">
        (PDF)
       </span>
       .
       <i>
        Science
       </i>
       .
       <b>
        291
       </b>
       : 599–600.
       <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">
        doi
       </a>
       :
       <a class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.1126%2Fscience.291.5504.599" rel="nofollow">
        10.1126/science.291.5504.599
       </a>
       – via msu.edu.
      </cite>
      <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Science&amp;rft.atitle=Autonomous+mental+development+by+robots+and+animals&amp;rft.volume=291&amp;rft.pages=599-600&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1126%2Fscience.291.5504.599&amp;rft.aulast=Weng&amp;rft.aufirst=J.&amp;rft.au=McClelland&amp;rft.au=Pentland%2C+A.&amp;rft.au=Sporns%2C+O.&amp;rft.au=Stockman%2C+I.&amp;rft.au=Sur%2C+M.&amp;rft.au=Thelen%2C+E.&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cse.msu.edu%2Fdl%2FSciencePaper.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArtificial+intelligence">

     </li>

      <cite class="citation web">

   <h2>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Further_reading">
     Further reading
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artificial_intelligence&amp;action=edit&amp;section=69" title="Edit section: Further reading">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h2>
   <ul>
    <li>
     DH Autor, ‘Why Are There Still So Many Jobs? The History and Future of Workplace Automation’ (2015) 29(3) Journal of Economic Perspectives 3.
    </li>
    <li>
     TechCast Article Series, John Sagi,
     <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150713184128/https://www.techcastglobal.com/documents/10193/34869/Consciousness-Sagifinalversion" rel="nofollow">
      "Framing Consciousness"
     </a>
    </li>
    <li>
     <a href="/wiki/Margaret_Boden" title="Margaret Boden">
      Boden, Margaret
     </a>
     ,
     <i>
      Mind As Machine
     </i>
     ,
     <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">
      Oxford University Press
     </a>
     , 2006
    </li>
    <li>
     <a href="/wiki/Alison_Gopnik" title="Alison Gopnik">
      Gopnik, Alison
     </a>
     , "Making AI More Human: Artificial intelligence has staged a revival by starting to incorporate what we know about how children learn",
     <i>
      <a href="/wiki/Scientific_American" title="Scientific American">
       Scientific American
      </a>
     </i>
     , vol. 316, no. 6 (June 2017), pp. 60–65.
    </li>
    <li>
     Johnston, John (2008)
     <i>
      The Allure of Machinic Life: Cybernetics, Artificial Life, and the New AI
     </i>
     , MIT Press
    </li>
    <li>
     <a href="/wiki/Gary_Marcus" title="Gary Marcus">
      Marcus, Gary
     </a>
     , "Am I Human?: Researchers need new ways to distinguish artificial intelligence from the natural kind",
     <i>
      <a href="/wiki/Scientific_American" title="Scientific American">
       Scientific American
      </a>
     </i>
     , vol. 316, no. 3 (March 2017), pp. 58–63.
     <i>
      Multiple
     </i>
     tests of artificial-intelligence efficacy are needed because, "just as there is no single test of
     <a href="/wiki/Athletics_(physical_culture)" title="Athletics (physical culture)">
      athletic
     </a>
     prowess, there cannot be one ultimate test of
     <a href="/wiki/Intelligence" title="Intelligence">
      intelligence
     </a>
     ." One such test, a "Construction Challenge", would test perception and physical action—"two important elements of intelligent behavior that were entirely absent from the original
     <a href="/wiki/Turing_test" title="Turing test">
      Turing test
     </a>
     ." Another proposal has been to give machines the same standardized tests of science and other disciplines that schoolchildren take. A so far insuperable stumbling block to artificial intelligence is an incapacity for reliable
     <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Disambiguation" title="Disambiguation">
      disambiguation
     </a>
     . "[V]irtually every sentence [that people generate] is
     <a href="/wiki/Ambiguity" title="Ambiguity">
      ambiguous
     </a>
     , often in multiple ways." A prominent example is known as the "pronoun disambiguation problem": a machine has no way of determining to whom or what a
     <a href="/wiki/Pronoun" title="Pronoun">
      pronoun
     </a>
     in a sentence—such as "he", "she" or "it"—refers.
    </li>
    <li>
     E McGaughey, 'Will Robots Automate Your Job Away? Full Employment, Basic Income, and Economic Democracy' (2018)
     <a class="external text" href="https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3044448" rel="nofollow">
      SSRN, part 2(3)
     </a>
     .
    </li>
    <li>
     Myers, Courtney Boyd ed. (2009).
     <a class="external text" href="https://www.forbes.com/2009/06/22/singularity-robots-computers-opinions-contributors-artificial-intelligence-09_land.html" rel="nofollow">
      "The AI Report"
     </a>
     .
     <i>
      Forbes
     </i>
     June 2009
    </li>
    <li>
     <cite class="citation book">
      <a href="/wiki/Bertram_Raphael" title="Bertram Raphael">
       Raphael, Bertram
      </a>
      (1976).
      <i>
       The Thinking Computer
      </i>
      . W.H.Freeman and Company.
      <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
       ISBN
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-7167-0723-3" title="Special:BookSources/0-7167-0723-3">
       0-7167-0723-3
      </a>
      .
     </cite>
     <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Thinking+Computer&amp;rft.pub=W.H.Freeman+and+Company&amp;rft.date=1976&amp;rft.isbn=0-7167-0723-3&amp;rft.aulast=Raphael&amp;rft.aufirst=Bertram&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArtificial+intelligence">
      <span style="display:none;">
      </span>
     </span>
    </li>
    <li>
     <cite class="citation journal">
      Serenko, Alexander (2010).
      <a class="external text" href="http://www.aserenko.com/papers/JOI_Serenko_AI_Journal_Ranking_Published.pdf" rel="nofollow">
       "The development of an AI journal ranking based on the revealed preference approach"
      </a>
      <span style="font-size:85%;">
       (PDF)
      </span>
      .
      <i>
       Journal of Informetrics
      </i>
      .
      <b>
       4
      </b>
      (4): 447–459.
      <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">
       doi
      </a>
      :
      <a class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.1016%2Fj.joi.2010.04.001" rel="nofollow">
       10.1016/j.joi.2010.04.001
      </a>
      .
     </cite>
     <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Informetrics&amp;rft.atitle=The+development+of+an+AI+journal+ranking+based+on+the+revealed+preference+approach&amp;rft.volume=4&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.pages=447-459&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1016%2Fj.joi.2010.04.001&amp;rft.aulast=Serenko&amp;rft.aufirst=Alexander&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.aserenko.com%2Fpapers%2FJOI_Serenko_AI_Journal_Ranking_Published.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArtificial+intelligence">
      <span style="display:none;">
      </span>
     </span>
    </li>
    <li>
     <cite class="citation journal">
      Serenko, Alexander; Michael Dohan (2011).
      <a class="external text" href="http://www.aserenko.com/papers/JOI_AI_Journal_Ranking_Serenko.pdf" rel="nofollow">
       "Comparing the expert survey and citation impact journal ranking methods: Example from the field of Artificial Intelligence"
      </a>
      <span style="font-size:85%;">
       (PDF)
      </span>
      .
      <i>
       Journal of Informetrics
      </i>
      .
      <b>
       5
      </b>
      (4): 629–649.
      <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">
       doi
      </a>
      :
      <a class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.1016%2Fj.joi.2011.06.002" rel="nofollow">
       10.1016/j.joi.2011.06.002
      </a>
      .
     </cite>
     <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Informetrics&amp;rft.atitle=Comparing+the+expert+survey+and+citation+impact+journal+ranking+methods%3A+Example+from+the+field+of+Artificial+Intelligence&amp;rft.volume=5&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.pages=629-649&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1016%2Fj.joi.2011.06.002&amp;rft.aulast=Serenko&amp;rft.aufirst=Alexander&amp;rft.au=Michael+Dohan&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.aserenko.com%2Fpapers%2FJOI_AI_Journal_Ranking_Serenko.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArtificial+intelligence">
      <span style="display:none;">
      </span>
     </span>
    </li>
    <li>
     Sun, R. &amp; Bookman, L. (eds.),
     <i>
      Computational Architectures: Integrating Neural and Symbolic Processes
     </i>
     . Kluwer Academic Publishers, Needham, MA. 1994.
    </li>
    <li>
     <cite class="citation web">
      Tom Simonite (29 December 2014).
      <a class="external text" href="http://www.technologyreview.com/news/533686/2014-in-computing-breakthroughs-in-artificial-intelligence/" rel="nofollow">
       "2014 in Computing: Breakthroughs in Artificial Intelligence"
      </a>
      .
      <i>
       MIT Technology Review
      </i>
      .
     </cite>
     <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=MIT+Technology+Review&amp;rft.atitle=2014+in+Computing%3A+Breakthroughs+in+Artificial+Intelligence&amp;rft.date=2014-12-29&amp;rft.au=Tom+Simonite&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.technologyreview.com%2Fnews%2F533686%2F2014-in-computing-breakthroughs-in-artificial-intelligence%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArtificial+intelligence">
      <span style="display:none;">

     </span>
    </li>
   </ul>

   <ul>
    <li>
     <a class="external text" href="http://www-formal.stanford.edu/jmc/whatisai/whatisai.html" rel="nofollow">
      What Is AI?
     </a>
     – An introduction to artificial intelligence by
     <a href="/wiki/John_McCarthy_(computer_scientist)" title="John McCarthy (computer scientist)">
      John McCarthy
     </a>
     —a co-founder of the field, and the person who coined the term.
    </li>
    <li>
     <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/handbookofartific01barr/" rel="nofollow">
      The Handbook of Artificial Intelligence Volume Ⅰ by Avron Barr and Edward A. Feigenbaum (Stanford University)
     </a>
    </li>
    <li>
     <cite class="citation encyclopaedia">
      <a class="external text" href="http://www.iep.utm.edu/art-inte" rel="nofollow">
       "Artificial Intelligence"
      </a>
      .
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Internet_Encyclopedia_of_Philosophy" title="Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy">
        Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy
       </a>
      </i>
      .
     </cite>
     <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Artificial+Intelligence&amp;rft.btitle=Internet+Encyclopedia+of+Philosophy&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.iep.utm.edu%2Fart-inte&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArtificial+intelligence">
      <span style="display:none;">
      </span>
     </span>
    </li>
    <li>
     <cite class="citation encyclopaedia">
      Thomason, Richmond.
      <a class="external text" href="https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/logic-ai/" rel="nofollow">
       "Logic and Artificial Intelligence"
      </a>
      . In
      <a href="/wiki/Edward_N._Zalta" title="Edward N. Zalta">
       Zalta, Edward N.
      </a>
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Stanford_Encyclopedia_of_Philosophy" title="Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy">
        Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy
       </a>
      </i>
      .
     </cite>
     <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Logic+and+Artificial+Intelligence&amp;rft.btitle=Stanford+Encyclopedia+of+Philosophy&amp;rft.aulast=Thomason&amp;rft.aufirst=Richmond&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fplato.stanford.edu%2Fentries%2Flogic-ai%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArtificial+intelligence">
      <span style="display:none;">
      </span>
     </span>
    </li>
    <li>
     <a class="external text" href="https://curlie.org/Computers/Artificial_Intelligence/" rel="nofollow">
      AI
     </a>
     at Curlie (based on
     <a href="/wiki/DMOZ" title="DMOZ">
      DMOZ
     </a>
     )
    </li>
    <li>
     <a class="external text" href="http://aitopics.org/" rel="nofollow">
      AITopics
     </a>
     – A large directory of links and other resources maintained by the
     <a href="/wiki/Association_for_the_Advancement_of_Artificial_Intelligence" title="Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence">
      Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence
     </a>
     , the leading organization of academic AI researchers.
    </li>
    <li>
     <a class="external text" href="https://blog.standuply.com/200-ai-ml-conferences-in-2018-eec7d0a50bcf/" rel="nofollow">
      List of AI Conferences
     </a>
     – A list of 225 AI conferences taking place all over the world.
    </li>
   </ul>

           <th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">
            In fiction
           </th>
           <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd hlist" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">
            <div style="padding:0em 0.25em">

              <li>
               <a href="/wiki/The_Engine" title="The Engine">
                The Engine
               </a>
               (
               <i>
                <a href="/wiki/Gulliver%27s_Travels" title="Gulliver's Travels">
                 Gulliver's Travels
                </a>
               </i>
               , 1726)
              </li>
              <li>
               Joe ("
               <a href="/wiki/A_Logic_Named_Joe" title="A Logic Named Joe">
                A Logic Named Joe
               </a>
               ", 1946)
              </li>
              <li>
               The Librarian (
               <i>
                <a href="/wiki/Snow_Crash" title="Snow Crash">
                 Snow Crash
                </a>
               </i>
               , 1992)
              </li>
              <li>
               Dr. Know (
               <i>
                <a href="/wiki/A.I._Artificial_Intelligence" title="A.I. Artificial Intelligence">
                 A.I. Artificial Intelligence
                </a>
               </i>
               , 2001)
              </li>
              <li>
               Waterhouse (
               <i>
                <a href="/wiki/The_Baroque_Cycle" title="The Baroque Cycle">
                 The Baroque Cycle
                </a>
               </i>
               , 2003)
              </li>
             </ul>

            <div id="Major_fields_of_computer_science" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em">
             Major fields of
             <a href="/wiki/Computer_science" title="Computer science">
              computer science
             </a>
            </div>
           </th>
          </tr>

         </li>
         <li>
          <a href="/wiki/Problem_of_other_minds" title="Problem of other minds">
           Problem of other minds
          </a>
         </li>
         <li>
          <a href="/wiki/Propositional_attitude" title="Propositional attitude">

           Qualia
          </a>

           Tabula rasa

           Understanding
          </a>

           Zombie

      <th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">

      </th>
      <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">
       <div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
        <ul>
         <li>
          <span class="nowrap">
           <a href="/wiki/Library_of_Congress_Control_Number" title="Library of Congress Control Number">
            LCCN
           </a>
           :

            <a class="external text" href="http://id.loc.gov/authorities/subjects/sh85008180" rel="nofollow">
             sh85008180
            </a>

          </span>
         </li>

         </li>
         <li>

           <span class="uid">

       <a href="#cite_note-bini-23">
        [23]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Swift_(programming_language)" title="Swift (programming language)">
       Swift
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lattner2014_24-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-lattner2014-24">
        [24]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
     <td class="hlist" colspan="2" style="text-align:center;border-top: 1px solid #aaa; padding-top: 3px;">
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wikibooks-logo-en-noslogan.svg">
         <img alt="" class="noviewer" data-file-height="400" data-file-width="400" height="16" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Wikibooks-logo-en-noslogan.svg/16px-Wikibooks-logo-en-noslogan.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Wikibooks-logo-en-noslogan.svg/24px-Wikibooks-logo-en-noslogan.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Wikibooks-logo-en-noslogan.svg/32px-Wikibooks-logo-en-noslogan.svg.png 2x" width="16"/>
        </a>
        <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Python_Programming" title="wikibooks:Python Programming">
         Python Programming
        </a>
        at Wikibooks
       </li>
      </ul>
     </td>
    </tr>
   </table>
   <p>
    <b>
     Python
    </b>
    is an
    <a href="/wiki/Interpreted_language" title="Interpreted language">
     interpreted
    </a>
    <a href="/wiki/High-level_programming_language" title="High-level programming language">
     high-level programming language
    </a>
    for
    <a href="/wiki/General-purpose_programming_language" title="General-purpose programming language">
     general-purpose programming
    </a>
    . Created by
    <a href="/wiki/Guido_van_Rossum" title="Guido van Rossum">
     Guido van Rossum
    </a>
    and first released in 1991, Python has a design philosophy that emphasizes
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Code_readability" title="Code readability">
     code readability
    </a>
    , and a
    <a href="/wiki/Syntax_(programming_languages)" title="Syntax (programming languages)">
     syntax
    </a>
    that allows programmers to express concepts in fewer
    <a href="/wiki/Source_lines_of_code" title="Source lines of code">
     lines of code
    </a>
    ,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Summerfield_25-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-Summerfield-25">
      [25]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26">
     <a href="#cite_note-26">
      [26]
     </a>
    </sup>
    notably using
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Significant_whitespace" title="Significant whitespace">
     significant whitespace
    </a>
    . It provides constructs that enable clear programming on both small and large scales.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AutoNT-7_27-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-AutoNT-7-27">
      [27]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Python features a
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dynamic_type" title="Dynamic type">
     dynamic type
    </a>
    system and automatic
    <a href="/wiki/Memory_management" title="Memory management">
     memory management
    </a>
    . It supports multiple
    <a href="/wiki/Programming_paradigm" title="Programming paradigm">
     programming paradigms
    </a>
    , including
    <a href="/wiki/Object-oriented_programming" title="Object-oriented programming">
     object-oriented
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Imperative_programming" title="Imperative programming">
     imperative
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Functional_programming" title="Functional programming">
     functional
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Procedural_programming" title="Procedural programming">
     procedural
    </a>
    , and has a large and comprehensive
    <a href="/wiki/Standard_library" title="Standard library">
     standard library
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-About_28-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-About-28">
      [28]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Python interpreters are available for many
    <a href="/wiki/Operating_system" title="Operating system">
     operating systems
    </a>
    .
    <a href="/wiki/CPython" title="CPython">
     CPython
    </a>
    , the
    <a href="/wiki/Reference_implementation" title="Reference implementation">
     reference implementation
    </a>
    of Python, is
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Open_source" title="Open source">
     open source
    </a>
    software
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29">
     <a href="#cite_note-29">
      [29]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and has a community-based development model, as do nearly all of its variant implementations. CPython is managed by the non-profit
    <a href="/wiki/Python_Software_Foundation" title="Python Software Foundation">
     Python Software Foundation
    </a>
    .
   </p>
   <p>
   </p>
   <div class="toc" id="toc">
    <div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en">

   <p>
   </p>
   <h2>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="History">
     History
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Python_(programming_language)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: History">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="thumb tright">
    <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
     <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Guido_van_Rossum_OSCON_2006.jpg">
      <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3504" data-file-width="2336" height="330" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Guido_van_Rossum_OSCON_2006.jpg/220px-Guido_van_Rossum_OSCON_2006.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Guido_van_Rossum_OSCON_2006.jpg/330px-Guido_van_Rossum_OSCON_2006.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Guido_van_Rossum_OSCON_2006.jpg/440px-Guido_van_Rossum_OSCON_2006.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
     </a>
     <div class="thumbcaption">
      <div class="magnify">
       <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Guido_van_Rossum_OSCON_2006.jpg" title="Enlarge">
       </a>
      </div>
      <a href="/wiki/Guido_van_Rossum" title="Guido van Rossum">
       Guido van Rossum
      </a>
      , the creator of Python
     </div>
    </div>
   </div>
   <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
    Main article:
    <a href="/wiki/History_of_Python" title="History of Python">
     History of Python
    </a>
   </div>
   <p>
    Python was conceived in the late 1980s,
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-venners-interview-pt-1_30-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-venners-interview-pt-1-30">
      [30]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and its implementation began in December 1989
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-timeline-of-python_31-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-timeline-of-python-31">
      [31]
     </a>
    </sup>
    by
    <a href="/wiki/Guido_van_Rossum" title="Guido van Rossum">
     Guido van Rossum
    </a>
    at
    <a href="/wiki/Centrum_Wiskunde_%26_Informatica" title="Centrum Wiskunde &amp; Informatica">
     Centrum Wiskunde &amp; Informatica
    </a>
    (CWI) in the
    <a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">
     Netherlands
    </a>
    as a successor to the
    <a href="/wiki/ABC_(programming_language)" title="ABC (programming language)">
     ABC language
    </a>
    (itself inspired by
    <a href="/wiki/SETL" title="SETL">
     SETL
    </a>
    )
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AutoNT-12_32-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-AutoNT-12-32">
      [32]
     </a>
    </sup>
    capable of
    <a href="/wiki/Exception_handling" title="Exception handling">
     exception handling
    </a>
    and interfacing with the
    <a href="/wiki/Amoeba_(operating_system)" title="Amoeba (operating system)">
     Amoeba
    </a>
    operating system.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-faq-created_6-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-faq-created-6">
      [6]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Van Rossum remains Python's principal author. His continuing central role in Python's development is reflected in the title given to him by the Python community:
    <i>
     <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Benevolent_Dictator_For_Life" title="Benevolent Dictator For Life">
      Benevolent Dictator For Life
     </a>
    </i>
    (BDFL).
   </p>
   <p>
    On the origins of Python, Van Rossum wrote in 1996:
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33">
     <a href="#cite_note-33">
      [33]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <blockquote class="templatequote">
    <p>
     ...In December 1989, I was looking for a "hobby" programming project that would keep me occupied during the week around Christmas. My office ... would be closed, but I had a home computer, and not much else on my hands. I decided to write an interpreter for the new scripting language I had been thinking about lately: a descendant of
     <a href="/wiki/ABC_(programming_language)" title="ABC (programming language)">
      ABC
     </a>
     that would appeal to
     <a href="/wiki/Unix" title="Unix">
      Unix
     </a>
     /
     <a href="/wiki/C_(programming_language)" title="C (programming language)">
      C
     </a>
     <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hacker_(programmer_subculture)" title="Hacker (programmer subculture)">
      hackers
     </a>
     . I chose Python as a working title for the project, being in a slightly irreverent mood (and a big fan of
     <i>
      <a href="/wiki/Monty_Python%27s_Flying_Circus" title="Monty Python's Flying Circus">
       Monty Python's Flying Circus
      </a>
     </i>
     ).
    </p>
    <div class="templatequotecite">
     —
     <cite>
      Guido van Rossum
     </cite>
    </div>
   </blockquote>
   <p>
    Python 2.0 was released on 16 October 2000 and had many major new features, including a
    <a href="/wiki/Cycle_detection" title="Cycle detection">
     cycle-detecting
    </a>
    <a href="/wiki/Garbage_collection_(computer_science)" title="Garbage collection (computer science)">
     garbage collector
    </a>
    and support for
    <a href="/wiki/Unicode" title="Unicode">
     Unicode
    </a>
    . With this release, the development process became more transparent and community-backed.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-newin-2.0_34-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-newin-2.0-34">
      [34]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Python 3.0 (initially called Python 3000 or py3k) was released on 3 December 2008 after a long testing period. It is a major revision of the language that is not completely
    <a href="/wiki/Backward_compatibility" title="Backward compatibility">
     backward-compatible
    </a>
    with previous versions.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3.0-release_35-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-3.0-release-35">
      [35]
     </a>
    </sup>
    However, many of its major features have been
    <a href="/wiki/Backporting" title="Backporting">
     backported
    </a>
    to the Python 2.6.x
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pep-3000_36-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-pep-3000-36">
      [36]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and 2.7.x version series, and releases of Python 3 include the
    <code>
     2to3
    </code>
    utility, which automates the translation of Python 2 code to Python 3.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37">
     <a href="#cite_note-37">
      [37]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Python 2.7's
    <a href="/wiki/End-of-life_(product)" title="End-of-life (product)">
     end-of-life
    </a>
    date (a.k.a. EOL, sunset date) was initially set at 2015, then postponed to 2020 out of concern that a large body of existing code could not easily be forward-ported to Python 3.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38">
     <a href="#cite_note-38">
      [38]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39">
     <a href="#cite_note-39">
      [39]
     </a>
    </sup>
    In January 2017, Google announced work on a Python 2.7 to
    <a href="/wiki/Go_(programming_language)" title="Go (programming language)">
     Go
    </a>
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Transcompiler" title="Transcompiler">
     transcompiler
    </a>
    to improve performance under concurrent workloads.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40">
     <a href="#cite_note-40">
      [40]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Python 3.6 had changes regarding
    <a href="/wiki/UTF-8" title="UTF-8">
     UTF-8
    </a>
    (in Windows, PEP 528 and PEP 529) and Python 3.7.0b1 (
    <a class="external text" href="https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0540/" rel="nofollow">
     PEP 540
    </a>
    ) adds a new "UTF-8 Mode" (and overrides
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/POSIX_locale" title="POSIX locale">
     POSIX locale
    </a>
    ).
   </p>
   <h2>
    <span class="mw-headline" id="Features_and_philosophy">
     Features and philosophy
    </span>
    <span class="mw-editsection">
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      [
     </span>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Python_(programming_language)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Features and philosophy">
      edit
     </a>
     <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
      ]
     </span>
    </span>
   </h2>
   <p>
    Python is a
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Multi-paradigm_programming_language" title="Multi-paradigm programming language">
     multi-paradigm programming language
    </a>
    .
    <a href="/wiki/Object-oriented_programming" title="Object-oriented programming">
     Object-oriented programming
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Structured_programming" title="Structured programming">
     structured programming
    </a>
    are fully supported, and many of its features support
    <a href="/wiki/Functional_programming" title="Functional programming">
     functional programming
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Aspect-oriented_programming" title="Aspect-oriented programming">
     aspect-oriented programming
    </a>
    (including by
    <a href="/wiki/Metaprogramming" title="Metaprogramming">
     metaprogramming
    </a>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AutoNT-13_41-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-AutoNT-13-41">
      [41]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Metaobject" title="Metaobject">
     metaobjects
    </a>
    (magic methods)).
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AutoNT-14_42-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-AutoNT-14-42">
      [42]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Many other paradigms are supported via extensions, including
    <a href="/wiki/Design_by_contract" title="Design by contract">
     design by contract
    </a>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AutoNT-15_43-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-AutoNT-15-43">
      [43]
     </a>
    </sup>
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AutoNT-16_44-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-AutoNT-16-44">
      [44]
     </a>
    </sup>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Logic_programming" title="Logic programming">
     logic programming
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AutoNT-17_45-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-AutoNT-17-45">
      [45]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Python uses
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dynamic_typing" title="Dynamic typing">
     dynamic typing
    </a>
    , and a combination of
    <a href="/wiki/Reference_counting" title="Reference counting">
     reference counting
    </a>
    and a cycle-detecting garbage collector for
    <a href="/wiki/Memory_management" title="Memory management">
     memory management
    </a>
    . It also features dynamic
    <a href="/wiki/Name_resolution_(programming_languages)" title="Name resolution (programming languages)">
     name resolution
    </a>
    (
    <a href="/wiki/Late_binding" title="Late binding">
     late binding
    </a>
    ), which binds method and variable names during program execution.
   </p>
   <p>
    Python's design offers some support for
    <a href="/wiki/Functional_programming" title="Functional programming">
     functional programming
    </a>
    in the
    <a href="/wiki/Lisp_(programming_language)" title="Lisp (programming language)">
     Lisp
    </a>
    tradition. It has
    <code>
     filter()
    </code>
    ,
    <code>
     map()
    </code>
    , and
    <code>
     reduce()
    </code>
    functions;
    <a href="/wiki/List_comprehension" title="List comprehension">
     list comprehensions
    </a>
    ,
    <a href="/wiki/Associative_array" title="Associative array">
     dictionaries
    </a>
    , and sets; and
    <a href="/wiki/Generator_(computer_programming)" title="Generator (computer programming)">
     generator
    </a>
    expressions.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AutoNT-59_46-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-AutoNT-59-46">
      [46]
     </a>
    </sup>
    The standard library has two modules (itertools and functools) that implement functional tools borrowed from
    <a href="/wiki/Haskell_(programming_language)" title="Haskell (programming language)">
     Haskell
    </a>
    and
    <a href="/wiki/Standard_ML" title="Standard ML">
     Standard ML
    </a>
    .
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AutoNT-18_47-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-AutoNT-18-47">
      [47]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    The language's core philosophy is summarized in the document
    <i>
     The
     <a href="/wiki/Zen_of_Python" title="Zen of Python">
      Zen of Python
     </a>
    </i>
    (
    <i>
     PEP 20
    </i>
    ), which includes
    <a href="/wiki/Aphorism" title="Aphorism">
     aphorisms
    </a>
    such as:
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PEP20_48-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-PEP20-48">
      [48]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <ul>
    <li>
     Beautiful is better than ugly
    </li>
    <li>
     Explicit is better than implicit
    </li>
    <li>
     Simple is better than complex
    </li>
    <li>
     Complex is better than complicated
    </li>
    <li>
     Readability counts
    </li>
   </ul>
   <p>
    Rather than having all of its functionality built into its core, Python was designed to be highly extensible. This compact modularity has made it particularly popular as a means of adding programmable interfaces to existing applications. Van Rossum's vision of a small core language with a large standard library and easily extensible interpreter stemmed from his frustrations with
    <a href="/wiki/ABC_(programming_language)" title="ABC (programming language)">
     ABC
    </a>
    , which espoused the opposite approach.
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-venners-interview-pt-1_30-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-venners-interview-pt-1-30">
      [30]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    While offering choice in coding methodology, the Python philosophy rejects exuberant syntax (such as that of
    <a href="/wiki/Perl" title="Perl">
     Perl
    </a>
    ) in favor of a simpler, less-cluttered grammar. As
    <a href="/wiki/Alex_Martelli" title="Alex Martelli">
     Alex Martelli
    </a>
    put it: "To describe something as 'clever' is
    <i>
     not
    </i>
    considered a compliment in the Python culture."
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AutoNT-19_49-0">
     <a href="#cite_note-AutoNT-19-49">
      [49]
     </a>
    </sup>
    Python's philosophy rejects the Perl "
    <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/There_is_more_than_one_way_to_do_it" title="There is more than one way to do it">
     there is more than one way to do it
    </a>
    " approach to language design in favor of "there should be one—and preferably only one—obvious way to do it".
    <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PEP20_48-1">
     <a href="#cite_note-PEP20-48">
      [48]
     </a>
    </sup>
   </p>
   <p>
    Python's developers strive to avoid
